DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum, and move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill covers a number of matters, some of which are minor procedural issues.
The first relates to the use of the terms `in-patient' and `patient'.

The Government, in co-operation with the States, the medical profession and the private health insurance funds, has been encouraging a move toward day surgery and day only procedures consistent with modern medical practice.

To facilitate this the relevant Acts were amended in 1989 to cover day surgery procedures. An integral component of those changes involved the substitution of the term `in-patient' in the National Health Act 1953 and the Health Insurance Act 1973 with the term `patient'. These changes removed the need to occupy a bed for private health insurance benefit purposes, thereby reducing the financial incentives for patients to be admitted overnight.

Although the reference to `in-patient' was substituted in the definition in the National Health Act it remains in the Health Insurance Act, the term `in-patient' still appears in error through the body of both Acts and this Bill deals with that oversight.

There is no policy implication of this tidying up except in one part of the National Health Act where the term `person' was inadvertently substituted in lieu of `patient'. Technically this inadvertent change would let private health funds refuse to pay benefits for new born babies in intensive care as they are technically not `patients' at the moment. The insurance funds understand, however, that this was an error and they are continuing to pay benefits while this change is being made.

The Bill also contains minor amendments to substitute the title of `Managing Director' for `General Manager' of the Health Insurance Commission wherever the term is used in the Health Insurance Act 1973, the Health Insurance Amendment Act 1991 and the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973.

The change of title is in line with the titles now used by other Government business enterprises. It is simply a change in title and it does not involve any change in the terms or conditions of the chief executive of the HIC.

The Bill also deals with one aspect of pathology. In some cases specimens received at one laboratory will be referred to another laboratory, for example, where they require testing on equipment not available at the first laboratory.

As the Act stands collection benefits are only payable where the specimen is collected by the pathologist or his or her employees. Where a specimen is sent to the second laboratory the collection benefit is not payable, as the staff employed by the first laboratory are not employees of the pathologist running the second laboratory. This Bill removes that anomaly.

The Bill also contains provisions which will repeal those sections of the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Act 1991 which related to the introduction of the interactive eligibility checking system and restricted the availability of pharmaceutical benefits to Australian residents and other eligible persons as defined in the Health Insurance Act 1973.
These provisions will not now come into effect because the conditions which had been inserted in the commencement provisions could not be met.

However, on 1 July 1992, new arrangements for checking eligibility to free or concessional pharmaceutical benefits will be introduced. These new arrangements relate to tighter administration of the existing legislation whereby claims that include prescriptions where the entitlement to concessional benefits is not valid will be reduced.

In these circumstances pharmacists will need to satisfy themselves that a person is entitled to concessional treatment. While the Government does not believe that there will be major difficulties in this, particularly as most pensioners, for example, are well known to their local pharmacist, there may be some cases where a person who is entitled to concessional treatment (ie currently paying up to $2.60 versus the up to $15.70 amount applying to general patients) has to pay the general patient rate at the time of dispensing.

Where such an event occurs and the patient can satisfy the HIC that he or she is entitled to the concessional rate there needs to be a power for the HIC to provide a refund. This Bill includes that power. This amendment will have effect from 1 July 1992.

A further change removes a technical difficulty with the definition of `approved pharmacist'. While State and Territory laws now prevent a person who is not a pharmacist from owning a pharmacy, this was not always the case. A number of pharmacies which are owned by non-pharmacists are currently operating under `grandfather' clauses. In these cases it was the practice to approve a pharmacist manager `for and on behalf' of the non-pharmacist owner; however, in accordance with recent legal advice it is now proposed to deem non-pharmacist owners, where this complies with State laws, as pharmacists for the purpose of supplying pharmaceutical benefits.

The Bill also makes provision to allow for the approval of suppliers to supply pharmaceutical benefits to be cancelled where it is clear that the supplier has ceased to supply pharmaceutical benefits, without having to wait for the approval to be inactive for six months before it can be cancelled. The other existing provisions which safeguard against inappropriate cancellation remain in place.

The Bill makes amendments to sections 4 and 5 of the Hearing Services Act 1991 that will further define `eligible persons'under the Act. The effect of these amendments will be that persons who are not Australian citizens nor Australian permanent residents will not be eligible for hearing services provided by the Commonwealth through the resources of Australian Hearing Services. The Minister may, however, determine (under paragraph 5(1)(h) of the Hearing Services Act) that certain persons who are neither Australian citizens nor Australian permanent residents can receive hearing services from the Australian Hearing Services Authority. The Bill also amends section 66 of the Hearing Services Act to extend the protection provided in that section to the statutory name `Australian Hearing Services'.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs for inquiry and report by the last sitting day in the Budget Sittings 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: The employment of visitors to Australia in the shearing industry with particular reference to:
(a)social and economic implications for rural communities;
(b)taxation arrangements;
(c)immigration regulations;
(d)international agreements; and
(e)industrial relations.

Mr President, I move this motion because in the community there is a great controversy about the role of New Zealand shearers in Australia. I must say at the outset that the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs is populated by senators who, while they may have a different agenda, have a clear intention when looking at any inquiries to find the truth and to make reports which are properly based and are useful to the Parliament and the people of this country. From that background I therefore give my support to this particular inquiry.

PARA.TAB: There have been allegations—and there continue to be allegations—that Australian workers in the shearing industry are severely disadvantaged by itinerant workers from New Zealand, who are able to take advantage of trans-Tasman travel arrangements and undercut existing working and award conditions. The result, they say, is that many locally based shearers who depend on local shearing contracts as their main source of income are now without work at a time when work opportunities in many industries are shrinking. This has caused a great deal of disruption and bad blood in many rural communities, even to the point of causing fights and brawls between Australian and New Zealand workers.

There is some evidence of widespread disregard for award conditions by graziers and shearing contractors, who have little or no regard for local workers and who appear to have deliberately set out on a path of breaking down the hard-won conditions and wages of Australian shearers. On the other hand, the graziers in the community are saying that very unreasonable terms are contained in the award; they wish to have weekend shearing and a number of other measures that they believe are proper and reasonable. So we have this controversy between the two groups. That controversy should be addressed and the truth made public.

All honourable senators present would be aware of the problems facing rural communities from the consequences of drought and recession in recent years. That makes the situation even worse. We have seen problems in the wool growing industry in recent years, especially with falling world commodity prices and diminishing world markets. These, combined with internal problems such as drought, have meant job losses in the wool industry. This has affected the shearing industry and the shearers themselves. It has exacerbated the problem in terms of the public debate and the effects that have been felt.

In that time both the Australian and the New Zealand economies have undergone substantial changes. New Zealand's new industrial relations laws and consumption tax laws are two key examples; they have created a very different climate from that which existed when the trans-Tasman travel arrangements and closer economic relations were signed. It is necessary for us to consider these important treaties again in the light of the way they affect job opportunities and conditions in Australian industries. Claims have been made that small businesses in the bush are failing because these workers quickly move on or return to New Zealand, taking much needed income out of the district.

The terms of reference were very carefully crafted to provide a focus, but at the same time giving an opportunity for those people who have shown interest to give evidence to the Committee and put forward a point of view upon which the Committee can make a recommendation to the Parliament. It is not in any way an exercise in Kiwi bashing, which people might believe is the case. Those people in the industry who are interested will have an opportunity to come before the Committee and give their point of view, whereupon an objective view will then be expressed by the Committee.

There are people who believe that there will be a result that will show up one side or the other of the argument in a particularly good or bad light. They may very well get a shock. I know from personal discussions with people from the AWU that they are prepared to accept the findings of the Committee, spots, bumps and all. I ask people in the rural community and the wool growing industry to accept it in the same spirit. I ask people in the Opposition to consider the remarks I have made. I certainly want to see a result that will be beneficial generally to the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the motion moved by Senator Burns, it is the view of the Opposition that it is an inappropriate time for this reference to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. Senator Burns has canvassed some of the issues. We could talk about drought and recession, of course, but it is not entirely relevant to the motion before the chamber.

PARA.TAB: The real reason we feel it is inappropriate is that the Committee is busy at present. It has an inquiry into lot feeding in Australia before it. The Senate is sitting for just about the rest of this year. We look like sitting for about six weeks out of seven in November and December. There undoubtedly will be an election this year or early next year and, generally speaking, the time of those on the Committee is pretty well committed. To embark on an inquiry that cannot then be done properly and in depth or which is open ended seems very foolish and a waste of Senate resources. Certainly, the Committee's Opposition senators are on other committees as well and have very heavy commitments. Generally, we take the view that it is not the right time to be referring this matter.

There is the risk of this inquiry being seen as an attack on New Zealand workers. There are a lot of New Zealanders in this country besides shearers and I think this reference raises a whole lot more than merely the question of shearers. In particular the motion refers to `the employment of visitors to Australia in the shearing industry'. The words `visitors to Australia' will undoubtedly cause other New Zealanders who are working here to feel that they are under threat as well by the terms of this inquiry, and that would be a pity.

It is important that this country has a close relationship with New Zealand, as it does. We have the closer economic relationship. The shearing issue is a part of that and I do not think it can be looked at in isolation. There was an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 14 September, entitled `Shearer survey fails to prove kiwi abuses'. There is quite a lot in this, but there is a great deal more in it than shearing.

The workload of the Committee and of the senators involved is quite heavy. The Opposition's senators, Senator Brownhill, Senator Crane and Senator Calvert, certainly are on other committees which are busy. Senator Bell certainly gives the impression of being busy and I would have thought that the Labor senators—Senator Reynolds, Senator Sherry and Senator West—were all heavily committed. It just seems an inappropriate time to be giving a reference to the Committee and, for that reason, we will not be supporting the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats strongly support the motion moved by Senator Burns, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. The primary argument advanced on behalf of the Opposition relating to time has little substance in light of the impression conveyed by the Chairman of the Committee. The members of the Committee, too, have enthusiastically endorsed the terms of reference of this proposed inquiry.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought the Chairman's opinion would have been given a bit more respect. The Chairman, after all, is in a position to know about the progress of the existing inquiry into the feedlot industry, an inquiry which the Chairman has assiduously addressed the Committee towards. The Committee in fact has undertaken the majority of its visits in the information gathering part of the inquiry and the evidence has been acquired from the travel that was necessary. The remainder of the work to be done in that part of the inquiry is not quite so time consuming.

The Committee itself of course understands the urgency of this particular issue. It has been bubbling away, if not fully boiling away, for many months and I think it is an issue which does not respect, and should not be related to, any election timetable or any other matter. It is an issue in its own right and needs and deserves to be addressed in its own right.

The Chairman has summarised the allegations that have been made surrounding the whole issue of visiting shearers in Australia and Senator Reid quite rightly points out that this is an issue which has the potential of broadening considerably. In fact, the intention of the Committee is to allow it to be broadened so that it becomes a little more than a debate in which a few slogans are thrown about in the media, in which a couple of surveys are run by a newspaper and an attempt is made to enter the debate without a complete set of facts.

If the debate comes before the Committee, the Committee has sufficient resources to deal with it, and the participants in the debate have the opportunity to broaden the issue and explain the full details without prejudice and without restraint. The fairest thing to do is to stop fiddling about with an article here and article there written by one or two journalists or one or two vested interests in the media. The Chairman's motion gives the opportunity for an inquiry to be conducted by the very committee which has the opportunity to put the matter in proper perspective and receive submissions from all interested parties. As the Chairman has already indicated, there is the potential for certain fixed positions to be challenged from one side or the other or from another side entirely. We support this opportunity.

The suggestion that the timing is not right is a pretty limp sort of suggestion, ill-informed about the progress of the Committee. The attempt to suggest that all the Committee members are busy is a bit of an insult to the diligence that has been displayed already by the members of the Committee. This Committee has been very productive, as one can see from the number of reports it has been capable of compiling, and very efficient in the use of the time available to it. I look forward to this Committee taking on this challenge.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion to refer the employment of visitors to Australia in the shearing industry to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. The case for the motion has been well put by the Chairman of that Committee, Senator Burns, and it has been supported by Senator Bell. There is widespread concern about this issue, not only in the industrial community but also in rural communities. What is needed is not the sort of confrontation pieces that we have seen—the polemics in the press about this. We want to see a thorough, considered examination of the issues involved. I certainly would like to see that and I think the proposal put forward by the Chairman of the Committee is a very good one.

PARA.TAB: The Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs is obviously the committee that should be dealing with this matter and it is quite able to deal with the matter. I cannot really see why—and I agree with Senator Bell on this point—the issue of the election should come into it. I respectfully disagree with Senator Reid on this point. Coincidentally, almost all of the members of that Committee are facing re-election in the coming election. None of the Opposition members of the Committee—Senator Brownhill, Senator Calvert and Senator Crane—is facing the forthcoming election. Senator Bell is not facing the forthcoming election—lucky him! I do not think Senator Burns—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not.
—No, Senator Burns is not.
—Are you suggesting senators don't work if they are not coming up for re-election?

—They do not work as hard, I should imagine. The whole point about it is that, irrespective of whether we are coming up for election, we should be working in the interests of the people. The fact that people are working on a matter of considerable concern to the community should surely be a plus, if we are looking at things in political terms. But I think this transcends politics, and Senator Burns said of his Committee that the matter would transcend politics if it were given to the Committee. Under those circumstances and because I want to see this matter transcend politics, I would like to see the matter go to the Committee, as proposed by the Chairman. I support the motion.

—in reply—The opposition we have heard to this motion was very feeble indeed and not based on facts. When the Committee discussed its capacity to carry out this inquiry, there was no opposition to the proposition that we could do so. I recall that on the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare four of the current members of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs were conducting four inquiries at the one time, and they finalised those four inquiries in a satisfactory fashion and very quickly.

PARA.TAB: Our Committee has set itself a timetable which we believe can be met. However, in the wisdom of the Senate, it may well be that it decides that there must be an extension. If that occurs and an election intervenes, so be it. It is an important matter and should be proceeded with fairly quickly.

The question was raised of only shearers being discussed. Of course there is not a problem only about the shearers. There have been small problems about workers from other countries for many years, but the shearers have been focused upon by the press and by the people it has interviewed and the observations they have made. It is a real issue; it is controversial. I do not see anybody going crook about Kiwi boilermakers or surveyors or engineers or nurses. So there is not a problem; why would we investigate it? Do not fix something that is not broken. The public debate makes this necessary.

I said at the beginning, and I know I have the support of everybody on the Committee, that this is not a Kiwi-bashing exercise. What does the word `Anzac' mean? There is a long and proud and friendly tradition of cooperation between our two countries and nothing is going to change that. But we do need to see what is happening in this industry and to get at the truth, so that everybody can understand it.

If the trans-Tasman arrangements or CER cannot stand up to some sort of examination, then they had better go. I believe the inquiry is a good task the Committee should set itself. The Committee will do it well, and I am sure that Senator Reid, on the presentation of the report, will be prepared to congratulate us on the job we have done.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services on the provisions of part 7, subscription television broadcasting services, of the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992, together with submissions, transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: To save time, I seek the Senate's leave to incorporate into Hansard a tabling statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON SUBSCRIPTION TELEVISION BROADCASTING SERVICES
TABLING STATEMENT

This report is the culmination of 10 weeks of intensive work by the Committee since 26 June. During this time, the Committee received 124 submissions and additional submissions, held 5 public hearings and, towards the end of the inquiry, held an extremely valuable "Round Table" meeting on technical matters with representatives of Government and industry.

Pay TV is one of those issues that never fails to invoke a great deal of opposing emotions. For the past ten weeks, members of the Committee have been exposed to the full range of views on all aspects of Pay TV, and, I might add, in concentrated form.
For example, of those who put views to the Committee:
.some do not want Pay TV at all, others regard Pay TV as Australia's passport to the 21st century;

.some say that Pay TV is not viable unless it is delivered by satellite, others say that Pay TV is not viable because it is delivered by satellite; yet others say that Pay TV is not viable no matter how it is delivered;

.the Committee was told by some that imposing Australian content requirement for programs or manufacturing would make Pay TV operators go broke; by others that unless an average of 70% Australian content requirement was imposed for programs and equipment, Australian industry would go broke.
And so it goes on.

From the outset, the Committee proceeded on the basis that this inquiry would not be "Pay Television re-visited," nor would the Committee set out to write the definitive report on Pay TV. In any case, the short time frame did not favour inquiries conducted on a grand scale.
Instead, the Committee sought hard to find common grounds on the remaining contentious issues on Pay TV so as to make the work of this Chamber easier when the legislation comes in here again.
These issues are:
.the conditions of participation in Pay TV by the ABC and SBS;
.the length of the exclusivity period for the initial Pay TV licence; and
.measures to optimise Australian programming content and manufacturing opportunities in Pay TV.
I am hopeful that we have pointed out some options that may yet break the parliamentary logjam over the legislation. Among the key recommendations regarding each issue:
ABC/SBS

The Committee has recommended that licence allocation be based on channels rather than transponders, and, on that basis, the initial licensee should be given three channels and the ABC one channel free of tender or charge. We think the ABC should be allowed to do what it does particularly well—produce a news and current affairs service of high quality.

When digital compression makes extra channels available, the initial licensee would be given half of the additional channels and the remainder should be returned to the ABA for re-allocation in a public process.

We are confident that this process would be to the benefit of the Australian public. Among other things, the ABC should have complete ownership of its subsidiary and complete control of programming and would also be required to adhere to a rule of at least 33 percent Australian content.
Australian Manufacturing Content

The Committee has sought to ensure that the Australian manufacturing industry will play a significant part in the Pay TV industry. To that end, it has recommended that 60% by added value of the transmission and reception equipment used in providing Pay TV be made in Australia, and that this content rule be monitored by the ABA.

A particularly significant recommendation that will impact on manufacturing is Recommendation 22, which requires the Government by regulation to set a common standard for licensees using analogue technology in order to ensure that analogue equipment may be inexpensively adapted for digital use.
Australian Programming Content

The Committee has made a number of recommendations to ensure that there is adequate Australian content in the programs shown over Pay TV channels. Among other things, the Committee has recommended that drama channels must ensure at least 15% of their expenditure be dedicated to new Australian program material; the definition of what is meant by "Australian drama" has been tightened up considerably; and the ABA is now also required to define what is meant by "new" Australian drama.
Exclusivity Period
Not surprisingly, the views of Committee members mirrored the wider debate in the Parliament and wider community, and common grounds did not come easily on some issues.

In particular, Members of the Committee could not reach agreement on one major issue, the period of exclusivity to be granted to the first licensee. Two Senators were of the view that there should be no exclusivity at all; one (myself) felt that the exclusivity period should be one year; two Senators felt that it should be three years, and one Senator, that it should be between three and five years.
These views are duly noted in the report. There are also Dissenting Reports by three Senators on the Committee on various other aspects of the Report.

On behalf of the Committee, I would like to thank the staff of the Committee Secretariat—Mr Robert King, Secretary; Ms Kay Chee Lance, Principal Research Officer; Miss Cheryl Scarlett, Senior Research Officer, and Ms Pamela Corrigan, Executive Assistant—for the hard work they have put into this inquiry.

In conclusion I would like to say that this has not been an easy inquiry, neither could it be called fun. However, we on the Committee have genuinely tried very hard to reach agreement on the key contentious issues to enable the legislation to pass. These efforts are reflected in the document before you and I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly to this report and the issues canvassed in the tabling statement. On behalf of all members of the Committee, I express our very sincere thanks to the staff who worked on the Select Committee—that is, the Secretary, Mr Robert King; the Principal Research Officer, Ms Kay Chee Lance; the Senior Research Officer, Miss Cheryl Scarlett; and the Executive Assistant, Ms Pamela Corrigan. Their work, with the very tough deadline we had, was very much appreciated. We would not have got the report out in the time that the Senate gave us without the dedicated work of the staff.

PARA.TAB: The tabling statement lists the fact that we received over 120 submissions and that we had hearings and so on. I want to comment very briefly on the difficulty the Committee had in dealing with many of the technical aspects of this issue.

All members of the Committee started off with certain ideological prejudices or views about what we thought of pay TV and what sort of model should be introduced. Throughout the hearing, we all found that our ideological predispositions became quite irrelevant when trying to deal with the complexities of technology and where it was going. The way in which the hearings were conducted and the level of questioning indicated that all members of the Committee were very keen to try to learn and understand the technology of this issue.

I do not think Senator MacGibbon would mind my repeating his private remark that in all the years he has been in the Senate serving on many Senate select committees and standing committees he has never served on a committee that has had to deal with such detailed complex technical issues as this Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services. I have not been here anywhere near as long as Senator MacGibbon. The only Committee I ever served on that came close in that respect was the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade when it dealt with nuclear ship visits, which became quite technical in one part.

The real problem Committee members had to deal with was the conflicting principles of what one wanted in the model. We had to deal with three major principles: the issue of exclusivity to encourage commercial viability; competition to provide consumers with a choice and to hold down costs to consumers; and using this new form of media in Australia to maintain and enhance media diversity in Australia. One could certainly adopt a model that dealt with only one or two of those principles rather than all three. The Committee was trying to deal with balancing out those three conflicting principles.

There were subissues to be dealt with that very much reflected the three major principles: how much Australian program content should be set; how much industry participation should be set; what sort of technology should be used, which was the most difficult issue for us as lay people to handle; and, finally, the role of the ABC and the SBS, which is one of the major issues referred to the Select Committee from the full Senate.

The Committee's report is not unanimous. There are dissenting reports, though there is overwhelmingly a majority view on the major issues before us. Without trying to describe it in her words, I believe that Senator Vicki Bourne's dissent is at the margin of the fundamental issues. The Opposition senators, Senator MacGibbon and Senator Alston, have put in a substantial minority report dealing with the fundamental difference of approach over such issues as exclusivity and competition.

There is no doubt that, as many of us expected, irrespective of the report and our majority recommendations, the matter has to come back into the Senate. It will be resolved in the Senate by at least two of the three major parties in the Senate agreeing one way or the other to a position that perhaps the House of Representatives could agree to as well. I suspect that the tabling of this report today is not the final step. It is a major step forward and it will be a major basis for further discussion within the full Senate between the political parties and the Government to try to get a working model through the Parliament.

It should be emphasised that all members of the Select Committee support the introduction of pay television; no-one on the Select Committee argues against its introduction. That is a major step forward in the public debate. I think that the process of the debate itself in the hearings of the Select Committee overwhelmingly proves that pay TV ought to be available for consumers in Australia. We are now one of the few—if not the only—major western advanced country that does not have pay television. It will be to our technological disadvantage in the long term not to start moving into pay TV. It is the beginning of providing a much wider range of personal communication, information and data information services to the public in Australia.

I want to conclude by thanking all the members of the Select Committee for the way they participated in the work of the Committee, particularly in the hearings, when we were dealing with very complex issues. Whatever the final outcome of pay TV in its final form, I believe the Select Committee has been a very useful public forum, not only for us, but also for the Australian public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join Senator Schacht in commending the work of the staff members who assisted in enabling the Committee to put down a report within an impossibly tight deadline, one that quite clearly was entirely politically motivated. It ought to be apparent that with issues of such complexity it is highly desirable that as much time as possible is allowed to explore them. I think that in the time available, the Committee did an excellent job in trying to come to terms with most of the issues, and the way in which the Committee was chaired was certainly conducive to that. I must say I was pleasantly surprised at the degree of harmony amongst Committee members when it came to a sensible examination of some very difficult issues.

PARA.TAB: I suppose what ought to be apparent to any, even cursory, reader of this report—and in a sense it has been glossed over in the way in which the report has been crafted—is that what Mr Keating did a matter of months ago, in throwing a dead cat into the ring by proposing this 12-month exclusivity model, has been exposed in this report for what it is worth. In other words, it was never a sensible, logical means of enabling pay television to get off the ground. It was simply a political deal done; yet another example of the `media for mates' approach that the Government constantly adopts; and, I think, yet another graphic illustration of the moral and intellectual bankruptcy of those who are not interested in getting policy right, but simply obsessed with getting the politics right.

If one looks at this report, it becomes blindingly obvious that virtually no-one supports a 12-month exclusivity period. A chart in the report shows that 13 of the 22 submissions which commented specifically on the exclusivity period argued for a longer period—from three to seven years. Indeed, that was Senator Schacht's starting position. It is a nonsense to have this sort of hopeless political compromise of 12 months.

One may take the view that all the old hang-ups that people have about infant industries need to be constrained, protected and pursued and that, therefore, a sufficient period of time should be provided for the initial licensee to get well and truly off the ground. Senators Beahan and Faulkner, to their credit, took the view that at least three years was needed in order to have a sensible period of exclusivity. As I say, that was Senator Schacht's initial view. He has now come around in the report to adopting the 12-month period, presumably so that the Prime Minister does not appear utterly and completely isolated.
The fact remains that overwhelmingly the weight of evidence rejected the logic and the economics of a 12 months proposal. If one looks at page 11 of the report one might be misled, because it says:

At the other end of the spectrum were those who advocated no exclusivity at all or expressed satisfaction with an exclusivity period of one year. The Committee noted the comments of Mr Stewart Fist, Hills Industries Limited, the Trade Practices Commission and Richard Rowe and Associates in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: That is really verging on the dishonest. The facts are that Richard Rowe and the Trade Practices Commission both argued against any form of exclusivity. Hills Industries said one year, but Mr Fist said that there should not be any exclusivity period. He took the view that giving three transponders to the initial licensee was more than a sufficient free kick. That glosses over the fact that overwhelmingly the evidence rejected the notion of 12 months exclusivity.

PARA.TAB: I think the dead cat Mr Keating threw into the ring on that notorious Sunday, when he humiliated the current Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) by rejecting his submission, which involved a five-year exclusivity period, and proposed this nonsensical political compromise, runs a very big risk of becoming a dead duck, and not just one we can treat with equanimity because it will be a side issue in politics. There is the very real risk that a monumental multimillion dollar disaster will befall the initial applicant. Many of the witnesses who appeared before the Committee made it very clear that the economics simply did not stack up and that the initial licensee was in very grave danger of either falling over or being fatally crippled by all the start-up costs and then finding that within a period of 12 months transponder licensees five and six would come along and swamp the initial licensee.

It ought to be made perfectly clear that what is contained in this document is a nonsense on the primary issue, and the evidence overwhelming demonstrates that. I think it is regrettable that the Government would appear to be still locked into defending the indefensible. What I think will be clear is that, despite the Prime Minister's continuing personal vendetta against the ABC and his reported reluctance still to allow it to have any sort of free access to pay television, it is very likely that we will see yet another deal done with the Democrats so that the ABC will be given the role the coalition has argued for from the outset, that is, a channel of its own, free of charge; and, we would argue, one that does not mandate programming. Indeed, the report argues that it ought to be confined to news and current affairs and that the first licensee should not broadcast news and current affairs.

The report is silent as to what would happen for subsequent licensees, who presumably then could come in and compete against the ABC. We would probably find that the first licensee was still locked out. That seems to me to be a very unfair and one-sided approach to the game. Nonetheless, it is very likely that the Government will come around to the view that the ABC ought to be allowed to have that access, simply so that the Democrats can then be persuaded to come down to the one-year exclusivity period which Senator Powell and Senator Bourne both reject. I would have thought that if they had any regard for the evidence they would have to say as I have said—that there was virtually nothing in the evidence to justify a 12-months exclusivity period.

There may be one or two of those who are prepared to bid for the first licence who would be prepared to wear it, but there can be little argument that they would be most unhappy and it certainly would not be their preference. An initial licensee would want as long a period of exclusivity as possible, for selfish reasons apart from viability reasons. Clearly, we can say that there is virtually no-one, apart from the Prime Minister and Senator Schacht, who appears to believe that 12 months exclusivity is desirable.

So what we have is in other respects a sensible recognition of realities, particularly the decision in relation to not mandating technology and transmission standards. That certainly was quite an achievement. There were those who urged us to start with digital and there were those who tried to persuade us that one form of analog was preferable to another, that the MPEG 2 standard for digital would be along shortly and, therefore, we could safely wait until then or require all licensees to start up on digital. But ultimately the Committee came to a very sensible judgment in that regard.

I strongly support from the outset the proposition that it is not up to the Government or, indeed, the Committee to try to outguess the experts on technology. The best way of judging that is to leave it to the players themselves. I should just say in passing that the principles to which Senator Schacht referred, which he has set out on page 6, do not adequately reflect the principles that one ought to bring into account. For example, I do not believe there is any such fundamental principle as the need for a period of exclusivity in order to maximise viability. I would certainly argue that viability is a relevant factor but that it ought to be a matter for the players and the marketplace. Certainly there is no divine right to a period of exclusivity, any more than there ought to be a divine right to tariff protection. Therefore, I do not accept that as one of the three principles. The need to ensure adequate competition certainly is, and the Trade Practices Commission will have a vital role to play in that regard.

The need to ensure diversity will be largely a matter for consumers, and I think it will evolve over time without any direct intervention. Certainly viability ought to be a matter for commercial judgment rather than for government intervention. Therefore, paragraph 2.7 should not be read as any sort of positive argument for the proposition that we need to have exclusivity and that if we do not it is not in the best interests of Australia. There is certainly a need for regulation in a number of areas, but as little as possible ought to be the starting point.

There is certainly no need for exclusivity. We have argued from the outset that each of those initial six transponders, apart from one set aside for the ABC, leaving five, ought to be made available at the same time through a competitive tender process. That is a rational, sensible, commercial approach. The Government chooses not to take it for reasons that escape logic and commonsense, which would presumably have much more to do with getting the politics right and providing a free kick for one or other of those who might come into the business. Certainly it ought to be made plain that there was nothing in the evidence of any of the witnesses who appeared before the Committee or who provided written argumentation that would in any shape or form justify that decision. When it is taken in due course, as I have no doubt it will be, it ought to be exposed for the sham that it is.

There are a number of areas of agreement. The exercise was worthwhile. We remain divided on the fundamental concept and the model that has been put forward. We have rejected it from the outset. We have been confirmed in that view by the witnesses who have appeared before the Committee. Our position in relation to the ABC is one that the Government will grudgingly come around to, because it will provide a lever for it to persuade the Democrats to adopt what is clearly an indefensible position. From their point of view, I would have thought it ought to be quite unacceptable. As the high protectionists in Australia, they are the ones who ought to be arguing for as long a period of exclusivity as possible. If they do not, then I will be confirmed in my suspicions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious from this report of the Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services that this is a massively complex and technical issue. We did find it very difficult to get our minds around all the issues that we were asked to, but I think in the end we made a pretty good job of it.

PARA.TAB: There is considerable disagreement among the experts on many areas in this report, especially technology. In particular, no-one has a crystal ball to foretell the speed with which inexpensive digital technology will become available. It is my personal view that we should start with digital technology if we are going to have pay TV at all, but it has been put to me by several people that if it is up to the key players, and if they are given about a two-year period to start up in, then we will start with digital technology anyway.

The Democrats have put in a dissenting report, which is quite short. In that report we point out three areas that we think are particularly important. The first is local content. The report says that 10 per cent local content is inadequate, and we absolutely agree. Every submission which addressed local content said that 10 per cent was inadequate. The report recommends 15 per cent, which is better than 10 per cent, but I still think, and the Democrats still think, that 20 per cent would be better than that.

For reasons of viability perhaps it might be a bit difficult to go over 20 per cent to start with. It would not be difficult to start at 20 per cent. We think that in about five years the Australian Broadcasting Authority should have a look at whether that should go up to 25 per cent. Indeed, I believe that if we have an independent and viable industry, we can go up much higher than 25 per cent.We had evidence that many countries around the world have minimum local content levels that are much higher than that. So once we start encouraging the industry we should have a sliding scale of local content going up; but we should start with 20 per cent.

The ABC was addressed. We still believe that the ABC should be mandated with a channel. Representatives of the ABC said that they would like to start with a news and current affairs channel. Certainly they do that very well, and we believe that they should be entitled to have the exclusive Australian news and current affairs channel. It is nice to have Australian news and current affairs rather than overseas news and current affairs going out to Australians.We also believe that the ABC should be able to have other channels. It would be in the public interest for the ABC to be given other channels by the ABA, either free of charge or at a considerably lower rate, when those channels are allocated.

The last item mentioned in our dissenting report concerned exclusivity. I would like to recommend to Senator Alston that he actually read the report. He obviously has not read the two parts in the report where the Democrats say that they would like a longer exclusivity period, which has led to his offensive comments about the Democrats.We said that we think a three-year period is a minimum and that we would like to see a five-year period. But we also put up another suggestion which was put to us and which we think is not a bad one. Rather than an exclusivity of total broadcast requirement, it would be an idea for the first licensee to be given programming exclusivity for either the movie or the sport channel, whichever it prefers, for a three-year period, and the ABC be given similar rights to the news and current affairs channel.

That would allow all licences to be allocated at once. The start-up period could be a maximum of two years and we could have three years after that, with exclusivity on either the movie or the sports channel and on the news channel—so it would only be two channels. Concerns about open competition, variety and stability of service for consumers, and encouragement of the establishment of a viable industry would be addressed. Manufacturing industry and production industry could also be addressed.

There are two further things. I would like to see the local content go past the drama channel and include the news channel and the sports channel. I believe that one would have to put up a very good argument to have lower than 20 per cent, 15 per cent, 10 per cent—whatever we end up with—local content in any channel whatsoever, not just drama.

Finally, and most importantly, I would like to congratulate the staff, along with Senator Alston and Senator Schacht, on their very good job. It was a very difficult and complicated area for the Committee, and it did an excellent job in a very short period of time under very difficult conditions. I would also like to congratulate the other members of the Committee.

It was a very civilised committee. We all got on very well. There was only one point at which I became a bit upset with one of the members of the Committee. That was when one witness was asked questions continually, started answering with 19 sentences, and was allowed by that one member of the Committee to finish four. I do not think that is good practice. We should all be looking at the way we treat witnesses before all of our committees. Apart from that, congratulations are due on a good report. I am looking forward to seeing the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take too much of the time of the Senate. This whole issue will be debated when part 7 of the Broadcasting Services Bill is considered by the Senate shortly. But I think it is important that I say something on the report of the Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services. From the day the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) expressed his view on how pay television should operate in this country, I said that the issue should go to a parliamentary committee for public scrutiny. Subsequently I served on that committee for a time—in fact, right up until it began its work on writing the report.

PARA.TAB: First of all, I want to thank the Committee for moving to allow me to continue to participate in the public hearings after I had been replaced as the Australian Democrat representative. I thought that was very generous of the Committee. I appreciated the opportunity to continue my work in an area in which I had, and still do have, considerable interest.

Although I have not had a chance to read the report yet, I felt a sense of deja vu in Senator Alston's remarks. Senator Alston seemed to be arguing today that a one year exclusivity is wrong and that there is more sense in a longer period of exclusivity. Yet, he is a signatory to a report that says no exclusivity.

The sense of deja vu arises from another exercise in broadcasting legislation, either in 1988 or 1989, in which the Opposition did not support a Government move to expand television audience reach from 60 per cent to 75 per cent because its policy was 100 per cent. I always thought that 75 per cent was at least some way towards 100 per cent from 60 per cent. But on that occasion as well I failed to follow the logic of the Opposition's broadcasting policy. I fail to follow it on this occasion. Nevertheless, I guess we will participate in that debate when the legislation is dealt with in this chamber.

I was pleased to hear Senator Schacht say that he believed this had been a positive exercise in a public discussion of a major issue—positive both in the context of the community, the interest groups and the industries concerned, and of the Senate Committee itself. That is quite contrary to the view he took late in the day when this Committee was being established. He had quite a different approach then.

At least I acknowledge Senator Schacht's change of view which does, I think, prove that the Committee's deliberations had been positive. I do not know that we can say they have been productive until we see in particular what the Government comes up with by way of legislation and then what the Parliament does with that legislation. I hope it will be productive.

I have been disappointed with what appears to be a continuing partisan approach, not in the investigations of the Committee but certainly in the eventual report. I hope that all members of the House of Representatives and the Senate, and in particular members of Cabinet and, I would suggest, members of the bureaucracy who are assisting the Government in putting together part 7, read the deliberations of the Committee, read the evidence and look at the compelling arguments that have been put for a model—a model different from that which the Government originally put forward at the behest of the Prime Minister.

As I say, the partisan flavour of the report is something of a disappointment. But an investigation has taken place and I believe it was positive. I hope that when we do get pay television in this country we will have a model which will work for Australian consumers and the Australian production and manufacturing industries.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation because I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I in no way wish to buck an agreement made in this chamber between the parties in relation to debate on the report of the Senate Select Committee on Subscription Television Services, and obviously at a later stage I shall make a more substantial contribution on the report.

PARA.TAB: On page 3 of yesterday's Australian Financial Review there was an article by Joanne Gray entitled `Pay-TV proposal gives 1-year start to ABC and rival'. It contains some clear inaccuracies and attributes to me positions that are not justified. I want to take this opportunity to clarify those matters. The fourth paragraph of the article states:

SPEECH.PARA: And one Labor committee member, Senator John Faulkner, is understood to differ with his two Labor colleagues, Senator Schacht and Senator Beahan, believing that the exclusivity period should be longer and that digital technology should be mandated.
In relation to the first point, the length of the exclusivity period, I think it is answered by paragraph 5.14 of the report. I quote the report:

The members of the Committee were divided in their conclusions on the need for a period of exclusivity, and on its duration. Senators Alston and MacGibbon were opposed to any period of exclusivity. Senator Schacht favoured a period of one year from the date of first transmission of programs. Senators Beahan and Faulkner concluded that three years was appropriate, and Senator Bourne argued for a period of three to five years.

In relation to the second issue raised in the article and attributed to myself, the question of digital technology being mandated, in private meetings of the Committee I did express my hope that the technology that would be used for the commencement of subscription television services would be digital technology. The Committee received conflicting evidence on when the first operator will be able to commence operation and whether that time frame will allow the first operator to commence operation with digital technology. If the introduction of digital technology were to mean a long delay in commencing pay TV services in Australia, then I would suggest that such a delay would be very hard to justify.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned about the impact on the costs to consumers if services commence in analog, as there would then need to be a transition from analog to digital, and I am concerned about the level of consumer take-up of subscription TV services. I hope that services begin with digital technology. I did not argue or recommend that the digital technology be mandated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill and I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: CRIMES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

This Bill proposes amendments to a number of Acts dealing with Commonwealth criminal law. These amendments will enhance the effectiveness of legislation central to the fight against organised crime and serious fraud:

amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 revise the account-opening provisions of that Act to reduce costs and minimise anti-competitive aspects of the verification procedures. They implement recommendations made by bankers and other members of the Ministerial Advisory Committee on the Operation of the CTR Act for streamlined procedures for account verification. In addition, the amendments give effect to community requests for a broader range of verification procedures and facilitate suspect transaction reporting under State and Territory law.

amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act broaden the application of the money-laundering offence to the proceeds of a wider range of foreign offences including the proceeds of arms trafficking or the ransom money from foreign kidnapping.

an amendment to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 will enable Australia to accede to the Council of Europe Convention on Laundering, Search, Seizure and Confiscation of the Proceeds from Crime thereby broadening the network of assistance available in such matters.

the Crimes Act 1914 is to be amended to create a new offence of piracy based on the 1958 Geneva Convention on the High Seas and also to implement a number of recommendations by the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law of which the most significant is the introduction of a system of penalty units for offences against Commonwealth laws.
there are also a number of minor amendments to other Acts such as the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983, the Australian Federal Police Act and various confiscation laws.
Turning to the detail of some of the more significant provisions of the Bill:
CASH TRANSACTION REPORTS ACT 1988

There are a number of technical amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988. Some of these amendments have been recommended to the Attorney-General by the Ministerial Advisory Group on the Operation of the CTR Act which was established to provide a formal forum in which cash dealers could bring directly to the Attorney-General's attention any concerns or suggested improvements to the Act. That committee recommended a number of changes to the account verification scheme to make it more flexible and less onerous without detracting from the law enforcement benefits of the scheme. These amendments are contained in the Bill and I thank the cash dealers for their thorough examination of these issues.

Other amendments are proposed in response to the needs of certain groups in the community who need to open accounts in a name other than that by which they have been commonly known. Such groups are victims of violence or threatened violence and their dependants, women who change their name following marriage or the breakdown of a relationship and Aborigines or Torres Strait Islanders who wish to use a traditional name. A referee procedure will enable these groups to become signatories to accounts without the need to meet the usual requirements in relation to documentation.

Suspect transaction reporting has been in place at the Commonwealth level for 2 1/2 years. State and Territory Governments have now recognised its benefits and are enacting complementary legislation to require reporting of transactions relating to State offences and to empower State police to follow up such reports. As these matters generally also involve tax evasion, they are already reported to the CTRA. Therefore, it has been agreed that the CTRA should be the recipient of reports under State law. Accordingly, the Bill will enable the CTRA to receive and deal with information reported under State legislation as if it were reported under the Commonwealth Act. The Victorian government has already introduced amendments to its Crimes (Confiscation of Profits) Act requiring the reporting of suspect transactions to the CTRA and other States and the Territories are expected to follow.

The success of Australia's cash transaction initiative is rapidly gaining world-wide recognition. Earlier this year a team of examiners from the US, Japan and Sweden visited Australia to assess, at first hand, Australia's implementation of the 40 anti-money laundering initiatives developed by the G7 Financial Action Task Force (FATF) in 1990. We can all take considerable pride in the fact that this team of experts formed the view that Australia had already implemented 39 of those 40 recommendations and will have achieved full implementation on ratifying the Vienna Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances, which I expect will occur later this year.

This achievement is drawing experts from throughout the world to inspect the systems used by the CTRA and to examine closely the legislation which supports it. Scrutiny will be at its most intense under Australia's Presidency of that Task Force during 1992-93. The Task Force met in Sydney in early September—only the second time that the group has met outside Europe.

Just as the CTRA is under close international scrutiny, our own formal review of the operation of the Cash Transaction Reports Act which is due to be completed by mid 1993, will commence. The FATF examiners commented "Australia benefits from having a well thought out system, which is reviewed as energetically as it is implemented." and also "The high degree of acceptance of this system, by both the banking and enforcement communities, and the high level of cooperation and coordination which mark its operations, is in part a tribute to careful planning, but also to intensive consultation." The amendments now before the Parliament are a result of both these review and consultation processes.
CRIMES (SUPERANNUATION BENEFITS) ACT 1989
The amendments to the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Act clarify the meaning of "sentence" in the Act and clarify the entitlement to employee contributions following the making of an order.
PROCEEDS OF CRIME ACT 1987

The amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act will extend the ambit of the money-laundering offences in sections 81 and 82 in so far as they relate to foreign offences. Currently it is only an offence to launder the proceeds of a foreign drug offence. Proceeds of arms trafficking, kidnapping and other serious offences are not covered. In keeping with our international obligations and to provide greater protection to our own institutions against infiltration by foreign criminals, it is proposed to extend the money laundering offence to proceeds of all serious foreign offences.

Other amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act facilitate the payment of pecuniary penalties from property restrained under the Act and enable the Commonwealth to protect and preserve forfeited property during the appeal period. Amendments are proposed to similar provisions in other confiscation legislation.
CRIMES ACT 1914

The main amendments to the Crimes Act 1914 implement recommendations of the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law chaired by Sir Harry Gibbs, GCMG, AC, KBE for the introduction of a penalty units scheme into Commonwealth legislation. The scheme will facilitate the calculation and updating of monetary penalties for Commonwealth offences and is modelled on similar schemes which have been operating in some States for a number of years. In future, provisions creating offences will prescribe the maximum number of penalty units and the Crimes Act will prescribe the value of a penalty unit. Thus, by simple amendment of one provision, the Parliament can ensure that the penalties for all Commonwealth offences reflect current monetary values. That will not preclude Parliament from using legislation to reflect the seriousness with which any particular offence is viewed by the Parliament by altering the number of penalty units prescribed for a particular offence. It has been recommended that the value of a penalty unit be set initially at $100. Further amendments to the Crimes Act will clarify the time limitation period for the commencement of prosecutions against corporations.

Another recommendation of the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law relates to the restriction on the availability of imprisonment where an offence involves only small amounts of money. This recommendation is based on the view that the criteria is simplistic and does not take account of the fact that, in offences such as bribery, it is not the amount offered as the bribe which determines the seriousness of the offence but rather the nature of the office sought to be corrupted. Therefore, the restriction on the use of imprisonment should apply only to specified offences. The Bill implements this recommendation.

Part IV of the Bill creates a modern offence of piracy based on the 1958 Geneva Convention on the High Seas. It is also closely based on customary international law which is reflected in the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. The amendment implements the relevant recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission report No 48 on Criminal Admiralty Jurisdiction and Prize. At present, the law relating to piracy is governed by Imperial Acts together with various State and Territory provisions. The report identified serious problems with this system. The imperial legislation is outdated, its application in Australia is uncertain, and jurisdiction over the forfeiture of ships and goods is vested in Australian Admiralty courts which no longer exist. In addition, the validity and scope of the various State and Territory provisions is doubtful. The international rules about apprehension of pirate vessels are an exception to the rule that foreign ships may not be apprehended on the high seas or while in innocent passage through the territorial sea. Therefore, these provisions define `act of piracy' for this purpose in the terms accepted by the international community in the 1958 Convention on the High Seas. The definition is intended to embrace only conduct to be regarded as piracy for the purpose of the Convention, and does not extend to conduct that, while it might involve some interference with shipping, is no more than a simple expression of protest eg by a public interest environmental group. However, it is important to note that such conduct, while not `piracy' in the international law sense, might still involve an offence against Australian law, for example under the Crimes at Sea Act 1979, provided there is a relevant connection with Australia.
The proposed new provision will make the Australian law in relation to the offence of piracy clear and concise, and will restore jurisdiction over seizures and forfeiture to the Australian Courts.
MUTUAL ASSISTANCE IN CRIMINAL MATTERS ACT 1987

Australia is likely to accede to the Council of Europe Convention on Laundering, Search, Seizure and Confiscation of the Proceeds from Crime. Australia is entitled to become a party because of its involvement in the drafting of the Convention. The Convention does not require documents transmitted between States party to the Convention to be authenticated. The amendment proposed to the authentication provision of the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 will enable Australia to comply with the Convention in this respect by rendering documents received in Australia pursuant to the Convention admissible in evidence in court proceedings relating to the tracing, freezing and confiscation of the proceeds of crime.
AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE ACT 1979

The most significant amendment to the Australian Federal Police Act will be to enable a female member or staff member of the AFP to be promoted during a period of maternity leave. S.34A of the Act, by suspending a member's or staff member's fixed term appointment during maternity leave, ensures that she does not lose part of her maternity leave entitlement because her appointment terminates during the leave. The proposed amendment to the section will remove the unintended discriminatory effect of preventing her promotion during that time.

Other amendments ensure that staff members are included in the scheme for the confiscation of superannuation rights and benefits of AFP members and staff members who have been found guilty of corruption offences.
DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC PROSECUTIONS ACT 1983

The amendments to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act will empower the Director of Public Prosecutions to arrange representation by State and Territory counterparts in Commonwealth matters such as offences connected with community policing in the ACT, guilty pleas in remote areas, mentions and the like where the matter is more appropriately or readily dealt with by that agency.
FINANCIAL IMPACT

These amendments will have no financial impact on the Commonwealth but the changes to the account verification provisions of the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 may reduce the costs of compliance to cash dealers.

In totality these relatively minor amendments not only strengthen the Commonwealth's criminal law regime but ensure that the Commonwealth maintains national and international cooperation in the fight against crime.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 9 September, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now debating the Swimming Pools Tax Refund Bill 1992, a very serious matter because this Bill purports to retrospectively take away rights which have accrued following a High Court judgment. Furthermore, these rights have already been subject to challenge in the court. As late as last Thursday a judgment was given severely criticising the action of the Australian Taxation Office and this Government.

PARA.TAB: Not only is this Bill unworkable but in its present form it will also not achieve its stated objective. It is reprehensible in that it contravenes accepted principles against retrospective legislation and constitutional principles concerning acquisition of property by the Commonwealth.

I submit that if this Bill is not amended in the way in which the Opposition puts forward, it will cause dissension within consumer groups because its effect will be one of inconsistent dealings. But it will have a wider impact in the long term which I do not think will enhance the status of the Government or the Taxation Office because this legislation and this taking away of rights—established under contract, legally binding, between ordinary citizens and the Tax Office—will not engender trust. In this particular instance pool builders will no longer trust the ATO, which has a history of agreements and ensuring negotiations, because the question in people's minds will always be: will the Tax Office challenge refunds or improper payments actually made or delay payments? It has been put to me that counsel would be negligent in not advising clients when entering into such agreements with the Tax Office about a likely challenge or likely legislation to offset the effect of what would otherwise be a legally binding agreement.

This legislation was subject to quite extensive evaluation by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Although we are unhappy that inadequate time was allowed to fully examine all the aspects of the Bill and to enable negotiation and consultation to continue, this legislation has been rushed into this chamber today. As late as the other evening meaningful negotiations were taking place. I commend the Taxation Office and the Government for allowing that to take place.

Hence my surprise this morning to find that this Bill is being rushed through, which will prejudice those negotiations. I think that is unfortunate, because it could have been possible, with suitable amendment and goodwill on all sides. I submit that there was that goodwill. We have officers from the Taxation Office who are prepared to negotiate in a responsible and meaningful way within the limits of the powers that were given to them, and also other officers who were involved in court action and people who would be affected as a result of this litigation.

Therefore, one must ask the question: why the haste? Is the Government fearful of further critical comment from the Federal Court about its reprehensible action on this Bill? I leave listeners and readers of the Hansard to make up their own minds.

To put it into perspective, it is important perhaps that the coalition was somewhat unhappy following that evaluation. Senators Kemp and Campbell and I have brought down a minority report. That minority report clearly states that we believe that those who are entitled to the refund should get it. I do not want that important principle lost in the debate that is likely to follow. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, those who ultimately paid the sales tax on inground swimming pools are entitled to a refund. This Bill fails to achieve that objective.
The Government's handling of this legislation has been deplorable.
The Government is to be condemned for:
(1) its failure to allow adequate time for the Committee to fully examine the Bill in the light of expert advice.

(2) its failure to remove from the ambit of the Bill the refunds payable pursuant to the agreement between the Swimming Pool and Spa Owners Association and the Australian Taxation Office entered into in November 1990.
(3) otherwise, its failure to amend the Bill to facilitate a more effective system of refunds.

The attitude of the Government in deliberately moving to legislate out of existence a formal agreement, voluntarily entered into by parties in good faith, will set a dangerous precedent that can only undermine public confidence in future agreements between taxpayers and the ATO.
Indeed, it could be said that, to this extent, the legislation abrogates the rule of law.

The Government's approach is all the more reprehensible because it intends to continue to pursue this course of action in the face of a decision of the Federal Court (Queensland G89 & 90 of 1992) which in recent days upheld the rights of members of SPASA to recover refunds under the agreement. Indeed, the court described as `unconscionable' the action of the ATO in denying to SPASA members their entitlement to refunds.
The statement by the Parliamentary Secretary—
undoubtedly made under duress—

Senator McMullan, in evidence to the Committee that `the court has interpreted the agreement in an unacceptable way so we are legislating to overturn it.' amply demonstrates the Government's determination to legislate away the rights of citizens rather than to appeal the decision in the normal way.

While the Government has foreshadowed amendments to improve the refund process, we do not believe they are adequate to meet the twin objectives of honouring the SPASA/ATO agreements and providing a refund mechanism equitable to both pool purchasers and pool builders.

Therefore, there must be a hidden agenda in this Bill. This is the most worrying problem in that the legislation demonstrates the Government's contempt of the High Court, and its willingness to dishonour an agreement made by an instrumentality—an agency—of government entered into in good faith, and members of an association, in this case the Swimming Pools and Spa Association of Australia. That agreement is threatened, which is a worry. The reason for the coalition amendment is to ensure that the Government does honour that commitment and, at the same time, that those who are entitled to the refund get it.

PARA.TAB: If the Bill is passed without an amendment to remove the SPASA-ATO agreement, there will be serious commercial difficulties for government, as people will no longer be able to feel secure in entering into agreements with the Commonwealth. This is a major worry, particularly as it has retrospective effect. This is not the first time that this has happened. Honourable members and senators may be aware that in 1990 there was an excise case involving BHP, and its rights were retrospectively taken away. We believe that that set a dangerous precedent, and I submit that that precedent has been replicated here today in the legislation before us. While the Parliamentary Secretary said that the Government does not lightly override such agreements, that is not good enough. Retrospective taxation, retrospective overriding of agreements and overriding of High Court actions and Federal Court actions, I believe, are deplorable acts of government.

Perhaps I should outline the sequence of events which led to this situation. Wholesale sales tax was introduced on in-ground pools in 1986. This represented a new field of tax because, for the first time, the tax was not imposed on goods as compared with a tax which had for several years been imposed on fibreglass pool shells. A concrete pool constructed on site, according to the legislation of the time, was deemed to be goods. The High Court found that this was not correct. A complicated method of calculating the tax was established, which included construction materials and labour as well as profit and overheads.

The tax was contested in the High Court where a ruling was handed down that the tax was unconstitutional for technical reasons. This judgment gave the moneys which had been collected under the tax an unclear status of `non-tax'. The Tax Commissioner could not rely on refunds under the sales tax legislation. The tax—we will call it a tax for want of a better word although it was unconstitutional and, therefore, not a tax—from the beginning was complicated and naturally very difficult to administer. This gave rise to a number of obscure situations for which, ultimately, customers, builders and manufacturers of fibreglass pools all effectively paid an indirect price or penalty.

The tax had been levied with the intention of bringing concrete pools into line with fibreglass pools. However, there was an anomaly in that the price was levied on the total cost of the concrete pool but only on the shell of the fibreglass pool, which is only about half the cost of the completed project. The deeming provisions caused confusion and uncertainty with regard to the application of the tax. There were, of course, errors of understatement and overstatement and an increase in avoidance schemes. These schemes were complex and difficult for the Taxation Office to monitor and police, and we acknowledge that. The problems led to many efforts to sidestep what the industry and the public regarded as a grossly unfair and suspect levy.

One of the main ways in which payment of tax was avoided was the use of the exemption for the owner builder. As might be expected, during the period from 1986 the number of owner builders skyrocketed from an estimated 2 per cent to around 30 per cent in 1990 in New South Wales for pools which were approved by local councils. Of course in Queensland, particularly along the Gold Coast, there are a whole lot more and the percentage was a lot higher.
