There is no reason to suppose that the ratios would be different in other States. The industry as a whole was well aware that a number of builders were avoiding tax under bogus claims as owner builders.

This particular scheme accounts for about one-third of the pools built. When an array of other schemes is taken into account, it becomes obvious that the figure could be estimated at half the total number of pools built. So we acknowledge there was a real problem. Such a situation is only ever harmful to aboveboard operators because these honest people have to compete with builders who are not paying tax. In order to do this they have to carry the cost of the tax themselves or carry other losses.

During the early period of the imposition of the tax there was a significant amount of activity and prosperity in the industry, and a number of legitimate pool builders were able to survive, but as the recession bit and the industry was squeezed it became more and more difficult. Many of the taxpaying operators became increasingly concerned by the failure of the non-specialists to pay tax and their consequent competitive edge, along with that from the fibreglass pool manufacturers. Naturally, complaints were lodged with the Taxation Office which was provided with an outline of the problem. However, the Commissioner proved unwilling or unable to act—and that is the problem. We have seen this so often.

It was at this point that the Swimming Pools Association moved to engage the service of professional advisers in the tax field. Thus, negotiations began for the redistribution of the tax burden in the industry. These moves met with no success and led to the beginnings of the situation which resulted in the High Court challenge. SPASA members began to appreciate that there was a problem with the tax and commenced making payments into a trust fund rather than to the Australian Taxation Office, pending the outcome of the case. This would enable the Association to remit the tax if the case was not found in its favour or, alternatively, to have access to the funds if the ruling went its way.

However, in 1990 the Tax Office insisted on the discontinuance of this arrangement and required the resumption of monthly payments, even in the face of legal challenge. This was, of course, the situation which produced the eventual agreement between SPASA's accountants and the Taxation Office in 1990. Under the agreement the pool builders would resume payments to the Tax Office, including moneys already held in trust, on the understanding that, if a legal challenge were upheld, the Tax Office would refund all the disputed refunds as well as interest at the same rate as applied to the overpaid tax. This was the condition on which the swimming pool builders were willing to continue to make payments.

Under this legally binding agreement the SPASA members were the taxpayers and there was never any provision or assumption that repayments should necessarily be made to somebody else, namely, the end point customer, and with that point I must say I have some little concern. I submit that, using the court actions, it would have been possible for SPASA to have applied to the court for that refund to flow through.

It was, from the beginning, the contention of the SPASA members that the money was not, nor ever had been, sales tax. The contention was ultimately upheld by the High Court. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that any restrictions on refunds of sales tax would not necessarily apply to refunds on concrete pools. So the agreement which was made to pay interest on top of the theoretical refunds supports the removal of the issue from statutory tax regulations.

SPASA members and their accountants had no reason to imagine that the Taxation Office would renege on the agreement, nor to suppose that the Government might come down with legislation which, effectively, makes retrospective the dissolution of the agreement. This, in fact, is what has happened. It is almost unprecedented in taxation history. That is why I refer to this legislation before us as being such an important piece of legislation. It will be seen by others as setting a precedent and this Parliament has put its stamp of approval on such legislation.

In a most unprecedented case which bears more similarity to totalitarian government operations than that expected in a Western democracy, we have a move whereby the Tax Office—and the Australian Government—has chosen to dishonour its own agreement and has chosen to thumb its nose at the High Court in the process. The High Court has ruled that the Commissioner must repay to Precision Pools the moneys it paid pursuant to the SPASA agreement, plus interest. The judge determined that the SPASA agreement was a sensible administrative arrangement for the Commissioner and that he had power to make it; that Precision Pools is entitled to be repaid and entitled to interest pursuant to the agreement with SPASA; and that the Commissioner has no plausible basis for not honouring the agreement.

The effect of the legislation will be to create a climate of uncertainty about, and mistrust of, both the Government and the Taxation office. Australian businesses will not know when agreements are likely to be overturned by outright refusal to honour them, and subsequent entrenchment of a turnaround in legislation in an attempt to legitimise these so-called dishonourable proceedings. We now have the very odd situation where the Commissioner, in the defence filed, sought to deny not only that he had an obligation to repay the money, but also that he ever had the authority to enter into the agreement which he entered into. That is appalling. This agreement was entered into in good faith by a section of the community. This good faith is now undermined, not only in the section of the community concerned but right across the board, throughout the corporate and private spheres of Australian commerce.

The uncertainty resultant from the break of faith is because the intention of this Bill before us is to overturn the decision of the High Court, even though the case is not actually mentioned directly in the legislation. This is further borne out by the fact that the Government has agreed to move some good amendments. I commend the amendments that the Government suggested to us, although at the time of the Bill hearing, they were not all presented. They are certainly a move in the right direction.

The effect of the practical problems will be to leave the contributions in the hands of the Tax Office, as in many cases the pool builders will not be able to establish a claim under the terms of the Bill especially in the period which has been allocated. That this effect is anticipated by the Government is evidenced by the revenue impact statement. The revenue impact will be positive but will not be able to be determined. How can this be so if the only intention of the legislation is to secure refunds from the Australian Taxation Office to eligible people? Indeed, the beneficiary under this legislation will be the Government because it will be retaining moneys that it is not entitled to and which the High Court has said it had no legal entitlement to.

Pool owners will still not be able, in many cases, to establish that they have paid the tax. Builders and owners will not be able to establish what percentage of sales tax has been passed on to the customer, because in many cases we have passed the period for which people have to keep the relevant information, namely, the five-year period.

As builders have to establish that they have repaid the tax to their customers before claiming the refund under the legislation, there is no incentive for them to make the claim. During the negotiations which followed the Committee hearings we were at pains—and the Taxation Office was trying to assist—to determine what was the acceptable administrative charge they should get to provide the incentive necessary for them to pass on the claims. Obviously, they would not do it for nothing, and they had to bear all the administrative costs.

Government members in the House of Representatives have insisted that goodwill will provide the incentive. This is not entirely reasonable because the industry is not a social security dispensing organisation. How many people have two in-ground swimming pools? This goodwill factor is unlikely to be present because people are unlikely to ask a builder to build them a second pool. I think the goodwill factor has been overstated in the House of Representatives.

The administrative costs of the process are a decided disincentive. There is no suggestion of any assistance to pay interest on the thousands of dollars that theoretically may have been borrowed by the builders to pay custom

SPEECH.PARA: ers under the original legislation. I submit that in the revised arrangement the Government has changed that, but to date we have still not got a satisfactory method of allocating moneys to the builders to ensure that they will administer those refunds.

PARA.TAB: My time is running out, and there are a lot more issues to be dealt with which my colleague Senator Short and others will take up. The Liberal-National Party coalition believes that the appropriate course of action is that, firstly, for the period from 1986 to 1990, prior to the agreement, the refunds should flow via the builders to the pool owners or the purchasers, because they would be the people who ultimately paid the sales tax under the invoice. Secondly, for the period of the SPASAA agreement legally entered into, binding and upheld by the Federal Court, the contract should be honoured. It is then up to the Government to provide the machinery and the mechanisms to ensure that justice is dispensed in an equitable way under those arrangements.

On a point of principle, the Liberal-National Party coalition's stand is right and will be upheld and acknowledged in a court of law and in subsequent history on the writing of tax legislation. It is the only honourable way to go. What is dishonourable is this Government's retrospective attempt to deny rights under an agreement that has been acknowledged and upheld by both the Federal Court and the High Court. This Government wants to prevent further litigation in the court, and I think this is reprehensible.

The Government in the explanatory memorandum had the temerity to talk about preventing windfalls from blowing into the hands of construction companies—who, incidentally, it did not trust to direct a refund to where it legitimately came from. In the light of these proceedings, it is little wonder that the Tax Office and the Government presume that no-one is going to act honourably according to the law when they are deciding not to do so themselves. I submit that it is the Taxation Office to which the windfall will result, unless the amendments can quickly be seen to be working well, particularly in respect of companies that are no longer trading or where operators have died.

The Government's amendments are an attempt to address this difficulty and are welcome by this side of the chamber. However, it seems unlikely that they will be sufficient at this stage to sort out the problems. Therefore we ask, Mr Parliamentary Secretary: why the rush to conclude this Bill at this time when we are moving very satisfactorily to wind our way out of a very serious situation?

A further problem is that all those operators who shunned or evaded making a payment which the Tax Office demanded will walk away without liability. That is reprehensible. Those who have done the honourable thing have had all the administrative nightmares of facing the Tax Office, a successful legal challenge, and so on. Mention was made of one builder who entered returns with the consent of the Tax Office but did not remit the funds. Now these funds cannot be collected from him. He is a real winner. Once again, the Government has taken on board a problem in respect of amending this legislation, but it remains to be seen whether these amendments will suffice. Naturally, we welcome the attempt.

In contrast to non-payers, for one reason or another, are the builders who pay the so-called tax and then have a court ruling that the money must be paid back. They are threatened by the legislation before us that there will be no practical way in which this situation can take place because money must be paid back to the customer. A satisfactory mechanism for an administrative charge, with or without charge, must be established sufficient to recompense the pool builders for the processes they will be obligated to go through as a result of this decision.

Just to reiterate, and to make absolutely clear where the end point is, if a customer had a pool built on which no sales tax was paid, there will be no refund. However, where the tax was paid, even though the price may have been the same for the reason of absorption of competitiveness, there must be a refund paid to the customer when it was the builder who paid the so-called tax. There will be enormous problems, I submit, and I look forward to the contributions of my colleagues on this side of the chamber. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to support very strongly the comments of my colleague Senate Watson. I must say that the Swimming Pools Tax Refund Amendment Bill sounds like a somewhat esoteric Bill; it does not sound like a Bill of the greatest moment. But when one looks at the principles involved in this Bill and at the facts and actions of the Government that underlie it, I doubt that we have seen a more important piece of legislation on tax matters and principles of taxation come into this Parliament for a long time.

PARA.TAB: I want today to go through the background of this matter and to bring attention to the state we have arrived at today with the introduction of this Bill. This Bill is about retrospectivity; it is about the Government and its Taxation Office breaking trust with the Australian public. It goes right to the heart of credibility in government. It targets people who acted legitimately—and I will come to that later on—and excludes those who acted illegitimately and were tax avoiders. Whichever way we look at this Bill and the background to it, the only conclusion we can reach is that it is a very serious situation. It is a bad Bill in terms of some of its central elements, and at the very least it has to be significantly amended. My colleague Senate Watson has outlined some of the amendments we feel are necessary, and I will come to those later on.

The history of this matter is a very important story to tell. The background really goes back to 1986, when a wholesale sales tax was introduced on in-ground pools constructed on site. Most of those were concrete pools. That decision to impose sales tax on those pools constructed in situ represented a new field of sales tax because for the first time the tax was not imposed on goods, as compared to the tax that had existed for several years on the sale by the manufacturer of a fibreglass pool shell. A concrete pool constructed on site was deemed by the Tax Office to be goods for the purpose of tax, and a complicated method of calculating the tax was set out which included construction materials and labour as well as profit and overheads.

In February 1992 the High Court ruled that this was not a legal tax and, for technical reasons, under the Constitution the provisions imposing the tax were of no effect. That was the ruling of the High Court. For the purposes of convenience, I will continue to refer to the charge as a tax but, technically, as a result of that High Court decision, it is not. Taxing concrete swimming pools is not a bad thing in principle; the coalition is not objecting to that. It is not a bad thing in itself, but this particular sales tax was bad because it was impossible to administer fairly and to enforce. The artificial deeming provisions caused a tremendous amount of confusion and uncertainty as to how to apply the tax. There was a great deal of error in understatement or overstatement of the tax payable and, as time went on, there was a vast amount of deliberate avoidance of tax. The Tax Office proved incapable of developing an effective system to supervise or enforce the tax and it lacked the resources to police the tax and its collection to any worthwhile extent.

The swimming pool industry comprises a very large number of small contractors. There are a few medium sized businesses but, as I understand it, no large or public companies are involved in the construction of concrete pools. Fibreglass manufacture is carried out by a much smaller number of larger companies. Fibreglass and concrete pool suppliers compete in the same market for in-ground pools.

The tax was set at 20 per cent on the manufactured cost of the fibreglass shell as against 20 per cent of the construction value of the in-ground concrete pool. So effectively this meant that, for a pool costing the same retail price to the customer, nearly twice as much tax was paid on a concrete pool as was paid on the fibreglass shell.

The years immediately following the introduction of this wholesale sales tax extension in 1986—that is, 1987, 1988 and 1989—were relatively prosperous years for the pool industry. The economy was showing good growth and a lot of money was available for consumer spending. This enabled the industry to maintain sales figures at reasonably good levels, despite the extra cost of the tax.

But, gradually, dissatisfaction with the tax, the avoidance issues and the whole mess to which I have earlier referred became widespread throughout the reputable section of the industry. These builders, including most of the larger specialist contractors who were acting ethically by making an honest attempt to calculate tax supposedly payable and remitting it by monthly returns to the Taxation Office, became concerned and frustrated at non-payment by a large number of other mainly smaller and non-specialist pool contractors installing in-ground concrete pools and the competitive disadvantage imposed by the tax as against fibreglass pools.

The Taxation Office received a large number of complaints about the system and the avoidance involved. Information was supplied to the Taxation Office where it could be obtained, but almost always no tangible result was forthcoming as a result of those complaints.

One main avenue of avoidance was the artificial use of the exemption provided in the Act for an `owner builder'. Prior to 1986, figures supplied with regard to local government approvals of swimming pools showed that owner builders represented less than 2 per cent of total approved pools. The definition of an owner builder in the Act was very tight, so much so that no ordinary home owner could qualify.

Nevertheless, by 1990, the percentage of approved pools by so-called owner builders in New South Wales had risen from that less than 2 per cent figure prior to 1986 to over 30 per cent of all pools approved by councils throughout New South Wales. It was well known throughout the industry that many builders were not paying tax on the basis that their customers adopted a fictional owner builder status.

By 1990, therefore, avoidance of tax by this one method out of many accounted for about one third of all pools built. Other methods were also widespread. Although no accurate figures can be obtained, it is commonly believed throughout the industry that tax was not being paid on well over half the concrete in-ground pools built in Australia.

In those circumstances it is not surprising that the ethical tax paying builders sought relief. Most of them are members of the Swimming Pool and Spa Association of Australia—SPASAA. On behalf of these ethical tax-paying builders, SPASAA engaged professional advisers, being sales tax specialists with one of the large accounting firms. They made representations on behalf of SPASAA members to both the Taxation Office and Treasury officials for the removal or easing of the tax burden—or at least for equity and fairness to be introduced into the arrangement—but without success. Thus began the search for other answers to the problem, which resulted in the legal challenge to the constitutional validity of the tax law that was commenced by High Court proceedings in August 1990.

In February 1992, the High Court delivered judgment on those proceedings. The High Court agreed with the SPASAA members' contention that the so-called tax on in-ground concrete pools constructed on site had never legally come into effect. When the proceedings were commenced, SPASAA members, recognising that they had a genuine ground for challenging the tax, stopped making monthly payments to the Taxation Office—that is, in August 1990—or they made such payments under protest on the grounds that the tax law was not constitutionally valid.

After discussion with Taxation Office officials, SPASAA set up a trust fund into which members' payments were made rather than to the Tax Office itself. SPASAA undertook to hold the moneys in trust pending the outcome of the case. If the law was held to be valid, SPASAA agreed to forward the moneys on to the Taxation Office together with any interest accrued in the meantime.

That arrangement stood for approximately three months. In November 1990—and this is still 15 months before the High Court's decision of February 1992—the Taxation Office advised that it could not agree to the trust arrangement continuing. Instead, the Tax Office required payments to be made by way of monthly returns, despite the legal challenge that was then in train. SPASAA members were unwilling to do this, but eventually an agreement was made between SPASAA's accountants and the Taxation Office in an exchange of letters in November 1990. That agreement stated plainly that the members would resume making payments to the Taxation Office of all moneys under dispute, including the moneys collected in the SPASAA trust account since 1990, on the basis that, if the constitutional challenge was upheld, the Taxation Office would refund all moneys so paid under protest, together with interest at the rate applicable to overpaid tax.

Without the promises made in that letter from the Taxation Commissioner's office, no further moneys, as the Commissioner well knew, would have been paid by SPASAA members. In light of the ultimate court decision, no further moneys could have been collected from them.

For many years in the sales tax law there has been a standard provision that wholesalers who pay tax can get a refund only if they satisfy the Commissioner that they have not passed the tax on to their customers or that, if they have passed it on, they have refunded it. No question of interest arises under this provision.

The agreement between the Commissioner and the advisers to SPASAA made by the exchange of letters in November 1990 made no reference to this provision or to any requirement that refunds to be made would go to any party other than the taxpayers—that is, the pool builders. It was known to the Commissioner that the SPASAA members contended that the money was not sales tax because of the invalid law—or what they considered at that time, and were challenging, to be invalid law, which ultimately proved to be the case—and any restrictions on refunds of sales tax would not apply as far as they were concerned. The agreement to pay interest on top of moneys refunded also takes it outside the statutory limitations on the refund of overpaid sales tax.

Before making his reply to the SPASAA proposal, the Commissioner was asked to satisfy himself that he had authority to make the agreement. His letter in reply acknowledged that. When the judgment of the High Court was given in their favour in February 1992, the SPASAA members had no reason at all to doubt that the Commissioner would honour the agreement by refunding all moneys paid under protest since August 1990, plus interest, while leaving open the SPASAA members' right to claim a refund of earlier moneys paid for the supposed tax since it was introduced in 1986.

However, the Commissioner did not respond to their request for repayment and they were forced to continue with the legal proceedings which, until very recently, were on foot in the Federal Court. I will come to that in a moment. In those proceedings, the SPASAA members asked the court for orders declaring that they were entitled to a refund of all moneys paid for the illegal tax, plus a refund of the moneys due under the special agreement, with interest.

The Commissioner filed a defence to these proceedings in which he denied that he was liable to repay the money to the taxpayer builders under the agreement, and even that he had authority to enter into the agreement. Another SPASAA member commenced a separate action on the agreement in the Federal Court in Queensland. The Commissioner has stated that he has no intention of honouring the agreement according to its terms. He submitted to the Federal Court in Brisbane that he was empowered to refund moneys only as though they were overpaid sales tax under the statutory limitations; that is, the builders would receive only moneys that they had refunded to customers.

Before the Federal Court decision on the case which had been put in train in Queensland could be handed down, the Government introduced the Bill which is now the subject of this debate. This Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on Budget night, 18 August. The Bill declares that the Commonwealth is not liable to pay moneys promised under any agreement and that refunds of tax will be made only under the statutory restrictions that I have already mentioned. If this Bill in its present form becomes law, each builder will have to convince the Commissioner upon declaration under oath, with severe penalties for misstatement, either that no part of the so-called sales tax was passed on to the customer or that any such amount passed on has been refunded.

By bringing in this Bill, it is clear that the Australian Taxation Office believed it could not win the Queensland court case. It, instead, has resorted to legislation to defeat the rights which the pool builders otherwise have at law. That is retrospective legislation of a kind typical of a totalitarian state, not a democratic country such as Australia that prides itself on fairness and normal parliamentary democracy.

Our democratic rule of law cannot operate if a government feels free to legislate to take away existing legal rights of citizens without compensation. That is the reason why this Bill we are debating today is of such great significance, not just to the principles of taxation law but to the whole basis of the functioning of a free and democratic society.

The Government's fears about the outcome of the case in the Federal Court in Queensland were well-founded. The decision of the Federal Court was handed down last Thursday. My colleague Senator Watson referred to the decision in his comments but, in a nutshell, the Court ruled with the pool builders against the Commissioner of Taxation. It is a very strong judgment on the part of the Federal Court. What I am about to quote may have already been quoted by Senator Watson. If so, it bears repeating. In that judgment, the judge making the order, Mr Justice Spender, said, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Commissioner were an ordinary citizen it would, in my view, be unconscionable for him now to decline to do which he promised to do in 1990.

Mr Justice Spender went on to quote questions of unconscionableness, estoppel, breach of warranty of authority and the principles lying behind his judgment. They are very strong words indeed from the Federal Court of Australia about the Taxation Office, the upholder of our whole taxation system in Australia. Let me repeat. The judge said:
If the Commissioner were an ordinary citizen—
subject to the same processes of the law as anyone else, as the Commissioner must be in a society such as ours—
it would, in my view, be unconscionable for him now to decline to do which he promised to do in 1990.

That is precisely what the Taxation Office has been doing. That is why this whole matter went to court. Through this Bill, the Government is attempting to undermine all those principles to which the Federal Court has drawn attention—conscionableness, integrity and trust—and to legislate its way out of the situation.

PARA.TAB: As well as the principles involved, the practical problems in the situation are enormous. Concrete in-ground swimming pools are sold under lump sum contracts. The vast majority of these do not show any amount for sales tax being included in the price. Nevertheless, sales tax had to be counted as a cost by those ethical builders who were paying tax in the same way as for any other cost of manufacture. The problem particularly in the last three or four years—although it is inherent anyway—has been that substantial discounts then had to be given on normal retail prices to meet the competition coming unfairly from the large number of builders not paying tax.

The pool industry has always been fiercely competitive. Customers commonly obtain three or four quotes from prospective builders. A situation frequently faced by the ethical sales tax paying builder was to present a quote to a customer at a retail price which included allowance for tax, but then to be met by a substantially lower quote from a non-taxpaying builder. The ethical builder was then in turn forced either to meet this quote or lose the job.

In that way, retail prices, and accordingly builders' margins, have fallen steadily over recent years. To some extent, of course, that may well be due to recessionary trends and the problems in the economy. We have the deepest recession for 60 years as a result of Prime Minister Keating having pulled the levers of economic policy in the most disastrous way for the past nine years. But, principally, the builders believe that it is due to tax avoidance and the necessary reductions that have been taken to meet that situation.

In such a situation, how can anyone determine how much sales tax has been passed on to a customer? I am advised that the average price to concrete an in-ground pool would carry approximately $1,200 to $1,500 in sales tax. It is not uncommon for builders to be forced into giving discounts on retail price of $2,000 to $3,000 to meet the unfair competition. A business must preserve its margins at a sufficient level to remain profitable and therefore to continue in existence. It is not commercially realistic to argue that a sizeable discount either equal to or greater than the sales tax must be regarded as coming off the builder's profit margin, rather than relating to not passing on the tax.

However, the Minister, in his second reading speech on introducing this Bill to Parliament, indicated that the Government believes it is acting in the interests of consumers in this matter by ensuring that any refunds ultimately reach them, thereby avoiding an undesirable windfall on the part of the pool builders.

What I have been saying today has attempted to demonstrate how wrong is that analysis of the situation. In particular, it ignores several key points. It ignores the fact that, where a customer has a pool built on which no sales was paid in the first place, then no refund can be given. It ignores the fact that many builders who have not paid tax will now walk away scot-free with no liability at all. It ignores the fact that no incentive is given to any builder to apply for a refund because the total value of it goes to the customer. The Bill denies the benefit of an agreement made in good faith by taxpayers with the Commissioner under which they acted to their detriment in paying further moneys which the Commissioner could never otherwise have received.Surely that must be repugnant on any principle of government. No taxpayer could ever deal with the Commissioner or accept his assurance on any matter if later it could be negated by legislation if the tax authorities happened to find that inconvenient to their own agenda.

Where does all this leave the pool customer? He has no identifiable right under the pool contract to any refund from the builder and it would be very difficult to establish what amount, if any, had been passed on by way of sales tax in most cases. He has no direct right of a refund from the Taxation Office. There is no ongoing goodwill between the builder and the customer in the normal case, as it is not a business in which there are too many repeat orders. Some builders may feel obliged towards customers on a personal basis, but most will have no reason to incur cost and spend time without reward solely for the benefit of an ex-customer.

So when this issue is fully analysed, when the background to it is taken into account and when the Bill itself is looked at carefully, it can be seen that not only is the Bill an outrageous denial of the existing legal rights of a group of taxpayers but it is more than likely, by design or otherwise, to result in a windfall for the Taxation Office by enabling it to retain moneys which have never been legally taxed. That is odious both in principle and in practice.

So for these reasons the coalition has very grave problems with this Bill as drafted. We believe that some of those problems can be met, at least in part, by amendments to the Bill which Senator Watson has foreshadowed. Nevertheless, even with those amendments it will be very difficult for this Bill to be doctored in a way that would escape the criticisms of the nature that Senator Watson, Senator Kemp and Senator Campbell have outlined in the minority report on this matter produced by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration and tabled here today. Let me quote a couple of paragraphs of that report. The opening paragraph says:
Clearly, those who ultimately paid the sales tax on in-ground swimming pools are entitled to a refund. This Bill fails to achieve that objective.

SPEECH.PARA: The minority report quite rightly says:

The Government's handling of this legislation has been deplorable and the Government is to be condemned over its whole handling of it and its failure to amend the Bill itself to facilitate a more effective system of refunds.
It makes the following vitally important point:

The attitude of the Government in deliberately moving to legislate out of existence a formal agreement voluntarily entered into by parties in good faith will set a dangerous precedent that can only undermine public confidence in future agreements between taxpayers and the Australian Taxation Office. Indeed, it could be said that to this extent the legislation abrogates the rule of law.

They are very strong words indeed from senators who are not normally moved to talk in such harsh terms, but they are very important words. They are very well founded, given the Government's handling of this Bill. We have a problem here of retrospectivity, of the whole question of trust between government and the community in one of the most important areas of government administration, namely, tax administration. That always goes to the credibility of government.

PARA.TAB: We are passing this Bill today, I understand, because the Government happens to want to get the Bill through. The Democrats have acceded to this, so there is no way we can stop that. There is no great urgency in this Bill other than that the Government wishes to try to avoid further court proceedings that will be damaging to it. That is not a sufficient and valid reason for the way this Bill is being rushed. I hope that we will be able to give it further consideration. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —As one would conclude from what we have heard so far, this is one of the most difficult taxation problems to come before the Senate in many years, certainly in the two years that I have been here. It is unlike any that we have looked at because we are not debating whether to put a tax on some item or on an activity; we are trying to deal with an extraordinary situation in an equitable way. That is the key to this: we are trying to find an equitable solution.

PARA.TAB: The history of this Bill really needs to be told—how we got to this mess. In 1983 the Parliament imposed a 10 per cent tax on manufactured fibreglass swimming pools. The industry complained that this tax was giving a competitive advantage to the more luxurious concrete in-ground pools, which were still untaxed. In 1986 the Government proposed to increase the tax to 20 per cent for manufactured pools and at the same time to impose an equivalent tax on the shell of concrete pools which are manufactured on site. This tax extension was achieved by deeming that the concrete shell was a manufactured good. The tax was paid, however reluctantly, by the builders and passed on to the owners.

However, in 1990 a legal opinion was obtained by some builders which questioned the constitutional validity of the tax on concrete shells. On the basis of this, the pool builders went to the Tax Office and said, `We do not have to pay this tax because it is not legally payable, and we are not going to pay this tax unless you agree in writing that the money will be refunded, plus interest, if our interpretation is correct'. As I understand it, the Tax Office agreed to this, and the legal challenge to the legislation, the Mutual Pools case, proceeded.

In February of this year, the High Court ruled in favour of Mutual Pools' assertion that the tax was unconstitutional. It is important to recognise that it is not beyond the power of the Commonwealth to tax these items. The Court ruled that the method which the Parliament unanimously approved of—and that includes the Opposition—was contrary to section 55 of the Constitution. We all said that it was a principle we wanted to adopt. We thought it was okay to tax these swimming pools; we did it the wrong way. So if we were to do nothing, subject to some uncertain legal technicalities, the pool builders would be entitled to a refund from the Commonwealth of all the moneys wrongly paid as sales tax from 1986, plus interest. The exact figure can only be guessed at, but estimates settle on a figure of at least $40m. Many people are saying that this would deliver a massive windfall gain to the builders at the expense of the pool purchasers who had paid the tax. That is unacceptable, I think. So we need a refunds regime which will ensure that, as far as possible, the person who actually bore the tax obtains the refund.

This legislation does provide such a regime, although we think it is still in need of further modification because it does not stop a pool builder obtaining a refund but it does impose a condition on that refund. The condition is that the builder must make a legal declaration to the effect that he or she has, in fact, borne the tax. This has to be substantiated and, if records have been kept, it should be possible to do that. In such cases the pool builder will be entitled to a refund. In all other cases the refund will go to the pool owner, or be split in some manner between the builder and the owner-purchaser.

I do not think any of us would dispute that, because of the way builders have determined the total price of the pool, there will be some difficulties in some cases in determining who bore the actual liability and, therefore, who should get the refund. But I do not think that that makes the principle of seeking to make the refund to the actual person who bore the tax any less correct. In the committee stage I will move an amendment which seeks to overcome what I think is still a flaw in the legislation. Put simply, the structure of the legislation as it stands at the moment does not grant any rights to the pool purchasers.

The coalition has spoken against the Bill on the basis of its overriding of the agreement between the pool builders and the Taxation Office. The Democrats regard this, too, as a very serious matter. We have agonised over our position. There is no doubt that it is a very serious matter for the Parliament to extinguish people's rights by legislation. We have people who are pool builders and people who are pool purchasers. By virtue of the way wholesale sales tax is imposed, the pool purchasers cannot be represented in the agreement between the pool builders and the Tax Commissioner.

The structure of this legislation will ensure that if pool builders did, in fact, bear the tax then they are entitled to a refund under this Bill. That point needs to be made very clearly—they are still entitled to a refund. So we think that is a just proposal, although we are aware of the precedent we are setting.

If we were to exempt the agreement moneys, which the Opposition proposed to do in the House of Representatives—estimated at about $9m—this would have the effect of denying the rightful refund to all of those owners who bore all or part of the tax. The Democrats think that this is a greater evil than overriding what we regard as a very bad contract.

As I have said, the Democrats do not do this lightly; we think this is an extraordinary circumstance. In recognition of the administrative effort and the cost of processing these matters we agree that the pool builders should be paid an administrative fee. As I understand it, this will be a flat rate. It will give pool builders an incentive to cooperate in assisting their customers to obtain a refund.

In closing, I wish to emphasise that, in reaching our position, we have had to deal with competing principles. The sanctity of contracts and the confidence of the professional community in its dealings with the Taxation Office is a major principle, but there is also the general principle of equity. The persons who paid the tax should be the ones who are entitled to the refunds. Parliament is sovereign and in this case I believe that we should exercise our sovereignty to ensure that a fair outcome is legislated.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation, the Swimming Pools Tax Refund Bill 1992, relates to a longstanding dispute between swimming pool builders and the Australian Taxation Office. The legislation, as it has been put forward in this Parliament, demonstrates both the incompetence of this Government and its predilection to ride roughshod over the rights of individuals. For that reason alone the legislation is unacceptable to the Opposition, but it is also unacceptable because of its retrospective effect.

PARA.TAB: To summarise this issue, pending a decision on a High Court challenge by the Swimming Pool and Spa Association on the constitutionality of sales tax on swimming pools constructed in situ, the Swimming Pool and Spa Association entered into an agreement with the Australian Taxation Office to continue to pay the 20 per cent sales tax which was being levied on these pools, on the basis that if the challenge was successful the sales tax would be refunded to the pool builders.

Subsequent to the High Court deciding in February this year in favour of the Swimming Pool and Spa Association, the Taxation Office reneged on that agreement and proceedings by the Swimming Pool and Spa Association to enforce the agreement were then undertaken in the Federal Court. Of course, only recently we heard the result of that particular challenge, and I will refer to that in a few moments. There have also been test cases initiated by some Swimming Pool and Spa Association members to recover moneys paid to the Taxation Office by way of sales tax on pools prior to the agreement being entered into.

It is estimated that in excess of 20,000 swimming pools have been constructed since the introduction of this tax in 1986. The Association claims its members are entitled to a refund of some $8m, plus $2m interest paid under the agreement with the Australian Taxation Office, which covered the period from mid-1990 until February 1992. The Association also claims that its members paid $20m to the Taxation Office in the period from 1986 until mid-1990—that is, the period before the agreement was entered into with the Commissioner—and, on top of that, millions of dollars were collected from non-Association members by way of sales tax.

This legislation has two purposes: firstly, to nullify that agreement that was reached, quite legitimately, between the Swimming Pool and Spa Association and the Australian Taxation Office; and, secondly, to provide an appropriate refund to the pool owner where the owner has paid all or part of the sales tax, and for the refund to go to the builder in some other cases. But subject to the amendments that have been foreshadowed by the Government today, only the pool builder, in the initial legislation, could initiate that refund claim. That was certainly a very significant shortcoming in the legislation.

On the basis of legal advice that the Association took in relation to its High Court challenge, it believed that that challenge would be successful and, of course, that proved to be the case. Therefore, its members would have been due to receive a refund of moneys paid to the Taxation Office—the sales tax which was not passed on to customers during the agreement period.As we would be well aware, agreements between the Taxation Office and taxpayers to settle outstanding tax issues are a regular and well accepted part of our taxation system.

The significant objection which the Opposition has to this legislation is that, as it nullifies the agreement between the Taxation Office and the Association, this would be the first time that the Australian Taxation Office has reneged on such an agreement. Never again will taxpayers have confidence in being able to reach an agreement with the Taxation Office if this legislation is passed, because they could never again have any confidence that at some future date the Taxation Office would not unilaterally, with the support of the Government by way of legislation, revoke such an agreement. That, of course, is a very serious shortcoming in tax administration and a major objection to this particular legislation.

Let me go to the background of the legislation. In 1986 this Government enacted legislation seeking to impose sales tax on in-ground concrete swimming pools. At that time, the Swimming Pool and Spa Association made representations, not only to the Taxation Office but also to Treasury and the Government itself, that in practice this legislation would be unworkable and, in particular, that the effects of the legislation could easily be evaded by unscrupulous pool builders exploiting the exemption available for owner-builders. As the record shows, these concerns proved to be absolutely correct.In 1991, after the introduction of this tax, the number of `owner-builders', so-called, in Australia increased from about 10 per cent to about 40 per cent of all swimming pool constructions.

In 1990 the Association received legal advice that the legislation was constitutionally invalid. The Swimming Pool and Spa Association was advised that its members need no longer pay this sales tax on in-ground concrete pools. As a consequence, the Association mounted a constitutional challenge in the High Court, arguing that the legislation was invalid. As a result of that initiative, in November 1990 the Commissioner made an agreement with the Association and its members to refund to them all moneys paid as and for sales tax from that time if the legislation was found to be invalid by the High Court.

In April 1991 the Association made a formal submission to the Treasury and the Taxation Office. This submission explained in detail why the legislation was not working and put forward a very compelling case for the repeal of the provisions introduced in 1986.

As I have already indicated, in February 1992 the High Court held that the legislation was constitutionally invalid. But despite that finding by the High Court, the Tax Office has not honoured its agreement with the Association. This is despite having taken legal advice that it could act upon the agreement's principles. As a result of that, Association members initiated actions in the Federal Court of Australia to recover the moneys which are owed to them by the Tax Office.

On 10 September—only last week—Mr Justice Spender of the Federal Court determined that the Taxation Commissioner has a legal obligation to honour the agreement which had previously been entered into. In his judgment he described the agreement as `a sensible arrangement' and stated that if the Commissioner were an ordinary citizen it would be `unconscionable for him now to decline to do which he promised to do in 1990'. Yet that is exactly what the Government is seeking to do on behalf of the Taxation Office through this legislation which was introduced on Budget night. If passed by this Senate, this legislation will retrospectively remove the rights that Swimming Pool and Spa Association members have under their agreement with the Commissioner which has now been determined as valid by the Federal Court.

Agreement was reached with the Commissioner to ensure that his interests would be safeguarded if the High Court decided in his favour. The Taxation Office would, therefore, receive full payment of the tax due. The Association was concerned that if its members ceased to pay sales tax from 1990 when the agreement was reached and the matter was determined in the Commissioner's favour some members may be unable to fund the payments that would then be due. There was also concern about the question of penalties. That is why the agreement was reached between the two parties.

At that stage the Association and the Commissioner agreed that all moneys payable as and for sales tax by Association members would from then on be paid into a joint Association and Australian Taxation Office trust account, pending the High Court decision. The Commissioner subsequently declined to become a signatory to that account and withdrew his support for that arrangement.

Subsequently another arrangement was reached between the Association and the Taxation Office whereby the pool builders would continue to lodge sales tax returns and pay sales tax to the Tax Office. Under that agreement, if the constitutional challenge was successful, the amounts paid under the agreement would be refunded to the pool builders unconditionally, together with interest, and letters were exchanged confirming that agreement.

Despite the decision of the High Court with regard to the constitutionality of this sales tax and despite the decision of the Federal Court with regard to the validity of the agreement, the Taxation Office refuses to make the refund which is due to pool owners. Instead, the Government has introduced the legislation which is now before us to overturn retrospectively that agreement and in fact extinguish the existing rights of pool builders. This Bill will destroy a very sensible agreement that was entered into in good faith by Association members. It cannot be said in defence of the legislation that it is at all concerned with the protection of consumer rights.

The concern of the Government is that there may be windfall gains achieved by pool builders if this legislation is not passed. But what the legislation ignores is the fact that many pool builders did not pay this sales tax. As I have already mentioned, a number of them became so-called `owner-builders' and therefore avoided the tax. Others took the risk that the High Court challenge by the pool builders would succeed. Therefore they took, if you like, a gamble and did not pay the tax. Obviously, they can in no way obtain a refund, which would have to be passed on to the pool owners. So this legislation completely ignores this significant group.

Unscrupulous builders who either posed as owner-builders or simply evaded the tax at that time placed unfair competitive pressures on those builders who sought to comply with the law and paid money to the Taxation Office as it was due with regard to sales tax. The consequence of that was that legitimate pool builders had to reduce their prices in order to compete with those builders who were not paying the sales tax. So, in effect, many pool purchasers did not pay that sales tax. Even though the scrupulous pool builders passed on sales tax to the Taxation Office, this was not charged back to the purchaser of the pool—the people for whom they were building the pool—simply because of the competitive pressures that were initiated by those unscrupulous builders who were not paying the tax.

Therefore, it is utter nonsense to talk of windfall gains being obtained by builders in these circumstances. As a consequence, it is equally a nonsense to claim that this legislation seeks to retrieve from certain pool builders so-called windfall gains. The clear moral requirement on the Tax Office and this Government is for the original agreement with the Tax Office to be honoured, for those refunds to be made available to the pool builders and for them in turn to pass on to the pool owners such amounts of sales tax as have legitimately been charged back to those pool owners.

There will be very serious and detrimental consequences if this legislation is passed. I have already indicated and argued in the body of this debate that it will first destroy a fair and sensible agreement reached between the Swimming Pool and Spa Association and the Taxation Office. Secondly, perhaps even more significantly, it would establish a very dangerous precedent with regard to using retrospective legislation to extinguish existing rights. Thirdly, it would have enormous implications for the way in which taxpayers will deal with the Taxation Office in future.

As I said at the outset of my remarks, if this legislation is passed, no-one ever again will be able to deal with the Taxation Office with any confidence in terms of entering into an agreement, negotiating a settlement or participating in a tax amnesty with the Taxation Commissioner. Instead, many taxpayers will take unilateral unauthorised action which, for many reasons, will not be in the interests of other taxpayers, the Taxation Office or the Australian community in general.

This legislation fails on many counts, and not just in relation to the direct interests of pool builders and pool owners. The shortcomings of this legislation have also been highlighted by members of the accounting profession in the evidence they gave on Monday to the inquiry into this Bill by the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, brief as it was. They raised a number of points of concern about the legislation. A major point was the one I have just made with regard to compromising the future administration of taxation law because of the lack of confidence this legislation engenders in any future agreements that might be made between taxpayers and the Taxation Office.

Other concerns include the attempt by the legislation to circumvent recovery proceedings that have been under way for some time, which have now been determined in favour of the taxpayers; the retrospectivity of the legislation, which I have already referred to; and the practical effect of this legislation, which is to validate what has already been determined by the High Court as a constitutionally invalid tax. One of the problems with the legislation is that there is no incentive for the pool builder to retrieve the tax that has been paid, even where it is due to him, because of costs that would be associated with obtaining that refund and the lack of any offsetting benefit to the pool builder for such costs imposed.

The accountancy profession has also raised the difficulty about the notion of passing on this benefit from the Taxation Office to the pool builder to the pool owner. As I have already mentioned, a number of pool builders during this period did not charge out their tax to their customers, because of the competitive pressures that were imposed upon them by unscrupulous pool builders who were not paying the tax. As the accountancy profession says, the issue of passing on becomes a lot more difficult in circumstances where a tax is simply part of the overhead structure of a business operation and is not specifically charged to a customer. That is the case in many instances with this particular sales tax. It was absorbed by the pool builder; it was not passed on to the customer or pool owner. So to require that a refund can be obtained only in circumstances where it is passed on to all pool owners is simply unsatisfactory tax administration.

Another issue the accountancy profession raised was the size of the administrative task in ensuring that such refunds are passed on to the customer, the ultimate pool owner. It is not only the pool builders who have extreme concerns about this legislation, it is also the accountancy profession, because of the inadequacies it sees in it.

In summary, the attitude of the Government in deliberately moving to legislate out of existence a formal agreement voluntarily entered into by parties in good faith will set a dangerous precedent that can only undermine confidence in future agreements between taxpayers and the Australian Taxation Office and the Commissioner. In practice it abrogates the rule of law. The legislation is all the more reprehensible for the way in which the Government has introduced it. It overturns a decision already reached not only by the High Court but also by the Federal Court of Australia, firstly with regard to the constitutionality of the tax, and secondly with regard to attempts by pool builders to enforce their agreements with the Taxation Office, both of which found in favour of the pool builders.

The statement to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration by Senator McMullan as Parliamentary Secretary that `the court has interpreted the agreement in an unacceptable way, so we are legislating to overturn it', clearly demonstrates this Government's intention to trample over the rights of citizens rather than to use normal due legal process to determine those rights. Above all, that highlights the deplorable way in which the Government has acted on this issue. It is totally unsatisfactory. The Opposition will not have a bar of it, and that is why we are seeking to amend the legislation. Those amendments warrant the support of this Senate, and I urge Senator Button, as the responsible Minister at the table, to accept the amendments. If those amendments are not accepted, this legislation should be thrown out lock, stock and barrel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a disgrace this piece of legislation is. As my colleague Senator Chapman has outlined the background to this reneging on an agreement, I will put in only one sentence and then go on to deal with the ramifications.

PARA.TAB: Pending a decision on its High Court challenge to the constitutionality of sales tax on pools constructed in situ, the SPASA entered into an agreement with the Australian Taxation Office to continue to pay the 20 per cent sales tax on the basis that, if the challenge were successful, the sales tax would be refunded to its members, that is, the pool builders. Twice Mr Boucher, in the recent hearings of the Public Accounts Committee into the Australian Tax Office, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our integrity is a cherished virtue.
On the second occasion he said:
In my opening statement, I was not resorting to hyperbole when I said that our integrity is a cherished virtue.
Pardon my cynicism for believing that that statement has all the veracity of Brutus when he spoke at the burial of Julius Caesar and said that he wept for him because he loved him.

PARA.TAB: The Commissioner of Taxation holds himself above the rest of the community and exercises powers, as I have said before, that make grown men cringe. Yet here we have the Tax Office reneging on and repudiating a legitimate agreement entered into. Honourable senators should ask themselves: what was the motive? Why did the Tax Office renege on an agreement it had entered into? Why, when there was an attempted enforcement of that agreement, did the legislation come suddenly before this Parliament? A second statement Mr Boucher has made is that he exercises the tax office without political influence. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: I find any proposition that our internal decision making is in any way politically slanted to be an unwarranted slur. It is offensive to me personally, and it is offensive to those of my officers. . .

I am afraid that Mr Boucher stands convicted. Here is the Government legislating to enforce the rejection of a legitimate contract by which he was found by a court of law to be bound. Why did Mr Boucher reject the agreement? That is a legitimate question to ask. One could speculate that the answer is that the government of the day said, `If you do, we will give you the legislation to back it up'. Operates with no political bias? I think not.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition will be moving amendments in the committee stage of this Bill. Senator Short and Senator Chapman have very strongly outlined the inequities and injustices that have long been perpetrated by the initial rejection of the agreement, compounded by the introduction of this legislation. Ordinary Australians are once again put at a disadvantage, first by the Tax Office and secondly by the Government; or rather, was it always the other way round? The Tax Office, said Mr Boucher, is not politically slanted, and yet the government of the day is bringing in legislation to back up a most horrendous act of dishonouring a contract.

At the time this contract was entered into, there was very good and adequate legal advice that the action of claiming the tax in the first place was unconstitutional. The Tax Office was aware of and privy to that. One asks oneself: what was the quality of its legal advice? One asks oneself: what was the basis for the implementation of the tax in the first place? Which particular branch of the Tax Office decided that it could impose that tax? There are many questions that need to be answered about, firstly, the way in which it was imposed; secondly, the agreement negotiated; and thirdly, why it was rejected. What discussions took place and what assurances were given to the Tax Office prior to its reneging on the agreement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to the statement that Treasurer Dawkins made in Melbourne, the day after the Budget was announced only four weeks ago, in respect of future tax increases:

QUESTION.PARA: Look, we're not considering any of those measures now . . . These are issues that might be considered 3 or 4 years from now . . .—
I refer also to his statement in the Parliament on the same day:
These are proposals which may only be resorted to if and when we make a judgment four years from now.

I ask: what has occurred in the four short weeks since then to force the Government to change its mind and introduce new tax legislation embracing these increases? Is there any reason other than that the coalition has exposed the Government's obvious intention to conspire to conceal the truth from Australian taxpayers?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short will recall this, I hope. The Government in the Budget Papers openly said that, in order to meet its deficit target in the mid-1990s, it may at the time consider the implementation of tax measures particularly relating to strengthening compliance with the tax system. When that was said in the Budget, those opposite started jumping around the place talking about secret taxes. After we had openly said that in the Budget, those opposite started all this spooky stuff about secret taxes.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the announcement made today by Mr Dawkins, those changes will be implemented as from 1994; the Government's personal income tax revised scales will be introduced from 1 January 1994. Not only do those tax changes induce greater fairness into the personal taxation system but, as distinct from the proposals of those opposite, they do not provide a situation where top income earners get something like 10 times the amount of taxation benefit out of the Fightback package that lower income earners—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that has something to do with thresholds. In terms of middle income earners, that is the sort of provision that is in the Opposition's proposals, which are all about incentivation for the rich: the rich need more money in order to work harder; the poor need less.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I agree with Senator Button's comment: it was said at Budget time that the Government may at the time—that is, in the mid-1990s—consider future tax increases. That is what the Treasurer said on the day after the Budget, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: These are proposals which may only be resorted to if and when we make a judgment four years from now.
I ask again: what has occurred in the four short weeks since then to force the Government to change its mind and to introduce those tax increase legislation proposals today?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing has happened in terms of the deficit or the estimates for the deficit or anything relating to fiscal policy. What those opposite did was to start a whole spooky debate about the issue. We just wanted to clean that up and put it beyond doubt. Apart from the taxes announced by Mr Dawkins this morning, which will be debated shortly in the House of Representatives—
—We have flushed you out.
—Order! Senator Short, you have asked the supplementary question.

—Apart from that, none of the other taxes—the withholding tax or the prescribed payments tax—which were referred to as possibilities in the Budget will be implemented by this Government. Contrast that with the situation of the Opposition. Even today, we had the chief executive of the National Farmers Federation on the radio saying, `Look, there's a gap; there's a hole in the Fightback package'. We asked those opposite yesterday—
—You have been caught out.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is clearly being asked whether the Minister misled the Parliament or whether the Government has changed its mind. It has nothing to do with Fightback or the National Farmers Federation. I invite you to direct him to answer the question.
—Order! It is not possible for the Chair to anticipate what the Minister is going to say.
—We can.

—Yes, those opposite can. I have already answered that part of the question. I told Senator Short in my answer to the first part of his question that we want to put this issue beyond doubt. I think Senator Short will find that it is he who has been caught out because there is a big gap in his financing proposals, and it is being pointed to increasingly by various sectors of the community.
—Wash your mouth out, John.
—Order! Senator Walters, will you cease interjecting.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister tell the Senate about the current state of relations with the Solomon Islands in the light of press reports this morning that the visit of HMAS Bendigo has been cancelled? Is there any basis for the claim that Australia, along with PNG, is responsible for the deaths of citizens of Solomon Islands?

—As I said in the Senate yesterday, there is no basis for any criticism of Australia that has been made by the Solomon Islands, and we are certainly disappointed that it has been made. In that context, we also regret the apparent decision that has been made to refuse permission for HMAS Bendigo to visit. I should say that we do understand the very real and very acute sense of shock and consternation that is being felt in the Solomon Islands at the moment at the violation of its borders by elements of the Papua New Guinea defence forces. The outrage felt in the Solomon Islands is legitimate. It is a feeling we also share. We just do not feel that any of it ought to be directed at us.

PARA.TAB: We do categorically reject any suggestion or insinuation that Australia is in any way responsible for the deaths of Solomon Islands citizens. It is quite incorrect to claim that because we have a defence cooperation program with Papua New Guinea or because Papua New Guinea sources some of its military equipment from Australia we are in any way responsible for any renegade actions by elements of the PNGDF. Indeed, there has been, in any event, no indication that the reported raid on Kamaleai involved the use of helicopters or, for that matter, any other Australian supplied equipment, to the extent that that is relevant.

The Government does deplore the loss of life in the Solomon Islands. We are very concerned about the stresses and the tensions these developments are imposing on relations between Papua New Guinea and the Solomons, which seem to be reflected in the statement from the Solomon Islands Government National Security Headquarters.

I should make the further point that we are certainly not siding with either party in the current border problems. We hope that solutions arise from early discussions between those directly involved and we encourage such discussions to occur as soon as possible. Papua New Guinea Foreign Minister John Kaputin's proposed visit shortly may provide an opportunity to begin the process of reconciliation. We hope that that consultation with PNG will provide a sound basis for the Solomons to once again recognise Australia's genuine commitment to a constructive bilateral relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it the case that Australia has been asked to send troops to the Solomon Islands to protect the border? What additional assistance, if any, could Australia provide to assist the Solomons in the policing of its border?

—There is no basis for the claims that Australia has been approached to send troops to the Solomon Islands border. That reference first appeared in a press release issued yesterday, 15 September, by the National Security Headquarters in Honiara. As I said yesterday, on a number of occasions the Australian Government has offered to provide appropriate assistance to the Solomon Islands to help manage its borders. Our current assistance is already substantial. Our defence assistance in total amounts to some $4.97m. We hold regular bilateral defence cooperation talks with the Solomons, most recently in May. In January this year, in response to a specific request, we provided five 5.3 metre fast patrol craft, specifically to enhance border control capabilities. That is in addition to the two full-size patrol boats which were previously given. We recently supplied the Solomon Islands police with replacement communications equipment which would be used, among other things, to support border surveillance.

PARA.TAB: In all of that, our offers of appropriate assistance have not extended to providing troops to patrol the border with Papua New Guinea, nor have we received, as I said, any request from the Solomons for such troops. We do consider it important for the two sides to agree on strategies for managing their common border and for such discussion to identify their needs. We would be willing to consider sympathetically providing appropriate assistance to meet these needs once they are identified and defined. While we do not want to impose any concepts of border management on the two countries, we could help with advisory assistance. We could provide the necessary communications equipment to facilitate better communication between the Solomon Islands coordination centre and the appropriate PNG authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a delegation from the Parliament of Malaysia, led by the Hon. Datuk Dr Abdullah Fadzil Che Wan, the Deputy Foreign Minister. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome the delegation to the Senate. I trust that your visit is both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate.
—Who wrote this one for you?

—Has Nick Bogus quite finished? I refer to the Government's proposed tax increases announced today. Will the Minister explain how the Government proposes to raise $2.5 billion in fringe benefits tax changes over the next two years when no provision has been made to compensate income tax exempt government employers, including State and local governments, for the additional tax collected from these organisations? In effect, how much will the Government be cutting grants to the States, including Queensland and Victoria, in order to raise FBT?

—The announcement made by the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, today bears on companies, government instrumentalities and exempt bodies of various kinds. Ultimately the burden, in so far as there is a burden, will be paid by high income earners who are the major recipients of fringe benefits taxes. This proposal by this Government again introduces additional fairness and equity into the taxation system. If we go back over the history of this Government, we did that with the introduction of the fringe benefits tax. The Opposition opposed it. We did that with the introduction of the assets test. The Opposition opposed it. In each case it said it was unfair and unreasonable. Subsequently, it decided that perhaps it was not so unfair after all; it was an appropriate matter in order to have a proper, fair and equitable tax system in this country. Those allegations will presumably be made again.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has to face up to the fact, if it sees itself as a possible alternative government in this country, that the tax system has to be fair and equitable and properly administered. That is the prospect which the Opposition has to face up to. In so far as the calculations made by the Tax Office are concerned, I will obtain further details from the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In relation to the additional information that the Minister is going to get from the Tax Office, because we now have elections in Victoria and Queensland, what are the additional taxes that the States are now going to have to pay as a result of this FBT measure? Could we get a clear answer to that question?
—Under this proposal the FBT will be treated in exactly the same way in the hands of a recipient as payrolls are in the hands of employers. They are deductible.
—Give us the figure.

—I understand Senator Kemp's point. As I said, in so far as the calculations are concerned, I will get further information from the Treasurer. There has been a significant increase in providing remuneration for top income earners by way of fringe benefits rather than by way of salaries. That is something which the tax system has to address and it has to address it with fairness and equity, whether it relates to the private sector or the government sector, as Senator Kemp points out.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp's question is a desperate one, typically trying to get some sneaky advantage out of creating some spooky threats in relation to Queensland and Victoria. I do not think he need worry about it. He should come back next time and ask me about Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I repeat the question because Senator Button has time to answer it: how much additional taxes will Victoria and Queensland have to pay? Could he answer the question?
—I told Senator Kemp that they were Tax Office calculations and I will get him the information.

—Has the Minister for Industrial Relations seen reports of a recent study mission undertaken by the Victorian Director of the Metal Trades Industry Association—that is an employer organisation—Mr Bob Herbert, on collective bargaining in the United States which warns of excessive legal costs if the industrial relations system moves away from a system of awards and industrial tribunals to one based on common law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The biggest most enduring closed shop in Australia and the one that engages in the most restrictive work practices of all is the legal profession. It is the intention of the Opposition—Mr Howard being its spokesman on this matter and he being a lawyer, I might add—to hand over the award system and the arbitration system to the common law and make a gift to the closed shop and the one with the most restrictive work practices of all, the legal profession.

PARA.TAB: I am asked whether I have seen this report of the Metal Trades Industry Association, as Senator Sherry points out, an employer organisation. I have seen the report. It is a report of a study mission being undertaken by its Victorian director, Mr Bob Herbert. There are features of the United States collective bargaining system that are similar in main point to the elements being promoted by the Opposition in terms of reliance on common law. It is not surprising therefore that when Mr Herbert inspected close up how the United States system operates in his report he counselled Australian employers not to have a bar of it. I will quote his finding in his report:

ANSWER.PARA: The inevitable outcome of moving away from a system of making and endorsing awards and agreements by industrial tribunals to one where `common law' agreements apply is to provide—
These are his words—
a field day for litigation, with the cost being borne by the employer.
Mr Herbert sees this as a manoeuvre to increase costs to employers in dealing with industrial matters through the common law. That is what he said. He is from a reputable employer organisation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Minister, your time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think this is a very important issue. The Minister, in his usual informative way, is pointing out the enormous problems of the Opposition's industrial relations policies and their consequences. What would be the effect on the vast majority of Australian workers, 70 per cent of whom earn below average weekly earnings, of adopting a common law approach to industrial relations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I was just saying that the view of the leading metal industry employers organisation in this country, and the one that speaks mostly for the trade exposed area of the economy, is that this would be the worst thing that could happen and that it would impose more costs on them as employers.

PARA.TAB: I am asked what the wider implications are. If it imposes more costs on employers, and costs to an unacceptable level, fancy the imposition on ordinary Australian workers, many of whom, as the questioner pointed out, earn below average weekly earnings. The cost imposition on ordinary individuals in Australia would be astronomical and that is assuming that their grievances can be addressed in the common law list, waiting time for which is quite considerable in any case.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would you know?
