—That is a fact. Senator Alston is a lawyer. I am interjected upon by a lawyer, a member of the most protected closed shop in Australia and one that has the most restrictive work practices. He is saying in defence of his closed shop with its restrictive work practices that we should hand over Australian industrial relations law. There will be several costs—
—You are into lawyers because they did away with the ad ban.

—Here is another lawyer who wants to protect the privilege of the closed shop and the privilege of the restrictive work practices. We are not going to adopt the US system that imposes more costs on employers and more costs on individual workers. It is clear that the United States has a litigious system. It is emerging as the problem in New Zealand where people under the contract system have to resort to the common law which is often beyond their ability. Thus, people are denied justice by lack of access to legal redress.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Have Australian Federal Police investigations during the past 12 months on the Queensland Gold Coast concluded that the Japanese Yakuza's penetration of the Queensland property market could be well above 25 per cent? Have these investigations linked one senior executive of Daikyo with a high-ranking Japanese Yakuza member?
—It was probably the Labor candidate.
—Order! Senator Macdonald, I ask you to withdraw. It was a clear implication on a member of another House. I ask you to withdraw it.
—Mr President, I am talking about the Labor candidate, not the Labor member.
—Order! If you said the Labor candidate, I am not going to ask you to withdraw. I thought you said the Labor member.
—Ha, ha!
—I am not helped by the interjections, particularly the last one when Senator Kemp was not even in his seat.

—I will ignore the defamatory comment made under the protection of parliamentary privilege by Senator Macdonald against a candidate in a forthcoming election in Queensland, linking that person to organised crime activity and with a particular Japanese organised crime group. I challenge him to say that outside the chamber and I bet my bottom dollar he will not.

PARA.TAB: I have no particular information available to me to answer Senator Kernot's question about an alleged AFP investigation revealing what she says in the substance of her question. If, indeed, the AFP has been conducting an investigation, it would be greatly enhanced by the cooperation which has been a feature of the relationship between the Australian Federal Police and the National Police Agency of Japan which has improved markedly over the past 12 months.

This Parliament has passed laws relating to money laundering which provide for very extensive gaol sentences and the imposition of very heavy fines, including for those aspects of international money laundering where proceeds of crime in a country such as Japan may be brought into Australia and invested in real estate or other apparently legitimate businesses.

So I can tell Senator Kernot that we do have the Federal Police capacity, backed by statute passed by this Parliament, to enable us to deal with organised crime groups laundering proceeds of crime from overseas into Australian real estate and property concerns. As to the particular matters she has raised, I will seek an answer from the Australian Federal Police and, provided operational sensitivities can be respected, seek to give her an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not expect Senator Tate to carry that around in his head, but I did give him notice and I would have thought he could have consulted the Australian Federal Police file on this matter. As Senator Tate has offered to get me the information, I ask him to also advise me whether the Australian Federal Police was involved in consultation with the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission and the Queensland Treasury casino control division, because of investigations by these bodies into a question mark over Daikyo as a founding partner in the Jupiters Brisbane casino bid.

—I think it should be pointed out that Senator Kernot did give my office some indication that she would be asking a question in this area at about a quarter to one today. I did attempt to find out from the AFP whether it would have a response before Question Time. It has not been able to provide that, and I think that is perfectly understandable with an hour over lunch. It is absolutely extraordinary that Senator Kernot should be pressing that matter.

PARA.TAB: As to the further elements of the question asked by Senator Kernot, of course I will seek information as to whether, in fact, the AFP has been involved in giving help to Queensland authorities in judging the propriety of an applicant, or whether a particular applicant for a licence is a fit and proper person in relation to casino developments in Queensland.

I repeat that I believe very strongly that, with the emerging cooperation between the Federal Police and the National Police Agency of Japan, and the ability now of the Australian community to deal with money laundering into Australia from overseas, backed by very heavy penalties as passed by this Parliament, we do have the legislative and law enforcement capacity to deal with such matters as they are revealed to us by investigation and, one would hope, collaborative investigation with overseas law enforcement agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Can the Minister confirm reports that Toyota Australia has successfully negotiated an enterprise agreement with the trade union movement and its work force? In the light of union and ACTU support for the Government's car industry plan, can the Minister outline the role the unions have played in the restructuring which has taken place under the plan?

—This question might have been directed to Senator Cook or myself, but the fact of the matter is that there has been an enterprise agreement with the work force at the Toyota plant and the Industrial Relations Commission ratified this agreement this morning. This means that all major car manufacturers in Australia have now reached enterprise agreements. This underlies the constructive role played by the trade unions in changing this industry and other industries for the better in recent years.

PARA.TAB: I think it is very important to remember that the Toyota agreement is based on it being a one-union plant when the Altona plant is completed. That represents a considerable recognition of the need for change in an industry which has had up to seven unions and, in the current Toyota plant, still does. Sometimes the unions have been ahead of management in recognising the needs for these changes which relate to international competitiveness.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Kemp says, `Ha, ha'. As a car component manufacturer said on Adelaide radio yesterday, the problem with the coalition is that on industry issues it is just out of touch. Senator Kemp's `Ha, ha' just makes that point. Despite those changes, which have been enormous, the Opposition still wants to turn the car industry into an industrial relations battlefield. That is the only way it knows in the area of industrial relations. The Opposition spokesman for industry, technology and commerce is wandering around telling industry, `We will implement our industrial relations policy and, if necessary, we will get the police and the troops to make sure it is carried out'. I have been told that by numerous industrialists.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister say how important enterprise agreements have been to the willingness of car companies to invest in Australia?

—Senator Foreman originally asked me a question about Toyota. When Toyota announced a massive investment here it did so on the basis of the Industry Commission's tariff regime, on the basis that this Government would assist it in accessing export markets, and on the basis that it would have a one-union plant with a flexible work force. Those were the conditions which Toyota asked for, as it is entitled to do in making an investment of this kind. The one-union plant and enterprise bargaining were crucial to that investment as they are crucial to other investments in the motor vehicle industry.

PARA.TAB: The whole point is that, with the Opposition floating around announcing proposed changes in policies on these issues, the investment climate—which is a long term thing but which has to be understood now because of the lead times involved in this industry—is threatened. It is all very well for people like Steele Hall to say that we will pull the right policy levers in the year 2000. It is too late to pull the policy levers then. I hope those opposite will discuss this at their meeting tomorrow. The policy levers have to be left in place right now. There is no point putting forward figures as to what the Opposition's industrial relations policy will save on the price of a car because they are invented figures off the top of the head of a grazier who is more used to counting sheep than he is to understanding industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to remarks made by the Treasurer on 19 August 1992 on the Neil Mitchell show on Radio 3AW, where he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Because we didn't want people to be saying `oh, they're giving with one hand and taking from the other, therefore we indicated the kinds of areas that might be looked at, might be looked at, four years from now. . . I'm telling you the prospects of it happening and that is very slight. . .

Is it true that the Government is now being forced to release these additional taxation measure details because, in the words of Mr Dawkins, `the prospect of it happening' is now not `very slight' but a certainty? Is the Treasurer now correct in saying, `Oh, they're giving with one hand and taking from the other'?

TALK.START.PARA: —These questions which are invented by some staffer in somebody's office do not, in the scheme of things, make much sense. I have already answered the substance of this question in an answer I gave to Senator Short at the beginning of Question Time. The Opposition's problem is that today the National Farmers Federation is saying, `We don't know what the Fightback package means in relation to a reduction on fuel excise. We went to ask the Opposition yesterday and still they can't tell us. We don't know what it means in terms of road users'.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question related to the Government's secret tax agenda which is now no longer secret. It was a specific question as to the consistency between what is being put down today and what the Treasurer said a short time ago. That was the question; we are expecting an answer to that question, not a speech from the Leader of the Government on some other subject.
—Order! I ask the Minister to reply to the question.

—I am sorry if those opposite have been a bit dry gulched by all of this. The statement made by the Treasurer today is a definitive statement about government tax policy, which we have not got from the Opposition. It is a definitive statement which arises out of the Budget Papers. The Opposition sought to make capital out of it because the Government had honestly put forward proposals which would be considered.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister provide the Senate with details on media reports that Air New Zealand has announced that it will be using Brisbane as a hub for operations to Asia? Is the Minister aware of any other developments which might lead to increased international air services to Australia?
—I am delighted to advise the Senate of such tangible returns to the Australian economy from the Government's recent policy changes and the agreement that we have signed with New Zealand.
—How will it help the one million unemployed?
—I will tell Senator Kemp. Air New Zealand has announced that it will commence services to Taipei and Bangkok through Brisbane. It will operate two weekly Boeing 767 services—
—Poor old Gossie and Kirner are not going to be happy with this.

—The one thing the Opposition cannot stand to hear is good news for the economy and for Australia. The airline has indicated that it expects initially to inject $14m a year into the Queensland economy and to provide directly or indirectly—if Senator Kemp is interested in listening—1,500 new jobs in Queensland in its first year of operation. The initial destinations will be expanded to an anticipated level of 24 services a week into northern Asia and Japan by November 1994. By that time, Air New Zealand is confident that it will be employing directly or indirectly in Queensland 10,000 people and injecting in the order of $90m a year into the Queensland economy.
—I hope it brings a lot in because they will need a lot to handle all the new taxes.

—This decision is very good news indeed for the vitally important Australian tourist industry and for Australian exporters. Senator Macdonald in particular cannot handle any good news for Queensland. That is what he does not want to hear. The memorandum of understanding also provides for another Australian carrier to commence operations in November this year on the trans-Tasman route.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question, seeking further information. Is the Minister aware of media reports indicating concerns by members of the Australian tourism industry over current international air services to Australia?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question is clearly introducing a new subject matter. It is not a supplementary question arising out of the answer that was given by Senator Collins. It is a different subject matter. It is therefore out of order. Senator Burns will have his time in a few minutes to ask another question.

—One thing I am finding to be a problem with the strict time limit is that there have been at least three supplementaries today that I did not think were in order—one from the Opposition and two from the Government. I really do think that in this case the supplementary is on another subject. It really did not relate to the services asked about in the original question.

—Mr President, my original question was about the operation of Air New Zealand as an international carrier. The second part of that question was about increased international air services to Australia. The supplementary question asks for further information in that regard.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Mr President, you have just ruled that the supplementary question was out of order and Senator Burns is arguing your ruling.
—Order! In view of the explanation given by Senator Burns, I will allow the supplementary question and I will listen to the answer, as long as it relates to the original question.

—Mr President, the relationship in this issue is a direct one. I have just advised the Senate of the very welcome news that, as a direct result of the new agreement we have with New Zealand and the policy changes of the Government in creating new services to Queensland through the terminal at Brisbane, Air New Zealand is confident that it will immediately generate—that is, right now—a $14m injection into the Queensland economy. Fifteen hundred new jobs will be created from this initiative directly and indirectly, leading up to an injection in the order of $90m to $100m by 1994 and 10,000 new jobs.

PARA.TAB: The concern that has been expressed by the tourism industry is this: this direct and tangible result—and it is relevant to point this out—of 10,000 new jobs created in Queensland is a direct result of the successful negotiations on additional capacity with New Zealand. These are the very rights and negotiations that the National Party was calling on me to abort and use as a weapon in the case of the United States of America. As I said before, in terms of the wheat industry, it does not assist the national interest to help one industry by trying to damage another. The jobs that have now been created in Queensland as a result of this agreement that has been signed are a demonstration that there are very significant potential benefits for employment and the Australian economy in the welcome growth in our aviation and tourism industries.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Wheat Sales by United States of America to Pakistan

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to a press release issued by President Bush and senior White House officials in response to the President's visit with farm leaders in January. The press release stated that the EEP subsidies would be used under the following criteria: the nature of competition in foreign markets; US historic presence in the market; and budgetary impact on sales. In the case of yesterday's wheat sale to Pakistan, this criteria has not been followed. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Australian Government has used any diplomatic channel to inform the White House that it is in breach of its own guidelines set out in response to discussions with Australian farmers?

—It is the case that the press release in January did contain those elements. It is also the case that most of those elements were explicitly contained in the text of the statement announcing the enhanced EEP just a few days ago. To that extent, it is that much more disappointing to express the matter perhaps more mildly than it should be when it seems to have been totally ignored in the context of Pakistan.

PARA.TAB: The problem with the US announcement of the sale of 220,000 tonnes of white wheat under the EEP to Pakistan at an average bonus level of $32.56 per tonne is that, obviously, it involves a breach of the undertaking to fully respect the situation in those markets where the EC does not at the moment have a significant presence and to take into account the presence in that market of non-subsidising suppliers, including Australia. The explanation that has been given for that—namely, that the EC was, as it were, sniffing around with the intention of entering that market—is not an explanation that is acceptable to Australia. It is the very situation against which we are seeking to guard—namely, a situation of plunging into a market and having a price reduction effect by virtue of one's presence in the market with subsidised wheat in an environment where, in the present circumstances, there is no competitive pressure from the EC for such subsidisation.

On all accounts, it is a very unhappy situation. Our unhappiness with it was communicated very directly and explicitly to the United States officials who were unlucky enough to be in Australia yesterday for the agricultural trade talks, which grew out of the Bush visit in January this year. As Mr Crean has indicated, it is a matter of communicating effectively our concerns rather than raging as such.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What action will the Minister take to ensure that the proposed 425,000 tonne sale, set aside for 21 September, will not be destroyed by American EEP wheat?
—Ron has just found a loophole in the two minute rule.
—Yes. It is our hope that it will not be and that, if it does go ahead, that it will not be—
—We need to be more positive in what we are saying.

—I am expressing a hope and the fact that has been communicated already, I am sure, to the Americans. It certainly will be again next week when Mr Kerin visits the United States to talk directly to Mr Madigan, the Secretary of Agriculture, and to Carla Hills, the trade representative.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt where Australia stands in this situation. The obvious difficulty we have is that a long term solution to this problem will not be achieved other than in a multilateral context with the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round. In the meantime, all that we can hope is that, by continuing to press the case through these various channels, the Americans become a little more conscious of their international obligations than their domestic, political demands upon them, which unhappily does not seem to be the case at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I preface my question with the information that, on 3 March this year, an announcer on Melbourne public radio station 3WRB, in referring to a female volunteer involved with the station who at that time was in hospital, broadcast that she was `doing what she does best on her back with her legs in the air'. Is the Minister aware of the view of this statement taken on behalf of the licensing director of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal that `the licensee did not, by broadcasting it, breach either the radio program standards or the provisions of the Broadcasting Act 1942'. Does the Minister agree with that view?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I personally investigated this matter when it was brought to my attention. Were the remarks quoted by Senator Powell actually broadcast, I would find them grossly offensive. In no way could one possibly find an excuse for any broadcaster who would broadcast such a gratuitous offence over the air.

PARA.TAB: I have asked for a complete response to Senator Powell's concerns, which I have received. I have looked at the answer. I cannot possibly fit it into two minutes. The other difficulty is that, because of the sensitivity of the issue, it is not reasonable to cut out any of the answer. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.
Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: RESPONSE:

PARA.TAB: The ABT received a complaint from a couple (Mr and Mrs Allen) who were involved with 3WRB, alleging that an offensive remark about Mrs Allen was broadcast on the station. It was claimed that an announcer, referring to a station volunteer who was in hospital at the time, broadcast that she was `Doing what she does best on her back with her legs in the air'.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr and Mrs Allen claimed that they had complained to station management but were not satisfied with the action taken.
The couple sent the ABT copies of letters from eight people which had been sent to the station's management committee complaining about the alleged remark.
The licensee denies that the remark was made. The problem is that there is no log tape to show who is right, because the station was not required to keep a log tape for the program in question.

In my view, a remark such as the one alleged to have been made, is just not acceptable behaviour for a broadcaster. It is demeaning to women in general, and many men and women would find it offensive. However, the ABT has told me that a remark such as the alleged comment, while it might be offensive, would not breach current radio program standards.
The relevant standard states: `A licensee may not transmit a program which:

PARA.TAB: (a) is likely to incite hatred or perpetuate hatred against; or
(b) gratuitously vilifies: any person on the basis of ethnicity, nationality, race, gender, sexual preference, religion or physical or mental disability'.

ANSWER.PARA: This standard and the similar TV standard are currently being reviewed by the tribunal.
The tribunal will give its work to the new broadcasting authority for use in determining codes of practice.
Finally, this issue does raise the question of standards and the community, and where the two occasionally part company because of changes in attitudes.

The new broadcasting authority is not about to impose censorship on broadcasters, nor will it listen to only one point of view on acceptable standards, but I would have thought that it is in the interests of all broadcasters to keep their fingers on the pulse of community attitudes.
It is obvious to me that attitudes about the portrayal of women in the media have shifted. I would hope that it is just as obvious to broadcasters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Justice aware that the Federal Police, in the course of criminal investigations, obtained a transcript of a telephone conversation between the State member for Chatsworth, Mr Mackenroth, and a Mr Santo Coco and that the transcript, which included allegations of a $5,000 bribe, was given to the Premier of Queensland, Mr Wayne Goss, by the Queensland Commissioner of Police? Has there been any further action by the Federal Police, as it appears that the Premier has been involved in a cover-up which includes the extraordinary expunging of the Hansard record?

—I am not aware of any particular matter such as the one Senator Parer has raised. I do have some recollection of an expunging of the Hansard record in the Queensland Parliament, but I must admit that was some time ago and I cannot recollect any particular AFP involvement. If there was any such involvement in producing a particular report, once again having regard to operational sensitivities and any charges that might be laid, I will ask the AFP to provide an answer and give it to the Senate.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for the answer. In view of the answer he gave to Senator Kernot before about the Federal Police having the capacity to deal with these matters—that was in reference to the Yakuza—I want his assurance that the Federal Police have the same capacity to investigate this matter in relation to both the Premier of Queensland and the honourable member for Chatsworth.

—The Australian Federal Police has as its charter the investigation of alleged offences involving what are claimed to be breaches of Commonwealth laws. If what is alleged would involve a breach of a Commonwealth law, that would be a matter for the Federal Police to investigate. If it has been involved in such an investigation, I believe that it would be proper, given operational proprieties, to inform the Senate of any consequences of such investigation.

PARA.TAB: There are other occasions where the Federal Police do assist State bodies, such as the Independent Commission Against Corruption or the equivalent in Queensland, or indeed the National Crime Authority, to carry out their investigations. The Australian Federal Police has always been most cooperative. We believe that the old territorial disputes and demarcations and jealousies between law enforcement agencies in Australia have in the past inhibited proper investigation of offences.

Nevertheless, I repeat my central point: the Federal Police has as its primary role the investigation of Commonwealth offences. If that has been the case here, as long as it does not interfere with any investigation, operation or court process, I will try to obtain an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General by noting that I gave both him and the Attorney-General's office two hours notice before Question Time, and also that the Minister received a question on notice yesterday on a similar topic.
—Senator Spindler, I suggest that you ask the question.

—Can the Minister advise whether investigations have been conducted by the Australian Securities Commission to determine whether any insider trading laws have been breached by the extraordinary sale of one and a half million shares in Jupiters Limited in the two weeks prior to Jupiters being awarded preferred applicant status for the Brisbane casino on 26 May this year?

—At this stage, I am not aware whether the Australian Securities Commission is conducting an investigation of the kind referred to by Senator Spindler. Ordinarily, I would not expect an investigative agency such as the Australian Securities Commission to offer any comment on whether it is or is not conducting an inquiry of that kind.

PARA.TAB: I have, nevertheless, sought to make inquiry of the ASC as to whether it wishes to offer any comment. It has to be emphasised that the Parliament established the Australian Securities Commission on a basis of independence and integrity and would insist that its investigations be carried out in a way which was not subjected to any ministerial or political pressure. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. Nevertheless, I believe the Senate, and indeed the Parliament as a whole, have a duty to put this pressure on. I ask the Minister to include the following in his inquiries: has the Australian Securities Commission determined at what stage during this two-week flurry of activity, which saw the share price for Jupiters increase from $2.19 to $2.52, the Queensland Premier and the Cabinet were advised that Jupiters had been recommended as the preferred applicant for the casino tender?
—I will take that question on notice.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of today's statement by the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, seeking to raise additional tax by enhancing the Tax Office's compliance strategies, I ask whether under the new rules the Tax Commissioner will automatically examine the taxation consequences of a taxpayer purchasing multimillions of dollars worth of assets at prices far below their stated value and shuffling profits and losses between companies in the same group. If not, will the Minister ask the Tax Commissioner to examine the implications for the Government's revenue of the purchase for $430,000 in May 1991 by the then Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, of a half interest in Euphron Pty Ltd, a pig holding company, which has just revealed in its annual return for the year to June 1991 a book value of its shareholder's equity of $8.4m, of which Mr Keating's share is $4.2m, or about 10 times higher that his purchase cost just six weeks earlier?

—The announcement made by the Treasurer today was about further enhancing equity and fairness in the tax system. We have done that over the years. The Opposition has always objected. The tax system under this Government will be administered fairly and with equity and without fear or favour in respect of any particular taxpayer. In so far as there is any specific matter in Senator Baume's question, I will address that to the Treasurer. As Senator Baume ought to know and perhaps scarcely respects, the fact of the matter is that transactions between taxpayers and the Tax Commissioner are considered by most decent people as being private.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister a specific question. He has not answered any part of it. I asked him whether he would ask the Tax Commissioner—not intervene or interfere in any way—to examine the implications. I ask him again, in relation to the matter of shuffling profits and losses, which he did not address in his answer: will the Minister advise me whether, under the new compliance rules, the Tax Commissioner will be able to examine the implications for the Government's revenue of large transfers of profits and losses within the same group, such as where Mr Keating's half-owned company Rincraft Pty Ltd reported a profit for the year to June 1991 of $1,521,585, which was almost exactly offset by a reported loss by another half-owned Keating company, Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd, of $1,518,817. What is being done under the new compliance rules to ensure that such shuffling does not change the tax liability? (Time expired)

—As I said in my answer to the original question, under this Government the Tax Commissioner has administered tax laws with fairness and equity and will continue to do so. In so far as there are changes to the tax laws announced by the Treasurer, I am sure the Taxation Commissioner will continue to do that. I repeat: only somebody who does not understand the rules of civilised behaviour would ask a Minister in this Government to get the Tax Commissioner to inquire into a particular situation. We do not do that. Decent people do not do that. Only grubs do that.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Government considering introducing a consumption tax? What would be the likely effect of such a tax on wages policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say quite categorically that the Government is not going to introduce a consumption tax. One of the reasons why we are not is that it would have a profoundly negative effect on the Australian economy. For example, under the Opposition's proposed consumption tax package, if normal wage and salary earners refuse to accept full discounting of their wage increases for the effect of the GST on prices, there is likely to be a wages break-out. If higher prices are imposed on wage and salary earners, as the Opposition will through its consumption tax, they will seek to correct that position by negotiating for compensatory wage increases, and this will lead to a wages break-out. Why should workers not want to do that when a 15 per cent GST is imposed on them?

PARA.TAB: Under Dr Hewson's consumption tax package, the bulk of workers will lose out; they will be worse off. I can give an example. Treasury's analysis shows that 70 per cent of households will clearly be worse off. For example, a family with children and with both parents working and each earning $25,000 would be up to $25 a week worse off. On the other hand, a family whose combined income is over $90,000 a year would find itself up to $105 a week better off. That is the Treasury analysis, not the Government's. It is an independent analysis by the Treasury which shows that the—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: even in the shortened time we have for answering questions, your ruling still stands that a Minister who chooses to answer a question should only answer the question in terms of his portfolio responsibilities. Would you please uphold your own ruling?
—Order! From what I have been able to hear, the Minister is dealing with the question within his—
—Mr President—
—He was asked whether he would introduce such a policy, as I understand it, and reasons why he would or would not introduce it. I call Senator Cook.

—Mr President, on the point of order, and taking the precedent that you set in allowing Senator Burns to make a comment upon your ruling earlier: I put to you that I think you were in conversation with Senator Jones and, in fact, did not hear what the Minister said. —Thank you, Mr President. What we have is a policy that favours the rich and disadvantages the great majority of Australian wage and salary earners, without a wages policy that can guarantee wage restraint. We have the accord. That has delivered years of restraint in Australia. No one should forget that under the Fraser Government there was a wages explosion for exactly this reason. —I take a point of order, Mr President. Could I request that the Minister table the typed notes he was reading from?
—Yes. Will the Minister table the notes?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's One Nation statement where he promised to streamline approval processes for major projects. Is the Minister aware that in April 1991 an independent task force recommended the construction of the $600m Tully-Millstream hydro extension and that the Queensland Government then referred the project to the Commonwealth Government for approval, as it includes a small area of World Heritage listed land? —My supplementary question is to Senator Collins, who has been the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia.
