If he is taking it on notice, I ask him also to find out, if approval has not been given, when it is likely—after 17 months—that approval might be given, in view of the Prime Minister's promise to streamline projects.

—I must say that I find it encouraging for Senator Macdonald to be concerned about initiatives that favour Queensland, instead of constantly attacking them, as he did in the Estimates Committee hearing again last night in respect of the ABC's upgrading of its studios in Queensland, which he thought was a bad idea. Apart from those gratuitously offensive comments, I have nothing to add to my previous answer.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. What are the benefits of the taxation arrangements announced by the Treasurer today? Do these changes improve the equity of the taxation system?

—The changes to the FBT system, as I said earlier, will preserve the integrity of the income tax system. Over the last few years, as a result of the concessional treatment of fringe benefits, some high income earners have arranged to have their salary paid as a fringe benefit, and less tax is paid than if they were paid an ordinary wage. In other words, there has been a shift from salary packages to fringe benefits packages. The change introduced today means that fringe benefits will receive the same treatment as ordinary wages. That is a fair outcome and one that preserves the tax base.
—Have you thought about the unintended consequences?

—Even Senator Watson, to whom we concede some knowledge on these issues, will concede that if the Opposition seeks to represent itself as a serious political group, fairness and equity in the tax system are essential characteristics. Enhanced tax file number and other anti-evasion measures will improve compliance in the tax system. These measures are directed at the few who avoid or evade their taxes. People who associate themselves with opposing these measures are choosing to support people who have been tax cheats—the people who are cheating their fellow Australians at the expense of the honest taxpayer.
—Rubbish!

—Honourable senators opposite talk a lot about the black economy. Their Deputy Leader invented figures on this until he was black in the face. The Government is the only major political party which has told Australians in detail what its tax policies are. Treasury and Finance found holes of enormous amounts in the funding of the Opposition package. It still will not say how those holes are going to be filled.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Coulter asked me a question about consultation in relation to plutonium shipments. I have a fairly detailed answer for him. If it is acceptable, I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: QUESTION

In view of Australia's membership of the International Atomic Energy Agency, has Australia been in any way consulted specifically in relation to the security of this shipment and any future shipments from France or Britain back to Japan.
ANSWER

PARA.TAB: Australia has discussed security arrangements for the shipments with Japan and the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM), in the course of regular consultations under Australia's nuclear agreements with Japan and EURATOM.

Australia has also discussed the security of the shipments with the United States, which has a 1987 agreement with Japan on physical protection and safety arrangements for the shipments, including the preparation of a detailed transportation plan.
-The United States recently announced that, after careful consideration, it had advised Japan of its approval of the transportation plan.

Japan has also made available publicly information on the physical protection arrangements for the shipments, including information on the construction and equipment of the transport ship and the escort ship, although obviously certain details such as the routes will not be disclosed on security grounds.

Australia is satisfied that the physical protection and safety arrangements for the shipments meet or exceed international standards, including those of the international Atomic Energy Agency, for the transport of plutonium.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Health, Housing and Community Services: Payment of Grants

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Lees asked me a question about monthly payments for programs administered by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services and some consequential questions. I have received an answer from the Minister. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Question

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it correct that the Government is proposing to move to monthly payments of grants for all programs administered by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services?
(2) If it is correct, does the Minister agree that this move will have serious consequences for the already underresourced and stretched services?
These consequences including among others:
(a)a substantial loss of income to service provider agencies which have budgeted to receive interest on grants in advance.
(b)the trebling of the administrative load and cost for the (mostly voluntary) treasurers of non-government agencies who already find the present system arduous.

ANSWER.PARA: Answer

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, the Government is proposing to move to monthly payments or grants for all programs.

Under finance directions issued with the Minister for Finance's authority under the Audit Act, payments by all Commonwealth Departments must have regard to the cash management implications. The finance directions, which are binding on departments because they have the force of law, require that payments cannot be made significantly in advance of need.

A review of the Department's programs revealed that the current cash management arrangements for a large number of programs already comply with the finance directions. For the balance of programs which were found not to comply with the directions (most receiving quarterly payments in advance), it has been necessary for the Department to move progressively to monthly payments in advance in order to comply with the directions.

In general, the largest component of expenditure by organisations receiving grants is salaries, which are normally paid fortnightly in arrears. Continuing to pay quarterly in advance in these circumstances would be contravening the finance directions under the Audit Act. The move to a monthly, rather than fortnightly, payment cycle is intended to give organisations some flexibility to budget for non-salary costs whose cash flow may not be even.

In moving to a more frequent payment cycle, there is no intention to alter existing acquittal arrangements. That is, there will not be an increase in the amount of paperwork associated with accounting for the grant. In addition, the Department is progressively moving towards making payments by direct credit to bank accounts which may reduce some clerical efforts associated with banking cheques.

In the circumstances, it is considered that the move to monthly payments in advance for most of the Department's programs is an appropriate balance between the cash management requirements imposed on the Department and the need for service providers to receive financial support on a timely basis with minimal, if any, additional administrative workload.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some time ago, Senator Bill O'Chee asked the Attorney-General a question concerning numbers of matters referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions during the 1991 calendar year and the average time taken to decide whether each of such matters should result in a prosecution. I have an answer. I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
Senator O'Chee asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 15 July 1992:
(1) What was the total number of matters referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions during the 1991 calendar year for the purposes of considering a possible prosecution.
(2) What was the average time taken to decide whether each such matter should result in a prosecution.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Director of Public Prosecutions has advised that 4925 matters were referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions for the purpose of considering a possible prosecution. This includes 495 matters that were referred to the Australian Government Solicitor in Hobart and Darwin who conducts prosecutions on behalf of the DPP.

(2) The Director of Public Prosecutions has advised that the actual date a decision is made whether to institute a prosecution is not recorded on the DPP's Case Matter Management System. However, with respect to those matters where it was decided to institute a prosecution, the average period between the date a matter was received and the date the matter was first mentioned in court was 19.61 weeks.

It should be noted that in some cases the agency that referred the matter would have been requested by the DPP to carry out further investigations before the decision was made whether to institute a prosecution. It should also be noted that the DPP does not itself institute a prosecution. That is the responsibility of the agency that referred the matter. Accordingly, there will inevitably be some delay between the decision of the DPP that a matter should be the subject of a prosecution and the issue of the relevant summons. Further, to take account of court backlogs in some jurisdictions, and to allow sufficient time for a summons to be served, a summons may be made returnable up to 6 to 8 weeks from the date it was issued.

The figure of 19.61 weeks does not include those matters referred to the Australian Government Solicitor in Hobart and Darwin for decision. Information of the kind sought in this part of the question cannot be obtained from the computer system operated by the Australian Government Solicitor, and a manual examination of each relevant file would be unreasonably time consuming.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Alston asked me a question which I think, by agreement, was based on an article in the Canberra Times. It was a question about a paper prepared by Dr Ann Harding of the Centre of Economic and Social Modelling. I undertook to seek some advice from the Treasurer. I have been advised that the results of this type of analysis should be treated with a great deal of caution. The newspaper report of Dr Harding's paper appeared to report only selectively on the results. Dr Harding's paper, properly analysed, shows in table 1 that households in the bottom 10 per cent of all households paid $6.90 a week in WST and $7 a week in excise. The amount of tax paid rises steadily as income increases, reaching $62 a week in wholesale sales tax and $47.20 a week in excise for the top 10 per cent of households.

PARA.TAB: What I have just said has to be seen in conjunction with the rest of this answer. Wholesale sales tax paid increases faster than excise. As Dr Harding states, `WST is essentially proportional across much of the income range'. In fact, on Dr Harding's figures, the WST becomes slightly progressive when calculated as a proportion of expenditure rather than gross income. There is nothing new in the claim that the indirect tax system is regressive. The primary cause is the existence of excises.

As to the claim that the fuel excise is a most regressive tax, the paper makes no claim about individual excises and, indeed, does not attempt to make any distinction between them. The progressivity or otherwise of any given tax is not at issue. The only thing that really matters is the progressivity of the tax and transfer system in its entirety.It is possible to design a system that compensates, for example, for the impact of the GST. The Treasury analysis, in fact, shows the Opposition how to design such a compensation package. Yet the Opposition instead designed a system that skewed the benefits towards high income earners—a system that deliberately over-compensates high income earners at the expense of low and middle income earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?
—For example, in terms of the Opposition's tax scales, the tax benefit for top income earners is something like six times that of middle income earners and ten times that of low income earners.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time, Senator Kernot asked a question about the Yakuza, the Japanese mafia, and referred to Daikyo. In an interjection across the chamber in a fairly light-hearted way I said, `Is that your preferred Labor candidate for Leichhardt?' or something like that.
—Light-hearted!
—Leichhardt—the electorate of Leichhardt.
—You said it in a light-hearted way!
—In light-hearted banter across the chamber. Mr President, you did not hear it and nobody else heard the exclamation.
—I did.

—Senator Collins, in his usual fashion, misheard it and makes a major issue about some fairly light-hearted banter across the chamber. I am rather distressed for the people involved. Because of the involvement of Senator Collins, Senator Tate, who then had the floor, on national television and on broadcast day, made a speech about slurring people.
—He heard it.

—Nobody else did. Senator Tate raised this matter on national television. You then, Mr President, based not on hearing what I said but based on what Senator Tate said, called upon me to retract because another member was spoken about. I replied in a somewhat nonplussed way. I was quite taken aback when you called upon me to retract that because I did not understand what the matter was all about. But you raised the point that I had referred to a member in the other place. I rose to my feet and said I did not refer to the member, I referred to the candidate.

PARA.TAB: My concern is that I know Mr Nev Bates, who was the Daikyo boss in Cairns and a bloke who was suggested as being the Labor candidate for Leichhardt. As it turned out, he did not seek pre-selection, I understand, and there is another Labor Party candidate for the seat of Leichhardt.

I am making this explanation at this stage because I want to say quite categorically that at no stage do I suggest that Mr Bates or anyone else connected with Daikyo in Cairns was connected with the Yakuza, the Japanese mafia. As I say, he is not even the Labor Party candidate for Leichhardt. I am rather distressed that that might come across and might be seen in that way. I do know Mr Bates. I have had a number of dealings with him. Obviously none of his colleagues in the Labor Party know whether he is a candidate or not. I unreservedly say that in no way would I suggest that he is in any way associated with the Yukuza.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make another personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins, in his typical loudmouth fashion, accused me in an answer he gave to a question of denigrating the ABC offices in North Queensland as a result of something that happened last night in the Estimates Committee. It is quite clear from Hansard that I was simply seeking information. The Hansard record will show that very clearly.I resent the continued loudmouth, buffoonish interjections by Senator Collins, when he deliberately misrepresents things that I say. He is obviously under a lot of pressure because he is losing ground in the north. I just wish to place on record that in no way would I suggest that those offices were being favoured. I was simply seeking information about the costs of those offices. When I receive that information, I will make further comments on it.

DEBATE.TITLE: WHEAT SALES BY USA TO PAKISTAN

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill—Mr President, I seek leave to move a motion to take note of the answer by Senator Evans to Senator Boswell relating to trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We have a problem in that under an order of the Senate I think we now have to put, before any other business, the motion that was to be moved by Senator McMullan.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop—Why?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the advice I have received. I believe that is the correct procedure.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner—It is a President's ruling.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a President's ruling. I have been informed that we passed the resolution this morning.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop—On a point of order, Mr President, would you please explain to the Senate on what basis you intend to lift that particular item above—
Senator McMullan—Because we carried a resolution to do so, you dill.

Senator Bishop—Talk about the pot calling the kettle black. Yesterday, Senator McMullan was found napping as usual. He had a bad day all round. He was found to be a poor manager of Government Business, as well as a poor manager of legislation before this chamber. I ask you, Mr President, what is the basis of your ruling that this matter will take precedence over all others?

Senator McMullan—On the point of order, Mr President, as a competent manager of Government Business this morning I moved a resolution that explicitly said that immediately after Question Time we would deal with this business, and you all voted for it, for which I was grateful, thank you.

Senator Bishop—Further to this point of order, Mr President; with respect, immediately after Question Time, when a senator rises to take note of an answer that was given in Question Time, I put it to you that Question Time, in the terms of that motion, has not been concluded.
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The resolution that was passed this morning was that at the conclusion of Question Time today Government Business order of the day No. 3 relating to the proposed motion to limit debate on answers to questions without notice be called on. That takes precedence. That is the advice I have received. Once this is concluded it is open to Senator Hill to seek leave to take note of an answer that was given today.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill—I ask a question arising out of this discussion, Mr President. What is the definition of the end of Question Time? I thought that at the end of Question Time you invited certain Ministers to give answers relating to questions given on another day. Are you extending the definition of Question Time to include that? Are you also extending the definition of Question Time to include personal explanations? If Question Time is to be described in these broader terms, surely other matters arising out of Question Time should be dealt with before this item of business is reached.

TALK.START.PARA: —The usual procedure is that when Ministers answer it is taken as part of Question Time. Senator Macdonald then sought, and was given, leave of the Senate to make a personal explanation. Are you going to seek leave to move your motion?

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan—You will get leave after the motion.
Senator Hill—Then I will seek to suspend Standing Orders. Mr President, I seek leave to move a motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the contingent notice of motion standing in my name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate or to provide for the consideration of any other matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek to suspend Standing Orders in order that I can move a motion to take note of the answer given by Senator Evans, and have that matter dealt with before we deal with this Government Business, order of the day No.3.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is it urgent?

—I am about to tell the Senate why it is urgent. It is urgent because Australian wheat growers are going broke as a result of not only United States subsidies but also European Community subsidies. The Government provides no answer. It is totally devoid of policy in this area. It is totally devoid of any diplomatic strategy whatsoever. That is why it is urgent. That is why this Senate should debate why this Government has failed. This Government should explain its failure to have both a policy and a diplomatic strategy to answer what is occurring.
—What would you do?

—I am about to get to what we would do. What happened a week ago when the United States announced an enormous extension of the EEP scheme by giving wheat subsidies to its rural producers? The Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Keating, was caught flatfooted. He did not know it was going to occur. There had been no diplomatic dialogue. Our mission in Washington did not know it was going to occur. The Prime Minister was told in the middle of the night at some dinner that it had already occurred. He had no idea. This was the level of the relationship with the United States that exists under the Government in these circumstances.

PARA.TAB: What did Dr Hewson do? As any sensible, rational and reasoned leader should do in this country, he wrote to Mr Bush setting out the concerns of the Australian people in this matter. He set out in a most reasoned letter their deep disturbance at what was occurring—in fact, their anger at what was occurring.

The letter looked at the basis of the relationship and the importance of the traditional relationship in other areas such as defence and whatever; how the trading relationship had developed; how we had been disturbed in the past by the extension of the EEP scheme; and how we understood that the United States was trying to combat what was happening in Europe. But the letter brought to the attention of the President of the United States that whether it was his intention or not, the effect of this extension of the EEP scheme was to hurt fair traders such as those in Australia, those who are prepared to produce for the market on the basis of their cost of production, not on the basis of subsidies. Dr Hewson brought that to the attention of the President of the United States. He went on to suggest some positive alternatives.

Senator Evans interjected, `What would you suggest'. The importance of Dr Hewson's letter is that it makes some positive suggestions. The alternative is that we get nothing from the Australian Government. What was the response of the Prime Minister to Dr Hewson's letter? It was to bucket him, to abuse him—to say that Dr Hewson is completely out of step and that he should not be doing these things. Not that the Prime Minister was picking up the ball and producing policy, entering into diplomatic dialogue. His only answer is the answer that he always gives, and that is simply to attack someone. In this instance it was to attack the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson.

This letter sets out some actions that the Australian Government should be taking. First, it suggested that they ought to enter into a dialogue to try to minimise the EEP payments and to try to ensure that they do not cross the border into our traditional markets, as has happened in today's announcement of the extension of the sale of American subsidised wheat to Pakistan. This traditional market of Australia's, which I understand has been basically an uncorrupted market in the past, is now to be corrupted in this way. Dr Hewson said that there ought to be urgent dialogue with the United States to try to avoid that happening. Did Mr Keating respond to that? No, he did not. He just abused Dr Hewson and said that he did not know what he was doing.

Secondly, Dr Hewson suggested a process of looking at some offsets, at least in the short term. This might not help the wheat growers but it may help some other portion of the agricultural sector in Australia that is also being prejudiced by the extension of international subsidies by both the United States and Europe. What was the response of the Prime Minister to that constructive and positive suggestion? He bucketed Dr Hewson again.

Further, he said that in the longer term Australia should be looking at a closer relationship with the United States, this major trading power that is now locking itself into the North American Free Trade Agreement; that Australia should, perhaps, in the longer term look to dialogue that would even lead—and I use the words that are in Dr Hewson's letter—`to eventual membership' by Australia of NAFTA. He spoke of, in the shorter term, `greater Australian involvement with, and eventual membership of, NAFTA'. Dr Hewson says that he has raised that with the Australian Government for it to consider and enter into dialogue. What was the response of Mr Keating? Again, it was to bucket Dr Hewson—nothing constructive, nothing positive; just an attack on the Opposition. This is always Mr Keating's answer.
That is what we are so frustrated about. That is what Australians have a right to be angry about. This Government ought to face up to its responsibilities. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government would not mind in the slightest the Senate taking note of the statement that I made today during Question Time if the object of that exercise was to express in an effective bipartisan way, as Senator Boswell indicated to me earlier that he wanted to take the opportunity to do, our common opposition to this very unhappy recent development in United States agricultural policy. It is entirely appropriate that the Parliament express a view on that. We would have been perfectly happy to allow time for Senator Hill, Senator Boswell or anyone else to move such a motion after the one minute that I understand it would have taken Senator McMullan to move the particular motion that procedurally he had established the grounds for earlier on.

PARA.TAB: But be that as it may, let me say that we have no opposition to the matter being debated in a sensible way. But it has not been debated in a sensible way by Senator Hill. What he has demonstrated again is the utter inability of the Opposition to look at larger questions of national interest. Rather, he has adopted a narrow, vulgar, partisan political view of this. He seeks the opportunity at every available occasion to not make sensible points about the way in which we should sensibly be conducting our trade policy so as to maximise Australia's national interests. Rather, he has advanced less than sensible points about the kind of political posturing that the Opposition feels it needs to engage in on these occasions.

The point about Dr Hewson's contribution to this debate is that it was muddleheaded and wrongheaded. As I have said on previous occasions, it was quite immature in its perception of the real elements of the situation that could be affected by the Australian Government. We all know perfectly well that the basic problem with the distortion of agricultural markets world wide is the existence initially of the European Community's market subsidy policy, which has been followed in rapid order by the United States in an attempt, in terms of its original foundation at least, whatever its recent manifestation has been, to counter that EC proposal and to deal with it by a form of trade war.

That is the basic problem that we are confronting and nothing that we do as a nation can address that basic problem other than to secure the remedy of that basic problem, which is effective multilateral trade liberalisation and effective trade disciplines through the GATT Round that is presently under way. Obviously, that is where we are devoting our primary focus in an attempt to resolve this question because we know perfectly well, as any sensible commentator knows, that it is only through that mechanism that the fundamental underlying problem of the EEP program will be able to be addressed.

At the same time we are trying very hard to minimise the adverse implications of that policy until such time as it is addressed in the international forum in which it needs to be addressed. We are addressing the issue in a systematic way with the President. We did that in January. We have done it in subsequent exchanges. We are doing it in the present agricultural talks. We will be doing it next week when Mr Kerin goes and talks to the senior Ministers concerned. We are endeavouring to mobilise in this respect the other wheat trading nations that are adversely affected by this exercise—our fellow senior members of the Cairns Group.

We are proceeding in a level-headed, sensible, diplomatic way to maximise the chances of the effect on our wheat sales being minimised. That policy has in fact really worked quite well, as I think Senator Boswell would acknowledge, over the last 12 months when we have had the spectre of EEP sales intruding into our traditional non-subsidised markets hanging over our head. But in practice those sales have been able to be effectively avoided by one means or another as a result of a fairly effective consultative process. We had hoped that that would continue.

The very unhappy results in Pakistan that were announced a day or so ago do rather demonstrate that, as I said in Question Time, the political imperative seems for the moment in United States political thinking to have outweighed the international obligation imperative. That is an unhappy development. We will take the matter up politically where it needs to be taken up next week when Mr Kerin goes to the United States and all the huffing and puffing in the world will not address that problem.

The reason Dr Hewson got a bucketing from Mr Keating and the rest of us last week was that he failed to acknowledge those realities about that particular dual-track approach to the resolution of this problem through the international mechanism and through sensible bilateral discussions. The basic strategy that Dr Hewson advanced to deal with this was the compensatory strategy—one which tries to leap in, embrace NAFTA, get access to US markets in beef, dairy and sugar, and thereby make up for what one loses on the wheat sales that continued to be subsidised. It was a loopy strategy, one that showed no signs of understanding the realities of the force and power of the lobby groups in the United States and no particular understanding of the way in which NAFTA had not helped Canada to deal with exactly similar problems; a strategy which failed completely to understand the adverse implications for Australian industry if it had been pursued. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a procedural matter that we are debating and not the substantive issue. I cannot help but reflect on the dissimulation of the Opposition and the way in which it is prepared to use any pragmatic, slimy argument to support its immediate and short term convenience.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think the term `slimy Opposition' is unparliamentary and Senator Coulter should be asked to withdraw it.
—Order! I think Senator Coulter used the term `slimy argument' or `slimy tactic', in which case it would not be—
—He said `slimy Opposition'.
—I do not think so. I will ask Senator Coulter. I heard Senator Coulter say `slimy tactic' and not `slimy Opposition'.
—Further to my point of order, I believe that I heard `slimy Opposition'. I ask you, Mr President, to read Hansard. Tomorrow, if that is correct, will you get Senator Coulter to withdraw.
—Certainly.

—Mr President, I did not. I said it was a slimy and pragmatic argument which suits the Opposition's immediate purpose and pays no attention whatsoever to principle. The Opposition raised the issue of the one-minute time limit on questions and the two-minute time limit on answers. I believe that you are absolutely correct, Mr President, in proceeding this afternoon with the motion in relation to taking note. By Senator Hill's procedure, it has become quite clear that if we were to adopt the proposals before us in relation to taking note, that procedure could be defeated every single afternoon by Senator Hill or anybody else in the Opposition simply using their contingent notice of motion.

PARA.TAB: We supported the Opposition in all good faith in relation to a time limit and we would in all good faith support the Government in relation to a time limit to take note for the very reason that we thought—we now know we were incorrect—that the Opposition was moving a time limit with good intention. We now realise that there is no good intention on the part of the Opposition whatsoever.

The issue which was the subject of the question is very important and the Opposition has every opportunity to debate that in an urgency motion if it wishes. No urgency motion was put up. It could introduce an MPI tomorrow. There is plenty of opportunity. The Opposition does not need to defeat a very good trial procedure that we are attempting to put in place now in order to get only five minutes on what they themselves regard as an important issue. It is, indeed, an important issue and it deserves a much longer debate. It does not deserve simply five minutes of catcalling across the chamber. This is a procedural motion and we should be getting on with debating that procedural matter so that we can trial this limitation on taking note of answers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am not sure whether we are debating this matter or not, and maybe Senator McMullan can enlighten us. Senator Evans said that he would debate the issue. I am not sure whether Senator McMullan will allow the debate or not, but I will proceed on the basis that he is not going to allow the debate.

PARA.TAB: I support Senator Hill's motion. There are 45,000 wheat growers out there who are absolutely shattered by yesterday's decision. This motion deserves some debate. It deserves to be brought before the Parliament. We could have brought it on as an MPI or urgency motion, but the Government is trying to get its legislation through. We wanted to have two 5- or 10-minute speeches, and now we have been rejected.

On 2 September the United States Government announced that it would increase its EEP payments by $1.4 billion, and EEP subsidised almost 30 million tonnes of wheat—the total export crop. When that announcement was made the Government should have gone on red alert. It had had two weeks warning. It had had two weeks to do something about it, to put a procedure in place to stop the US Government. Two weeks later—yesterday—we heard an announcement that the EEP-assisted sale to Pakistan would be 220,000 tonnes of wheat in a market that was rightfully our market.

No white wheat was going into Pakistan; there was a very small proportion of red wheat going in from the EC. Mr Bush assured the farmers after his visit in June that he would continue to take into account Australia's interest as a non-subsidising exporter. He gave that response to the farmers and he also made it in a letter dated 4 September. Seven or eight days later we find that Mr Bush, the leader of the most powerful nation in the world, has gone back on his word. We have seen him do a complete about-face, and Australian farmers cannot understand it. To them a man's word is his bond. Deals are done on a handshake.

Australian farmers cannot understand how the leader of a nation we have stood by so many times could just turn his back on them. They cannot understand why Australia offered Mr Bush the greatest honour given to any visiting head of state, one not given even to our own monarch—to address both Houses of Parliament. In that announcement he said that he was our friend and would never let us down or turn his back on us. He then went out yesterday and did that. No-one in the bush understands what it is all about. That is why we have to debate this very important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about bringing the flag back?

—I would be interested in Senator Schacht's contribution on this because it is a very serious matter. Ninety per cent of the EEP wheat that has been sold has not increased American sales at all. All it has done is lower the price of all wheat sales in the rest of the world.

PARA.TAB: These are the reasons why we want a fully fledged debate on this matter of maybe 10 or 15 minutes each. We are trying to do it in a matter of five minutes each. Australia had 16 per cent of the world market, which had increased to 19 per cent before EEP came in. Last year our wheat share was reduced to 13 per cent, and it is forecast to fall even further. In 1991 we produced 15 million tonnes of wheat, and production has decreased now to 9.4 million tonnes, although the drought has accounted for about 1.5 million tonnes. Does Mr Bush not realise what he is doing to Australian farmers? (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are debating here is Senator Hill's concern that he can debate in four minutes an issue that he wanted to make the Minister answer in two minutes. That is all that is under discussion. There is absolutely no controversy about the fact that Senator Hill would have had leave to speak on it.
—You'll learn. It would have been over ages ago.

—Of course it would not, you poor old thing, but do not worry. The fact of the matter is that Senator Hill had been told. He asked, and I said he would get leave, as soon as this motion was dealt with, to speak for four minutes. There would have been half an hour to debate it. Everybody could have had four minutes and there would have been no problem, as was indicated yesterday.
—Are you going to give leave for the others we want to discuss?
—Up to the limit of half an hour, yes. I said yesterday that everybody who seeks leave under the procedural motion that I proposed, if it is carried—
—How can we have half an hour to debate it when we have got three or four to do?
—I have said that everybody who seeks it will get leave. It is up to the Opposition as to how they use that time.
—You are saying that you could have a further half hour debate on it?

—Of course those opposite could; it is up to them. But there was half an hour available and those opposite chose not to wait and to proceed in this manner. What this debate is really about is to prove—and it is very kind of those opposite to do so—that we need a resolution to regulate the use of the motion to take note. If there is no such resolution, the process that currently exists will continue to be blatantly abused and misused even where we try to give an indication that, within reasonable bounds, leave will be given. There is no question of any approach from the Opposition of seeking to be cooperative about these matters. All it is trying to do is, firstly, hasten up the procedure and, secondly, use up to half an hour to speak on a matter on which it wants to restrict the Minister to only two minutes.

PARA.TAB: It really is a very tedious and repetitive exercise of abuse of the Standing Orders. But that is not surprising because what we have here is exactly what we had in the points of order raised by Senator Hill during Question Time; that is, the application of one set of standards to the Opposition and a different set of standards to other people. As I understand the standard English definition in the dictionary, when we say that a different set of standards should apply to oneself than that which should apply to other people, that is called `hypocrisy'. That is exactly what we are seeing here today, and that is why this motion ought to be defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, just by the way before I start, in response to your interjection that we will not be here tomorrow, I would like to explain to you that we will be here tomorrow—
—I said that the President will not be here tomorrow.

—The President will not be here; I stand corrected. The suspension of Standing Orders to have a full blown debate is an urgent matter. The wheat industry's present position is far more urgent than a lot of people in this chamber and many people elsewhere realise. President Bush made his initial announcement some two to two and a half weeks ago and the Australian wheat growers experienced an immediate reaction to it—but I do not think their immediate reaction was experienced in this place and it certainly did not sink into the world trade.

PARA.TAB: In the first instance, the Chicago Board of Trades price of wheat went up $5 a tonne, which was a reaction to the better treatment that the American wheat growers may receive. So, initially, that went up $5 a tonne, and a lot of people were led into the false assumption that that rise was going to have no effect. We are now two weeks down the track and we see the Americans starting to make their contracts. The first contract which was hardly mentioned was the sale of 600,000 tonnes of wheat to Egypt with the new EEP scheme; that was just over a week ago. Then, that not having been enough, they came in with this latest one to Pakistan, one of the traditional markets for Australian products including wheat.

We have the advantage in Australia of growing better quality wheat than the average wheat in America, and we have been able to hold our market share due to that fact. It seems to me that the thrust of the American system is to really bang that money in. Senator Evans himself said today that that subsidised sale to Pakistan was at $35 a tonne.

Two years ago in Australia—and Senator Walsh would know this, as he is still a wheat grower—we had a disaster of the same proportion. Two years ago at this time of the year we were looking at something like $180-odd a tonne and then, when we had the Americans working, it dropped down to $115. That was a drop of about $65 a tonne overnight which sent Australian wheat farmers to the wall. It was so important that the Lawrence Government of Western Australia—and I do not give that Government much credence for anything, but I do for that—offered a guaranteed minimum price last year so that a crop would be planted. I do not know how that Government could have delivered that, but it did. This year the Federal Government, giving the wheat industry credence, put a planting subsidy in the One Nation package.

So it is an important industry. The Federal Government has thrown money in to plant; and the Lawrence Government made the promise, although it did not put anything in. The Federal Government, having put that money in to enable plantings to be made in New South Wales, has invested in the wheat industry and now Australia has been belted over the ear. However, with the advent of President Bush's first announcement, unfortunately this Federal Government led by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did very little.

This morning I asked someone whether Mr Simon Crean is out of the country, because on this EEP announcement I never heard a noise from him. I know that he is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and not the Minister for Trade, but one would think he would have made some kind of a noise. Just by his absence, he has astounded me. He has not made one sound, whereas at least our shadow Minister for primary industry—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! You don't read the newspapers.
—Perhaps Senator McKiernan could tell me where he made a noise.
—I will send them to you.

—He never said a word on it. This is a very urgent matter because so many people are hanging on it. Last year we were able to boost the price back up from about $110, or whatever it was, to $175 because of the lack of production in Australia caused by the drought in the eastern States. This year the crop has built up, so with a greater supply the price will be more under the hammer. This urgency motion should be passed to enable us to have a full blown debate on how this Government should handle this important issue.

—This is a serious matter; there is no question about that. The disappointment is that the Opposition chooses to play games with the issue rather than confront it in a realistic and effective way of making policy. On this issue the Opposition is engaging in stunts rather than focusing on diplomacy. If there is one word that characterises the policy of the Federal Opposition on matters of trade it is `confusion'—I am tempted to say `utter confusion'. We only have to look at the record over the last couple of weeks.
—What did Tim Fischer say?
—I will come to Mr Fischer in a moment.
—Don't forget Lateline.

—I will focus on Lateline in just a moment. If we look at the contradictory, inconsistent and incoherent response of the Federal Opposition on matters of trade over the last couple of weeks, we see that, firstly, Australia is about to join the North American Free Trade Agreement, according to the National Party. There is no evaluation of that. There is no assessment of the benefits. There is absolutely no thought opposite being given to the consequences of that for Australia, particularly for Australian farmers—absolutely no thought being given to it.

PARA.TAB: Then the contradiction comes: within 24 hours the approach is made—the imperial forelock tugging occurs again—to John Major to intervene at one minute to midnight. We are approaching Britain—and I will come to the situation regarding Britain and the European Community in the 1960s in a moment.

Finally, of course, the Opposition shifts ground to attack the Japanese. We have a bout of Japan-bashing. The stupidity of that is revealed the very same day when it becomes clear to the entire Australian population that we run a massive trade surplus with the Japanese and that our diplomacy with the Government of Japan over recent years has meant a significant opening up of the Japanese market to our products. Of course, we have repudiation not from the Government, the media and the Australian community alone but from the Japanese Embassy and the Embassy of the United States of America.

That is the ultimate evaluation of the stunts in which those opposite have been engaged. Contrast that with the approach of the Government which is multilateral and which has been consistent, coherent and coordinated. That is why Canada and Argentina approached us in terms of response to President Bush's announcement. Those opposite failed dismally during the 1960s when the UK went into the common market; they failed utterly. They failed to anticipate; they failed to prepare; they then failed to respond. The interests of Australian rural communities are much better safeguarded by this Labor Government than ever they would be under a coalition Government. It is a simple matter of fact which is recognised—and that is a problem those opposite fail to confront.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to:
Question so resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed from 15 September, on motion by Senator McMullan:
