Senator Kemp—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I wish to move a motion to take note of the answer Senator Button gave in response to a question asked by Senator West.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Clerk has called on Government Business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a moment ago we had an example of what I believe is a malaise creeping into this place. I believe that there is a problem with which we are all faced. It is a case of attack and counter-attack. It is a case of persons taking actions which, to their colleagues and to the Opposition—indeed, perhaps to the whole of the chamber—are not appropriate and then a reaction setting in. The matter we have just debated concerning wheat subsidisation was of sufficiently grave importance to this whole country for a ministerial statement to be placed before this chamber. Then there could have been a proper and full debate on that statement.

PARA.TAB: The action taken is a reaction to that failure and I believe that this is what we are seeing in the motion currently before us. We are dealing with a motion by Senator McMullan to restrict the time of speakers on motions to take note of answers to questions to a period of two minutes. I believe he is going to extend that time to four minutes. Regardless of whether it is two minutes or four minutes, it is still a retaliation for the action taken by the Opposition in the chamber on Tuesday.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sensible proposal—full stop.

—Senator Coates says that it is a sensible proposal. I know Senator Coates's view about this chamber; he would like to do away with this chamber. He would like to restrict the ability, and indeed the rights, of senators to express their views on behalf of the people that elect them. He does not care about the rights of the State of Tasmania.
—I do.

—The honourable senator does not. If he did, he would uphold the rights of this chamber. As senators we have imposed on us a duty to express our views on behalf of our constituents and particularly to uphold the rights of the States and the individual rights of citizens in those States. That is what this chamber is all about. It is also all about the audit and control of executive government actions. It is a very grave thing indeed to attempt to amend Standing Orders, which are designed to protect those rights. This motion, like the one carried on Tuesday, would tend to deny those rights and deny the ability of the chamber to hear adequate answers.

PARA.TAB: Of course, we have had a problem in Question Time over the last few weeks. The problem now, however, is that punitive measures are being meted out to all as a reaction to the excesses of the few. Sitting back here, one could see what was happening. Only one or two Ministers were making an absolute welter of Question Time—debating the point and answering at length the dorothy dixers and so forth. With respect to those Ministers, I think it was quite inappropriate. On the other hand, not last week but in weeks leading up to that, points of order had been taken by the Opposition almost ad nauseam and Question Time was becoming a bit of a shemozzle.

We are now faced with these punitive measures which are going to affect the whole of the chamber and the individual rights of each senator. It will not be too bad for the Opposition and it will not be too bad for the Government. In fact, I think both the Government and the Opposition secretly would probably agree with Senator Coates that the proposal has merit on its own. That would be only a very temporary conclusion. The Government should be aware that it is setting a precedent which can be used against it if and when the Government becomes the opposition. I believe that the Opposition, for its part, should take a long, hard look again at what was done on Tuesday and at what is proposed today, even if the four minutes is conceded and even if the time limit will be 60 minutes in total.

A valid point has been made by the Opposition. That valid point is that the development of the practice of taking note from time to time of Ministers' answers is probably better than proposing MPIs. I have no means of telling whether the total time used for taking note of answers has exceeded or been less than the time that would have been taken on MPIs forgone. The reason for that, of course, is that I do not know what was in the minds of those in the Opposition as to whether they intended to put in certain MPIs on certain days and instead of that have decided to take note of certain answers. I suppose that the situation we would have under the proposal put forward by the Government and the amendment put forward by the Opposition will not worry them too much, because the Opposition has 33 senators and the Government has 31. If they all take their two or four minutes, whatever it will be, they will cover the subject quite comprehensively.

But this also comes down to the question of what this proposal will do for the rights, responsibilities and duties of Independent senators and senators from the smaller parties. I think this time limit will substantially reduce and interfere with the rights of those senators. From memory, I have utilised the option of seeking leave to move to take note of an answer by a Minister only once. I believe that was reasonable and I believe it was effective because it got the point over and the point was ultimately responded to by the Minister.

These particular proposals will not allow me as an individual senator to exercise that right in the same fashion as would be available to members of the Government and members of the Opposition, because they can have a whole team of people to carry on the argument over the period set for taking note of Ministers' answers. I believe that people should consider that matter when they are addressing this question and when they are voting upon this question. Who knows? From time to time people do make a decision to stand as Independents or indeed to be here as Independents.
I do not think there would be any problem at all in relation to Question Time if the rules for questions in the Standing Orders were observed. Let us look at them. Standing order 73 states:
(1) The following rules shall apply to questions:

SPEECH.PARA: questions shall not contain:

PARA.TAB: (a)statements of fact or names of persons unless they are strictly necessary to render the question intelligible and can be authenticated;
(b)arguments;
(c)inferences;
(d)imputations;
(e)epithets;
(f)ironical expressions; or
(g)hypothetical matter;

SPEECH.PARA: questions shall not ask:

PARA.TAB: (h)for an expression of opinion;
(i)for a statement of the Government's policy;—

SPEECH.PARA: listen to the dorothy dixers—
or

PARA.TAB: (j)for a legal opinion;

SPEECH.PARA: questions shall not refer to:

PARA.TAB: (k)debates in the current session; or
(l)proceedings in committee not reported to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Questions shall not anticipate discussion upon an order of the day or other matter which appears on the Notice Paper.
(3)The President may direct that the language of a question be changed if it is not in conformity with the standing orders.
(4)In answering a question, a Senator shall not debate it.

If those rules were all complied with I suppose there would be no problem; there probably would be no Question Time either, if the truth is known. As Chairman of the parliamentary fellowship committee it would not be a bad idea to advertise for a researcher to do a bit of research on Question Time in the Senate to see how far these particular rules are observed.

PARA.TAB: The questions arising out of this matter are quite serious. We have only two days left in this week. All I did yesterday was try to delay this matter for another day in the hope that it would be given mature consideration and in the hope that the sort of childish reaction which is taking place in this chamber would be circumvented and that precedents would not be established. If we carry this motion—even though it would apply only to the end of this sitting week—people are going to point to it in times to come and say, `Well, it was done there. This is one way of overcoming the situation'. I suggest that what we need to do now is to put it aside for another couple of days and then sit down and have a look at it. Perhaps some people need to be talked to and we need to see whether commonsense can prevail.

I say to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) who is at the table that the ultimate sanction comes from within the parties. The ultimate sanction so far as the Government is concerned is that it can deny leave for a senator to move a motion to take note of an answer. There are the contingent notices of motion which can be utilised by certain senators. If the situation gets too out of hand, it is then for the colleagues of the offenders to say that enough is enough and that, if they continue to make a welter of it, the result will be a restriction of the rights of senators. That will ultimately backfire on those who are making a welter of it. In that respect, I include the couple of Ministers who have been extending their answers, which gave rise to the action taken by the Opposition on Monday, which in turn gave rise to the reaction that is taking place today.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a supporter of the time limit for Question Time, which I remind honourable senators is on a trial basis only, I feel some responsibility for the reaction that has occurred to that proposal. I oppose strongly putting a time limit of any kind on the freedom of debate which offers us the opportunity to take note of the answer of a Minister. The implications of a time limit are very different within Question Time compared with outside Question Time and there are very different consequences.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the time limit in Question Time is to maximise the number of questions asked and to increase the number of senators who are able to participate; it is not to gag Ministers. If it is felt that two minutes is too short a time to allow Ministers to properly answer questions, then this time should be increased or the time limit should be abolished. However, the time limit for taking note of Ministers' answers has very different implications. It really has three undesirable effects.

Firstly, it may gag a senator from entering into a dialogue or a debate on a matter of importance. Secondly, it may well force a practice of routinely taking note in such a way that it can be overused by always exercising that option for 30 minutes or, worse, for 60 minutes after Question Time and irrevocably change the practice of this chamber in a way we have not really thought through.

Thirdly, and most importantly to senators like me, but also to all of us, it reduces each person's time to two minutes or four minutes which penalises individual senators. It also means that one party could monopolise almost all of the time if its members organised themselves effectively. In my view it is the way in which the time limit was introduced into this chamber that has led to the problems which we are now facing.

By using a contingency motion and immediate introduction rather than a notice of motion which allows all senators to give it consideration and to prepare for its effect on their participation in Question Time, we have seen a backlash occur. The backlash has occurred because senators and Ministers were unprepared to suddenly become concise either in questions or answers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surprise attack.

—Yes, but I believe it led to some very undesirable consequences. I suggest that those honourable senators who had questions and did not realise they had to compress them into one minute then felt they had a lot more to say that had not been said and so they took note of the answers. I also think Ministers who were unprepared to suddenly compress their answers to two minutes also failed to answer adequately the questions which were addressed to them. As a result of that we are facing difficulties. However, I suggest that the whole trial period of time limits for Question Time be allowed to run its course before considering further limitations that are resulting from this backlash. If we as the Senate wish to rise out of the gamesmanship and if we really want to evaluate the value of a time limit for Question Time, or for the period after it, we should not confuse the two by beginning the second change before completing the time period for the first. I therefore oppose this motion on two grounds. Firstly, it should not be introduced until after the results of the trial period for the time limit on Question Time has been settled. Secondly, I will vote against it on the ground that it is an undemocratic procedure which gags honourable senators who wish to draw attention to matters of importance and engage in dialogue with Ministers rather than simply make a short speech for two or four minutes.

—I rise simply to urge honourable senators to consider very seriously the matters that Senator Harradine raised in his speech. Senator Harradine has been here for quite some time and he understands the way this House operates. Serious consideration should be given to the matters raised by Senator Harradine. I do not say I agree with all the matters he raised but what he said should be given some serious consideration.

PARA.TAB: I do agree with Senator Harradine that if the Standing Orders were followed many of the problems we have run into and which we have had to take this action over would not have occurred. Senator Harradine raised standing order 73 (i) which says that questions shall not ask for a statement of government policy. On a number of occasions I have raised this with the President by way of point of order and I have been almost contemptuously dismissed with the comment that if we did that we would stop Question Time.

Question Time is not about expressions of Government policy. If matters of Government policy are to be raised that should be done, in accordance with the Standing Orders, by way of ministerial statement and the matter should be properly debated. As I understood it, the purpose of Question Time was to obtain facts from the Government about the Government's administration of this country and it was not there to give the Government a free kick on every occasion to make a policy speech on what the Government is all about.

If the President's view is correct and he enforced that rule, there would be no Question Time. If that is what the President thinks and if that is what the rest of honourable senators think, then we should get rid of that standing order. In my view, the standing order is quite clear. What the President and everybody else does here during Question Time is say, `Yes, I understand what the standing order says, but I don't believe it means what it says' when the words are quite obvious. So we continue to completely ignore and run contrary to the Standing Orders. If that is what we want to do, and that is a matter for everyone to decide, we should remove that standing order.It seems quite ridiculous to me that this major chamber of legislation making in this country should make rules and then not abide by them. We make rules and we expect everybody else in Australia to abide by them on pain of penalty if they refuse, yet we make our own rules and completely ignore them.

I raised a matter with Senator McMullan by leave at the conclusion of the debate yesterday, but I want to raise a further matter briefly. If the procedure of taking note of answers is confined to half an hour, how will the President determine who is to get the call from all the honourable senators wishing to take note of answers? I suppose, for those in the Liberal and National parties, that is something for us to organise amongst ourselves and the President should have an easy job there. If what has happened in the past follows, whoever gets the call will move the motion and will be followed by quite a number of speakers. Senator Chamarette's comment that it will effectively cut out herself and Senator Harradine is very valid. Does the President then make an unwritten rule that he divides up the time to allow the Democrats to do it so many times and the Independents so many times?

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope not.

—I agree with Senator Watson; I hope that he would not. It does raise those sorts of problems. I raise that point again to urge that, if we go ahead with this procedure at all, it be allowed to go for at least one hour.

PARA.TAB: I certainly think that the time restriction on questions and answers has been a very good one. It is a measure that I personally would like to see made more permanent. I recognise that there is a need to have some restriction on moving to take note of answers, but what is being proposed is not reasonable. I urge, at least for the trial period, that one hour be allowed. I suppose in some way it could be justified by saying that Question Time lasts an hour, therefore, moving to take note of answers should last for an hour. I ask that honourable senators consider those matters, particularly those raised by Senator Harradine, when considering this proposal as a more long term operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly to this motion to limit the time for debate on motions to take note of answers. I accept the discipline of the motion in its broad terms and principles—I will not argue about the finer points of whether the time limit should be four minutes, two minutes, half an hour, an hour, three-quarters of an hour, 20 minutes or whatever—because the other day we imposed discipline on those opposite and, for that, I am prepared to take discipline.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette mentioned that the motion is unfair because of its surprise element. I believe that the best attack is a surprise attack. That is where one gets the most benefit and that is how we got what we did out of the Government the other day. I take full blame for the motion moved the other day, because I was sick and tired—

TALK.START.PARA: —Credit—not blame.

—No, I take the blame. That motion was born out of frustration. We get a list of questions, and they generally come from those on the front bench. We were getting down to four questions from this side for the whole of Question Time. There was absolutely no chance for backbenchers to ask questions. As Ministers were taking 20 minutes to answer questions, there was more frustration here and more points of order were taken.This trial has disciplined Ministers to answer questions in a short time. It has definitely had an effect.
—With Labor senators asking supplementaries.

—That is right, but it has had its effect. Senator Button has been able to answer questions in that short time, using the supplementary angle, of course—those opposite retaliated with that approach. It is marvellous how much Senator Evans can tell us in two minutes, although his eyes are always looking at the clock. I believe that those two senators have taken the trial in good spirit.Senator Cook was different on the first day; he spat the dummy and put everything on notice. Senator Collins did likewise with some questions, and I know that Senator Ray put one of my questions on notice.

PARA.TAB: These Ministers have gradually come out of their shock. Today, from what I can remember, hardly one question was put on notice. The Government is accepting the measure. The motion that was moved and carried the other day with the help of the Democrats, for which I thank them, has had its effect. I believe that, when we come back, we should look at extending this trial for the rest of the year, thus having it for almost a full session. I believe that, excepting the finer points being sorted out—I will not argue about them because Senator Short is looking after them—the same rule applies to the motion that we are debating now: if we want to discipline those opposite, we should accept it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to propose an additional amendment to the four that I added yesterday.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I want to put on all fours the concept behind this motion in terms of the procedural points that apply to the time limit on questions and answers during Question Time. As I understand it, the clock stands still during the period in which points of order are taken during Question Time. I and other members of the coalition think that the same should apply to the segment on taking note of answers. Therefore, I move:

PARA.TAB: After paragraph (c), add the following paragraph:
";(d)the time taken in raising and determining any points of order during the debate under this order shall not be regarded as part of the time allowed for debate under this order".

SPEECH.PARA: That would put that situation on all fours with the situation in relation to Question Time. I have discussed this matter with the Australian Democrats Whip and I have foreshadowed it with Senator McMullan.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Senator Short, do you wish to put those conditions together or separately?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday it was agreed that each part of the motion be put separately.

—I want to sum up the debate briefly. Firstly, I seek leave to amend part (a) of my motion in the terms agreed with Senator Macdonald. For anybody looking at the wording, it is to delete the words `that day' at the end of part (a) and insert them after the word `given' in the first line of part (a).

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Paragraph (a), omit "given to questions without notice that day", substitute "given that day to questions without notice".

The import of that, for anyone who wants to follow it, is that if a Minister were to give an answer on a day to a question asked the previous day, it would still be capable of being taken note of. The day on which the answer is given is the trigger rather than the day on which the question is asked. It is a different concept from Senator Short's amendment, but it covers the point that Senator Macdonald raised yesterday and about which I undertook to come up with an amendment.

Whatever happens to the rest of the motion, I will accept the amendment which Senator Short has proposed today. I am quite happy for the people raising points of order not to be part of the time limit. It makes the management of it a bit more difficult, but it does mean that points of order are taken out as a time wasting tactic in these situations. I am happy to accept that part, but I do not accept any of his other amendments for the reasons we discussed before; I will not be repetitive.

I accept—it may not be universal on the front bench and that may be because I am the only one here who does not get to answer questions—that there was a problem with the way Question Time was operating in this place. I do not argue that. I think the proposal we have to regulate it will not last as the proposal, but I am not averse to making Question Time work better. It is easy for me to have the luxury of doing that; I am the only one who does not have to deal with the consequences but, nevertheless, I accept that. I think most people would also accept that the procedural motion to take note of an answer, which I accept is a legitimate procedure, was being abused, and something needs to be done to regulate that.

I think the proposal we have, particularly Senator Short's part (d), has some symmetry with the regulation of Question Time. I am happy to enter into some discussion on a long term basis about how we should regulate both, and perhaps other parts of Standing Orders, to balance the rights of senators to use all the mechanisms available to them under the Standing Orders and constrain their capacity to abuse those rights. I am happy to apply that balance of principles to Question Time. I do not think we have it right, but I am happy to address the principle. I am happy to apply it here and to address it at greater length.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about an hour instead of half an hour?

—If it is going to apply for only one day, I am prepared for the next fortnight, after both these procedures expire, to have some discussions about what the long term arrangements might be, both for Question Time and motions to take note. That is something we can talk about before we resume in a fortnight's time.

—I seek a point of clarification in relation to Senator McMullan's proposal. I understand that in condition (a) he wants to transpose the words `that day' and put them in after the word `given'. Senator McMullan would be aware of the amendment I made to (a) yesterday, which is in the Notice Paper today, to add at the end of condition (a), the words `or the previous day'. Is he suggesting that they—
—I am opposing that.
—You are opposing that?
—Yes, I think this meets a substantial part of your problem, but I would not go as far as your proposal. I do not want to debate it any further. I am saying I do not accept that.

—I am not quite clear on that. That is quite a different proposition. Senator McMullan's proposal would now mean, would it not, that if an answer were given yesterday, more information or more consideration of it to fully absorb that answer may be given in the ensuing 24 hours. So Senator McMullan's change would not allow that answer to be taken note of the following day.
—It never did.
—No, I know it did not.
—It still doesn't.
—I thought that Senator McMullan had indicated agreement with the concept.

—Senator Macdonald made a different point, which I thought was a valid point and I acknowledge it. But it is not yours. I am not pretending that I accepted yours; I did not. I accepted Senator Macdonald's. It is not unrelated, but is different and more limited.
—They have to be put to the vote, do they not.
—Yes, that is correct.
—Order! I intend to put the amendments separately. The question is that the first amendment moved by Senator Short be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is that the second amendment moved by Senator Short be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is that the third amendment be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is that the fourth amendment be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the fifth amendment be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the motion, as amended, be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion, as amended, be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister representing the Treasurer (Senator Button) in response to questions without notice asked by Senator West and Senator Michael Baume on 16 September 1992 relating to fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Colleagues will recall that one of the issues that was raised in relation to this question was the extension of fringe benefits tax to bodies in the public sector which have been largely exempt from the payment of this tax. I would like to know whether a fringe benefits tax would be paid in respect of the butler employed in Mr Keating's office. We have learnt in recent weeks that, unlike any other Prime Minister in the 92 years of Federation, Mr Keating actually has a butler employed in his office. We have heard that Mr Keating is a very wealthy man. There is no doubt about that.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the answers that were given by Senator Button during Question Time, the issue that is before this chamber now is who will pay the FBT for Mr Keating's butler-valet in his Parliament House office? Senator Button tried to pretend today that this tax is not actually aimed at State governments in the sense that State governments would have to pay further taxes. I think that is quite wrong and the debate, as it proceeds in the next few weeks, will show that to be wrong.

We have not heard how much Mr Keating's butler is paid. I have put a question on notice so that we can determine the salary that is paid to Mr Keating's butler. We want to know whether the Government is fair dinkum about applying the FBT across the board. Will Mr Keating's butler, as distinct from any other butlers that wealthy people in this country may have—the butler that Sir Peter Abeles may have, the butler that Mr Chris Skase may have had or the butler that Mr Laurie Connell may have had—be subject to the FBT? Under the old tax regime, these people presumably would have had to pay the FBT on those services.

So the question before this chamber is to what extent, if any, FBT is paid on the butler employed in Mr Keating's office. I think this is a big issue. It is an issue on which undoubtedly the community will focus its attention. This will be the symbol of how fair dinkum Senator Button is, how fair dinkum Mr Dawkins is and how fair dinkum Mr Keating is in constructing a tax system which is fair and equitable between all members of the community.

Will Mr Keating's butler in Parliament House be exempt from the FBT? Will his second butler in the Lodge be exempt from the FBT? I note that Senator McMullan is very keen to get to his feet. We would certainly appreciate a very clear answer from him. The community will be demanding answers to that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Kemp's assumption was right, the question might be interesting. But his assumption is wrong. The same person who provides assistance to the Cabinet Office for this Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is exactly the same person who did it for Bob Hawke. There is no new position; there is no new person. It is exactly the same person as has done it for all the Prime Ministers that I can recall. Nothing has changed. There is no new person; there is no new position; there is no new title.
—New uniform?

—As I understand it, he asked the Prime Minister. He said, `What would you like me to wear?'. The Prime Minister said, `Wear what you like'—and he does. There was no decision by the Prime Minister as to what he should wear. I asked him why he wore those clothes and he said, `I asked the Prime Minister what I should wear and he said "Wear what you like"'. Therefore he does.
—What does he wear?

—He wears what he likes. He does an excellent job. He works very hard. Nothing has changed with the change of prime ministership. Not only is the position the same and the conditions the same; the person is the same. He is the same individual who did it previously.
—And the Lodge? Who pays FBT for the butler at the Lodge?

—I do not know that one pays FBT on people who are paid wages. I do not know the employment arrangement for the Lodge. I know who was there when the former Prime Minister was at the Lodge. When I visited the Lodge with the present Prime Minister I did not meet such a person. One may be there during the hours that I am not present.
—Is it a fringe benefit?
—If it is, then fringe benefits tax will be paid on it. It is quite straightforward.
—But who will pay it—Mr Keating or the taxpayer?

—It will be paid in exactly the same way as everyone else, including Senator Kemp, who is paid by the taxpayers. Everybody else in this chamber and every other person who is paid by the taxpayer has his fringe benefits tax, if there is any, paid in exactly the same way. I doubt that it constitutes a fringe benefit in terms of the Act. But if it does then fringe benefits tax will be paid in terms of the Act. It is quite straightforward.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp will be given a proper answer to the question on notice which he asked during an Estimates committee meeting last night. The answer to the question that he asked today would be interesting if his assumption was right, but his assumption is wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is very interesting today to ask Senator McMullan to tell me how Mr Goss is going to get all the additional money that he will need to pay in fringe benefits tax in respect of all employees of the Queensland Government and its instrumentalities and authorities who receive a fringe benefit as part of their salary package. The fringe benefits tax will now be payable in increased amounts. We wonder where the Queensland Government is going to get that money from to pay that additional tax. Similarly, a lot of local authorities—and this is of interest to me—pay fringe benefits taxes. I understanding from the statement made today by the Government that fringe benefits taxes will bear increasingly on local authorities as well.

PARA.TAB: It would be very interesting to hear Mr Goss say whether he stands by the promise he supposedly made, or did make but did not keep before the last election, that he was not going to increase taxes. If he is not going to increase taxes, where is he going to get the money from to pay this increased incidence of FBT on instrumentalities, hospitals and so on? I would like to know. I would like to know the answer within the next couple of days.

The Queensland Budget is not a Budget. It was introduced; it is just a jumble of words. It was never debated or passed. But that Budget went along a certain line and certain money has been allocated for certain things. Yet we have a situation where now the Commonwealth is imposing an additional tax on the Queensland Government. Where is the Queensland Government going to get that money from? Is it going to cut back on services? Will it perhaps add a little more to the cigarette tax that it brought in the day after the Budget was presented. It brought in the so-called Budget one day. The next day—the first day of the campaign—it introduced a new tax on cigarettes. Maybe the cost of cigarettes will have to go up yet again to help pay for the fringe benefits tax that this Government has imposed upon the Queensland Government.

I call upon the smokers of Queensland to consider very seriously where Mr Goss is going to get this extra money from. Cigarette smokers are an easy target. Mr Goss has already proved that. If he has a shortfall in his Budget, he will not be worried about adding to the tax that he has already put on smokers. He will get the money by increasing the tax on cigarettes. Maybe he will consider a fuel tax. This is something that we have never had in Queensland before.

If this Government keeps imposing taxes on State governments and instrumentalities—instrumentalities which the State Government has to fund—and local authorities, which are funded in part by the State, in part by their own resources and in part by the Federal Government, then they all have to find the additional revenue to meet the additional taxes imposed by this Government. It is vital that the voters of Queensland know before Saturday just where Mr Goss will get this extra money from. What additional tax will he put on them? Will it be on cigarettes? Will it be on fuel? Will it be on stamp duty? Where are these additional taxes coming from? The people of Queensland deserve that answer before Saturday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter was raised by Senator Kemp concerning the perks of office given to Mr Keating because of an article published in the Sydney Morning Herald on 21 August 1992. It became pertinent because of the announcement today that there is to be an increase in the FBT, which will fall again upon business and restrict the ability of business to create new employment. Also, there is the impost that Senator Macdonald has outlined which will affect the people of Queensland and Victoria, in particular, who are going to their elections, and Australians in other States because of the clawing back effect that this will have on finance assistance grants.

PARA.TAB: The reason that Senator Kemp drew attention to the special fringe benefit given to the Prime Minister—that is, the services of a butler cum valet, not only in the Lodge, where one could see that that would be reasonable, but also in his parliamentary office—is that it is quite legitimate to argue that this is a fringe benefit of office bestowed on Mr Keating and a special privilege given to him.

I will read the description which leads to that conclusion. Senator McMullan can argue all he likes that this is not a special privilege on which FBT ought to be paid. We have already established in this place that there seems to be one relationship and one rule between Mr Boucher and Mr Keating, and quite another rule between Mr Boucher and everybody else. This is the special perk of office that comes with Mr Keating's butler. Mr Peter Hartcher writes:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister has a butler in his Parliament House office. His name is Guy. He is, by all accounts, a diligent and hard-working fellow who takes his job seriously, right down to the grey striped trousers and the resolute refusal to allow anyone. . . inside the Prime Minister's inner office in Keating's absence.
His employer summons him into the presence by means of a small hand-held remote-control device like a TV channel-changer.
Or a dog whistle, I suppose. The article continues:
When the Prime Minister is away from Canberra, he keeps himself busy making cakes for the 35 other office staff.

Guy is a careful, proper and fastidious little man and, for some perverse reason, the Prime Minister apparently enjoys shocking him. And so it was recently, as Keating returned to his office after holding court at a press conference.
Guy, waiting deferentially by the prime ministerial door—
I do not know whether that is the new door we have opened up in his office at the cost of some $5,000—
to welcome his returning employer, took the liberty of telling Keating that he had handled the press conference—which Guy evidently had watched on the in-house TV—extremely well.
Keating paused: `Thanks. I'm a professional. A professional c—-.' It had the desired effect.
Charming language; charming treatment of a man who is presumably trying to carry out a job in a diligent manner.

PARA.TAB: The point that is being made, though, is that one can reasonably argue that it is not necessary for the purposes of running a ministerial office in this Parliament House to have a personal butler cum valet. I can understand that perhaps he has to lay out the expensive Zegna suits on which no sales tax is presently paid. DEBATE.TITLE: WHEAT SALES BY USA TO PAKISTAN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Boswell on 16 September relating to the effect of United States wheat subsidies on the Australian wheat industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to address the totally inadequate response that the Government has provided to this action by the United States. I believe the Minister's answer did not disclose any action that the Government was foreshadowing which would have any more effect than the action that has been taken so far.

PARA.TAB: The Government on numerous occasions has said that it deplores the action and that it feels that the United States should not have done it, in the face of the action of the United States right now, today, announcing that it has, in fact, made a sale of wheat to Pakistan, a nation that is not in the traditional market of the European Community which the United States says is the market to which that particular EEP increase is directed.

Pakistan is very much in the area of the Australian wheat market and is being targeted by Australian wheat farmers. It is one of our traditional markets. The United States sale will do incalculable damage to Australian wheat farmers, yet the Australian Government cannot provide any action except to say that it deplores this action and that it will appeal to the United States to mend its ways.

I regret to say that the Opposition is taking the same view. It also is shedding crocodile tears and saying that the United States should not do that, but that action is all that it is prepared to support. Neither of the parties was prepared to support my notice of motion which called on the Government to tell the United States that we can no longer regard it as a friend if it is going to do that particular damage to our wheat farmers; that we must protect our wheat farmers; and that we will issue a notice to quit on the bases that the United States still maintains on Australian soil. Also, we should be telling the United States that we will look with a somewhat more jaundiced eye at the arrangements it is seeking with Australia for its air routes.

The question is: are we prepared to continue to be a doormat, or are we prepared to tell the United States that it is no longer our friend if it, intentionally and with full knowledge, goes into our markets and damages our wheat farmers despite its protestations that it is still our ally and friend?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Coates, I present the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on annual reports tabled from January 1992 to June 1992.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports of the Committee: No. 5, Christmas Island Rebuilding Program and No. 6, Refurbishment of the Reserve Bank of Australia Perth. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the reports.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The reports I have tabled are the Committee's fifth and sixth reports for 1992. The fifth report relates to the Christmas Island rebuilding program, which was one of the most interesting inquiries the Committee has undertaken for some time. The aim of this project is to align conditions on Christmas Island with mainland Australian standards as part of a broader government policy aimed at the integration of Australia's Indian Ocean Territories within Australia. The need for major upgrading of the infrastructure on Christmas Island has been given impetus by the introduction of mainland Australian laws from 1 July 1992.

PARA.TAB: The rebuilding program will provide substantial new infrastructure for the island at a cost of $132.85m. At the time of the public hearings in May 1992 the Government had committed $37m for the next five years subject to the endorsement of the Committee. The most urgent works include a new and upgraded sewerage system and water supply, a new hospital, a new police station, extensions to the school, andupgraded housing. Funding of the remainder of the works in the rebuilding program will be considered by the Government following the Committee's report.

The existing infrastructure on Christmas Island was designed and built to meet the requirements and standards of a mining operation. Significant elements predate the Second World War. A period of renewed construction began after the war but by the mid-1970s construction activity had tailed off.

With the decline in mining profitability and the uncertain future of the island in the 1980s, there was little incentive to invest in maintenance of the island's infrastructure. The Committee was shocked, when it carried out inspections prior to the public hearings, to observe the appalling state of most of the infrastructure for the provision of government services on Christmas Island. In particular, the Committee was struck with the incredibly run-down condition of the hospital and the completely inadequate sewerage and water supply systems. In summary, most of the current infrastructure is more than 30 years old, in poor condition and does not meet current Australian building, health and safety standards. Western Australian Government agencies, which will provide most government services on behalf of the Commonwealth, have made it clear that existing conditions are completely unacceptable for their operations and staff.

At the public hearing on Christmas Island, and having had the benefit of a thorough inspection of the existing infrastructure, it became obvious to the Committee that the $37m committed by the Government did not include all essential items. Those not included were: clearing of aggregate plant from the hospital site; power and water supply to the hospital site; new crane; and wharf and jetty upgrading.

The result of this situation is that while the hospital could be built, there were no funds to provide power and water supply. Even more serious was the situation regarding the port infrastructure which is completely inadequate to handle the increased volume of freight which will result from the rebuilding program. It is vital that the port infrastructure be upgraded as part of the initial funding program.

On behalf of the Committee, the Chairman wrote to the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Ms Fatin) on 4 June 1992 indicating that in the Committee's view the priorities determined by the Government for inclusion in the initial $37m funding program did not include all essential items. The Committee suggested that the Government should consider increasing the amount committed over the first five years.

The Committee is pleased to note that, following Budget considerations, the amount committed has now been increased to $42m to provide for additional items of critical importance including wharf improvements and a new wharf crane.

The Committee recognises that the Government's commitment to rectify the immediate infrastructure, health and safety issues may stimulate private investment on the island and it has recommended that prior to the final commitment to the total 10-year rebuilding program there should be an assessment of the success of the initial funding program which may lead to changes in priorities and/or funding levels.

The Committee has made a number of detailed recommendations in the report for consideration by the Government and I will briefly mention a number of them. Heritage aspects have been given due regard and protection. However, the Committee has recommended that the fuel tank containing the Second World War strafing marks should be demolished with the panels containing the strafing marks being removed and displayed in a suitable location, at a cost of some $40,000.

The Committee also believes that Christmas Island is an ideal location for a demonstration project to test the feasibility of alternative energy systems to augment existing conventional power generation systems in isolated communities. The Committee has recommended that DASET commence the collection of the necessary solar and wind data and set up a pilot plant to assess the feasibility of the chosen alternative energy system. DASET should include in the rebuilding program the sealing of the roads from the airport turn-off to Waterfall and from the golf course to Waterfall at a cost of $1.2m. These roads will soon become the busiest on the island and should be sealed.

The rebuilding program will provide an opportunity to implement training programs for local workers. The Committee has recommended that as a matter of urgency a scheme be set up to maximise training and apprenticeships. The Committee has also recommended that DASET should ensure the maximum possible use of local labour and materials in the rebuilding program.

The Committee has recommended that a comprehensive strategy be developed to address the critical housing situation on the island. While funds are provided in the rebuilding program to upgrade housing for government employees, the Committee has recommended that the Government consider additional funding of some $16m to meet the Commonwealth's wider housing obligations on Christmas Island. Housing is an issue of considerable concern on the island and the Committee hopes the Government will give favourable consideration to extending the scope of the rebuilding program to address the overall housing problems, not just those of its employees.

The Committee's sixth report relates to the refurbishing of the Perth branch of the Reserve Bank of Australia at a cost of $32.2m. The Reserve Bank has operated from its current premises in Perth since 1973 and the building no longer complies with current building regulations and some services are nearing the end of their operational life. The removal of fire retardant asbestos material is an important aspect of the work. If I remember correctly, it accounts for $11m of it.

The Committee is satisfied that the refurbishment option is the most economical of the options available to the Bank. The refurbishment will proceed on a staged basis which will enable an assessment of the availability of tenants and market conditions in Perth before proceeding with the fit-out of tenanted floors. I commend the reports to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I am somewhat out of breath, it is because I have been attending the meeting with the United States Ambassador and the visiting officials. We were engaged in a fairly vigorous discussion on the fact that Australia wants President Bush to honour his undertaking that the export enhancement program he has announced will not adversely affect Australian markets.
—Did you use a Senate committee room just to get in the mood?

—It was in a Senate committee room. It was a fairly vigorous discussion and it is still going on. But I was in continuum on the Swimming Pools Tax Refund Bill 1992. Before lunch I had just made the point that we are seeing one of the most dishonourable acts that we have ever seen in this Parliament. We have seen an agreement entered into between the Swimming Pools and Spas Association and the Australian Taxation Office in the following terms. The agreement states:

SPEECH.PARA: Pending a decision on its High Court challenge to the constitutionality of sales tax on pools constructed in situ, the SPASA entered into an agreement with the Australian Tax Office to continue to pay the 20 per cent sales tax on the basis that if the challenge was successful the sales tax would be refunded to its members, i.e. the pool builders.

That was acted on in good faith by the builders who were parties to the agreement. It was not acted on in good faith by the Tax Office. In the course of the Public Accounts Committee investigation into the Australian Tax Office, we have for the first time seen the Commissioner, senior officers and the Tax Office as a whole accountable. It is not an experience that they are used to or seem to enjoy. Indeed, I have pointed out very strongly that we have evidence on the public record that the Tax Office and the Tax Commissioner have given special treatment to the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and that that special treatment was given to Mr Keating when he was the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't you read last Thursday's Financial Review? You are a disgrace to the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! Senator Walsh.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would say to Senator Walsh and his interjections that I dealt with both him and that letter in fairly good detail and if he had bothered to remain in the chamber he would know that. Please read the Hansard.

PARA.TAB: We have demonstrated that favourable treatment has been given by the Australian Tax Office and the Tax Commissioner to Mr Keating in that he was written a letter saying, `Please, Mr Keating, would you mind awfully getting your tax return in?'. This letter has been tabled in the Parliament. It is on the public record and when I asked tax officials at the supplementary Estimates hearings earlier this year how many ordinary Australians who were in a similar situation of having failed to put in two tax returns—this was the case with Mr Keating—or even one tax return, I was told by the Tax Office that nearly 10,800 ordinary Australian taxpayers were prosecuted for that offence.

We have evidence on the public record of favourable treatment being meted out to Mr Keating above and beyond nearly 10,800 ordinary Australians. I then compared that with the case of Mr Phillip Smiles and I dealt very succinctly with the reasons for making that comparison.
Mr Boucher came to that inquiry and twice said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our integrity—
meaning that of the Tax Office—
is a cherished virtue.
He further said:
In my opening statement, I was not resorting to hyperbole when I said that our integrity is a cherished virtue.
I said that that rang with all the veracity of Brutus in his burial speech of Julius Caesar when he said, `As Caesar loved me I wept for him, but he was ambitious so I slew him'.

PARA.TAB: One could say that for the Commissioner to say that integrity is the most important thing to him does not sit well with his action to renege on an agreement into which he had entered. Ask yourself about the motivation. Why did he do it?

Mr Boucher has also been very strong on saying how he acts in a way that is not politically influenced. Yet he must have known of the legal opinions which the swimming pool builders had which showed that they would win that argument. It makes one question the sort of legal advice he received and what quality he put upon it. And, I dare say, there must have been a political backup that said, `Even if you lose, we will bring in legislation'.

In my book that is political influence of the worst sort, and we see it all here today. First of all, we see the Bill introduced. It purports to be a two-page, simple, nothing Bill. What do we get today? We get the amendments—pages of them—and pages and pages of explanatory memorandum. None of it fixes up the inequity that has been done. None of it rights the wrong of the Tax Office which purports to hold itself out as being fair minded and as exercising justice.

The statement that Mr Dawkins put down today and the accompanying documentation included, among other things, a submission from the Taxation Office telling how, with good hard work and diligence, it can up the compliance rate. Up the compliance rate? What about its own compliance rate, its own compliance with an agreement it entered into? The submission then goes on, in a rather fatuous way, to say that it would get a better tax return rate, more money out of taxpayers, if taxpayers kept better records.

Mr Boucher had better go and read the Auditor-General's report which castigated him for his bad record keeping. I read on to see that Mr Boucher reckons he can get more money out of the ordinary taxpayer if he is allowed to spend some more money on information technology. He has already spent $1.2 billion. What is the result of that? We have a special, nice little cosy agreement between the Taxation Commissioner and the Public Sector Union. It is a lovely little document whereby the trade union is given, at taxpayers' expense, things like an office in every branch, a desk, a lockable filing cabinet and a telephone with no bar on it.

In addition to that, if any officer of the Tax Office actually spends all day, every day, on trade union business, that person is not allowed to be reprimanded and we, the taxpayers, have to find another officer to fill that position. I have sent that document to the Department of Finance to be costed, and I have in my mind a reasonable estimate of what that cost is going to be. Do those opposite think that the ordinary Australian taxpayer is going to be very impressed when told that, on the one hand, the Taxation Commissioner gives his money away to the trade unions and, on the other hand, that he reneges on a perfectly legitimate agreement that he has entered into with legitimate taxpayers?

I have said before that the Tax Commissioner's reputation has not really changed much since biblical times. He has not enjoyed a good press. When he does this sort of thing there is no reason why he should. We will take a serious look at the situation whereby almost one thousand people who were employed on the collection of revenue are now surplus to that requirement because of the $1.2 billion expenditure on information technology. Guess where they are now being employed? Under the PSU agreement nobody is allowed to be sacked. People are not even allowed, against their will, to be moved to a different CBD. Those people, for the most part, have gone into PR—at the taxpayers' expense to try to make the ordinary Australian citizen have some respect or liking for what goes on in that Tax Office.

We need a Tax Office that can be trusted. We need a Tax Office that can be respected. How on earth can we have any sense of justice or any sense of equity in the minds of ordinary Australians when there is special treatment for the Prime Minister and when the Tax Office, in a blatant form, reneges on a perfectly legitimate agreement? We have a very serious problem which we have to deal with. It is a crisis of confidence. For the Tax Commissioner on this occasion to argue that there was no political interference will not wash. Senator Watson has just come into the chamber. He brought down a minority report dealing with the referral of this Bill. I can only say that he—together with other coalition senators—expresses it in a very succinct manner, saying that the behaviour of the Tax Office is nothing short of a disgrace.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I would like to bring into this chamber some of the correspondence I have received from ordinary Australian citizens saying how the might of the bureaucracy has been brought down on their heads and how they have been treated and abused. They are simple letters; there are no grandiose statements; there is no might to go off to the courts and fight the Tax Commissioner. They have no option but to pay up. When one reads of their plight and sees the sorts of people they are—from simple pensioners to people who are struggling to stay in business and employ a few people—one wonders just what the sense of justice and equity in our tax system is all about.

The Opposition is addressing the question of justice and equity. Our tax reform proposals provide a plan that will allow justice and equity to come back into the system. But this Government is besotted. Because in 1985 the trade union movement denied it the right to introduce a broad based goods and services tax, we are stuck with this unfair, ramshackle system of wholesale sales tax which has so many anomalies and such a bias against certain parts of the economy that any people who have the temerity to stand up and justify it ought to hang their heads in shame. Mr Boucher may well cry out in hearings and say, `Our integrity is our most cherished virtue', but he must pardon the Australian people when they say, `Your words ring very hollow'.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will confine most of my remarks to the Swimming Pools Tax Refund Bill 1992 but I want briefly to refer to the concluding remarks of Senator Bishop. The recently published opinion poll of public confidence in the Tax Office clearly indicates that it ranks significantly ahead of many Australian institutions, including parliamentarians and including Senator Bishop—and for very good reason in that it does an excellent job and it does a difficult job very well—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. If Senator McMullan was trying to say that he had conducted a poll on me, I would like him either to produce the poll or else withdraw his remark.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—What is the point of order?

TALK.START.PARA: —The point of order is that he has made a reflection upon me. I would like him to withdraw it.

—Senator McMullan, a remark was made with regard to Senator Bishop in particular and I understand that you were referring to a poll that was about politicians in general. As the remark has been offensive to Senator Bishop, I ask you to withdraw it.
—Obviously I will withdraw it to facilitate the smooth flow of Parliament, but it is a very absurd proposition—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would like that withdrawal to be unconditional.

—I would like to speak to this point of order. This is absolutely monstrous. There is absolutely nothing unparliamentary about saying someone is unpopular. This is debasing the whole concept of what it is that constitutes unparliamentary language. We have had an interesting discussion about this matter in the past. I am not one who takes a very narrow view. I do not really care. If people can say something in public, I am happy for them to say it to me here. If they can say it in the street, they should be able to say it in Parliament. But to say that one cannot say that someone is unpopular is reducing it to an absurdity and I will not withdraw it.
—I have a further point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President.

—Order! There are no further points of order. I have heard the two points of order and I only say that, for the reasons I set out, I asked Senator McMullan to withdraw and he did withdraw. It was further to that that Senator Bishop said that he should be asked to withdraw unreservedly. All I have done is ask Senator McMullan to withdraw and I have heard him say that he withdraws. I call Senator McMullan to get on with the business which is in front of the Senate.

—Thank you. I will not take long on the Bill. This is a very important Bill and, for most people, a Bill that has required a lot of consideration because significant principles are in conflict. Most of the participants in this debate and the members of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration—the only Committee member present in the chamber is Senator Watson—and those who attended the Committee hearings spent a lot of time grappling with the difficult balance of principles involved; it was not easy.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this Bill is to establish a refund code to deal with the refunds flowing from the Mutual Pools decision and to ensure that the amounts that will be paid by the Commonwealth get to those who actually bore the `tax'—I use that word in the same sense as Senator Short; we all know that literally this is no longer a tax, but one cannot speak in inverted commas so, like everyone else, I will continue to use that word. It has not been easy to strike the right balance, because an important question was established before the courts about the rights of people that should not lightly be dealt with by the Parliament.

In the time since the Bill went to the House of Representatives, the Government has received a number of representations, including those which flowed from the Committee discussions. Amendments have been circulated. I will not waste the time of the Senate talking about them because we will have the committee stage to consider them. The reason I refer to them now is to demonstrate that the Government's approach with regard to this legislation is specifically directed towards achieving the purpose of ensuring that those who bore the burden imposed by the legislation get every possible opportunity to obtain a refund.

When thinking about support or otherwise for this legislation, one has to think about what happens if the legislation is not passed. It is true that it is important to consider the consequences of passing this legislation—and there are serious questions of principle at hand—but let us look at what happens if we do not pass this legislation.

If the Senate does not pass this Bill or a Bill to achieve this purpose—that is, to establish a just refund code—the consequences will be that those pool purchasers who actually bore tax will get nothing and those pool builders who were able to charge the cost to the purchaser will receive windfall gains of tens of millions of dollars that is the property of the taxpayers of Australia. It is not the Government's money; it is the money which belongs to the taxpayers of Australia.

I do not want to talk at length because we want to get on to the committee stage. However, in making that point, I want to simply refer to a letter in today's Australian Financial Review from Mr David Royal of Sydney, who sets out the case quite clearly. It is those who incurred the cost—the purchasers of the pools—who should be compensated. I draw honourable senators' attention to that article and another to similar effect in the Courier Mail of 14 September, where pool purchasers are starting to realise the implication of what would flow from the decisions of the court if the Government took no action. They find that entirely unjustifiable, and they are correct.

I thank the Committee members who gave serious and proper consideration to this important matter. Obviously at the end of the day we did not agree, but it was a proper process. In the end, the conflict of principle was too great for serious consideration and deliberation to lead us to an agreement, but I think we have better legislation for it. I thank them for their support. I thank for their contributions those who spoke sensibly to the legislation, which was the overwhelming majority of speakers. I commend the Bill to the Parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Swimming Pools Tax Refund Bill 1992
Mr President, these amendments address concerns raised in the debate on the Bill in the other place and by Honourable Senators since the introduction of the Bill into the Senate.
The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration considered the issues on Monday and discussed proposals for most of the amendments now being circulated.

Since that time further discussions have taken place between the Government and other Senators and representatives of builders and pool purchasers in an effort to resolve the perceived deficiencies in the Bill.

I would observe that, while there has been much convenient criticism of the Bill there has been very little constructive criticism. I thank the Democrats for taking a constructive approach. The Opposition, by contrast, has been quick to criticise but their only amendment proposal is to simply hand builders a windfall gain at the expense of purchasers.
The amendments proposed by the Government will achieve the following results.

A pool builder who passed part of the `tax' on to the purchaser, subsequently refunded that `tax' to the purchaser, and also absorbed part of the tax will be able to lodge one declaration with the Commissioner to claim the full amount of the refund.

Pool purchasers will be able to obtain, direct from the Commissioner without the need for the money to pass through the builder, a refund of an amount paid as sales tax on a swimming pool by lodging a joint declaration with the pool builder. This will overcome any problem arising from the builder being out of pocket and having to borrow money to pay the refund to the pool purchaser before obtaining a refund from the Tax Office.

If the pool builder has died or no longer exists, the pool purchaser will be able to apply direct to the Tax Office for a refund. The pool purchaser will have to supply the information needed to complete the necessary declaration.
Interest will be paid to a pool purchaser who receives a refund direct from the Tax Office from the time the tax was remitted by the builder up until the time the refund is paid to the purchaser.
If the purchaser gets a refund passed through the builder interest will be payable for the period beginning when the `tax' was remitted up until the builder makes a refund to the purchaser.

To assist a builder with costs incurred in preparing declarations that will obtain a refund for a pool purchaser, the builder will be entitled to receive an administrative fee paid out of the interest payable to the purchaser. The fee will be $100 or if the interest payment is less than $100 it will equal the amount of the interest.
To ensure that there is sufficient time for those who should get a refund to make a claim the period in which declarations can be lodged under the Bill has also been extended to two years.
I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum and commend the amendments to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Sales Tax Amendment (Transitional) Bill 1992
Sales Tax (Exemptions And Classifications) Bill 1992

PARA.EMPHASIS: Speech on amendments to be moved by the Government by Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer Senator Bob McMullan

SPEECH.PARA: I move the amendments being circulated on behalf of the Government.

Mr President, these amendments are consequential upon submissions that have been made to the Government and to the Senate Select Committee established by the Senate to report on the new streamlined sales tax Bills. The Committee's report has been tabled in the Senate today.

At the time of introduction of the Bills in the House of Representatives, the Treasurer gave a public commitment to consult widely to ensure that the new system will operate as smoothly as possible. That consultation process has been facilitated by the establishment of the Senate Committee.

After examination of the submissions and discussion with representatives of some affected industries, the Government has decided to make some changes to the Bills that will meet many of the concerns that have been raised. The Treasurer announced those changes on 11 August 1992. The Senate Committee, in its report, has recommended that the Senate pass the sales tax Bills, subject to the inclusion of the changes announced by the Treasurer.
There are six areas of change. These are:

PARA.TAB: the general anti-avoidance provision
leases
external costs
exempt use
deemed manufacturers
untaxed goods and the small business exemption.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the main features of the changes.

There has been some suggestion that the general anti-avoidance provision is wider than its counterpart in the income tax law (Part IVA) and that, consequently, it could create uncertainty in the marketplace. The provision has been redrafted to clarify the circumstances in which it will apply. In particular, the provision will list the factors which the Commissioner must have regard to in deciding whether to cancel a benefit received under a tax avoidance scheme. Additionally, the dominant purpose test has been changed to refer to a purpose which is dominant as against the total of all other purposes for which the scheme was entered into rather than being compared against each of the other purposes.

After consultation with the leasing industry, the Government proposes to legislate, with modifications, some of the existing administrative arrangements which allow the benefit of the conditional exemption system to be available to lessors.

In particular, the Government has extended the concessions that will be available for leasing stock, including leases granted on a short-term basis, so that exemption will apply if continuous short-term leases are granted in wholly exempt circumstances. Partial exemption will apply if short-term leases of goods are made in both taxable and exempt circumstances.

These new concessions will apply under agreements entered into between the lessor and the Commissioner of Taxation. The agreements will extend to parts and materials, and certain repair equipment, used in the repair and maintenance of the leasing stock.

The specific unconditional exemption for pallets provided for in the Bills will no longer be necessary under these proposed amendments for short-term leases and it will be withdrawn. Pallets leased on a short-term basis will be eligible for the same exemptions available for other short-term leases of goods.

A new credit provision will also be available for goods leased or loaned for a trial period and then sold in exempt circumstances to the same person. A separate provision will enable exemption to apply where one or more back to back sub-leases are interposed between the owner and the exempt sub-lessee.

The Bills seek to bring into the sales tax base product design and development costs incurred by persons who are past the traditional wholesale taxing point (e.g. where design costs are incurred by a retailer who contracts out the manufacture of the goods). While there is some public recognition of the general need to tax these costs, a number of practical difficulties in applying the new provisions have been identified. In the light of these concerns, the Government has decided that the full external costs provision should not be proceeded with at this time in order to allow a further examination of the issues identified. However, the proposed external costs arrangements will continue to apply to royalty payments, except that liability will be limited to the value of the royalty payment attributable to the goods.

The Bills require the immediate user of taxable goods to qualify for exemption rather than the ultimate user. The change was made to clarify the existing law, which is very unclear in this area. During the course of consultation, a number of specific examples have been identified where exemptions that are currently available under the existing law will not be available under the new law. The Government considers that some of these existing exemptions should be retained in the new law. The new law will be extended to provide exemption for the following goods:
. goods donated to, or by, exempt bodies (such as certain charities) and goods for use as prizes or awards by exempt bodies;

. parts and materials used in the repair or maintenance of goods owned by goods producers and exempt bodies (such as Governments and certain charities) if the property in the parts and materials passes to the exempt person; and
. goods that, under a contract with an exempt body, become part of buildings or other structures owned or leased by exempt bodies.
. goods that become part of a building or other structure leased to an exempt body

The Government will maintain the business inputs concessions available to certain classes of deemed manufacturers under the existing law. If a person supplies materials to a manufacturer to be made up into goods for resale by that person, the existing law deems that person to be the manufacturer and liable to tax on the goods. The deemed manufacturer is, however, eligible for certain business inputs concessions.

The new law will not have a concept of `deemed manufacturer'. Instead, liability will fall on the actual manufacturer. This will have the effect of removing business inputs concessions from persons who are, under the existing law, deemed to be manufacturers. However, following representations from industry, the Government has decided to allow the concessions which currently apply to deemed manufacturers to continue, but only where the made-up goods are mainly for wholesale sale by such persons.

As presently drafted, the new law will impose tax on goods that have been subject to the small business exemption where they are subsequently sold by retail or applied to own use by another business. However, there are concerns that some businesses (in particular, retailers), which are not generally liable to tax on their sales, would have difficulty in identifying and valuing the goods for the purpose of meeting the wholesale sales tax liability.

The Government accepts these concerns and will amend the untaxed goods provisions to remove the liability on retail sales and applications to own use of goods that have previously been exempted from tax because of the operation of the small business exemption.

Mr President, these amendments indicate a willingness on the part of the Government to take on board the concerns expressed by industry and other interested persons about certain aspects of the streamlined sales Bills. The Government will continue to consult widely on the new law.
I commend the amendments to the Senate.
