SPEECH.PARA: SALES TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Clauses 1 to 4—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —Initially I want to speak generally in order to seek some clarification from the Government as to the reasons for the amendments being put before this chamber. The Government announced in the 1990-91 Budget that it would undertake a major review of the sales tax, which encompasses something like 27 Acts, with a view to simplifying a regime that even it acknowledged had become very cumbersome, burdensome and anomaly ridden over the years.

PARA.TAB: The Government, or more particularly the Australian Taxation Office, undertook what we were told was a very extensive and exhaustive review of the existing sales tax legislation. The Government came up with a set of proposals which were announced by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in, I think, April of this year in terms of the general direction in which the Government was going to go by way of its proposed simplification.

The Bills were introduced into the House of Representatives late in May and were guillotined through that chamber without any substantive debate at all. The question arises as to why the amendments are now before us. The amendments that we are about to consider completely or to a very large degree undermine and certainly emasculate the Bills that were introduced as a result of the Government's review. Given that the Government had said that this was the most extensive review of and change to sales tax law since its origin in 1930, one can only express surprise that it has now seen fit to produce a whole raft of fundamental amendments which undermine many of the key so-called simplification changes that were to be introduced.

I also remind the Committee that the changes which foreshadowed the actual amendments that we are considering now were announced by the Treasurer at something like six o'clock in the afternoon of 11 August 1992—just 12 hours before the select committee which this chamber had set up to examine the Bills was due to hold its first public hearings on the 150 submissions that had been received. This select committee was established as a result of concern expressed by the coalition following an enormous number of representations and expressions of concern right across industry and the wider community following the initial introduction of the six Bills in May.

There was no indication of what was to follow when this legislation was guillotined through the House of Representatives and introduced into the Senate in June. Had the Senate not agreed in its wisdom to establish a select committee, we would not be here debating these amendments because the original Bills would have become law before these amendments were even dreamt of.

The whole exercise that the Government has been engaged in in terms of amending the legislation in such a fundamental way smacks of very hasty changes to what it claimed to be legislation designed on the basis of the most thorough of reviews. The amendments that were announced by the Treasurer on 11 August, but which were not available until after the Select Committee had in fact reported to the Senate, added great confusion to the Select Committee's deliberation on the Bills. As I said, the Select Committee has examined submissions received from 150 interested parties right across the Australian community. These submissions had been prepared on the basis that the Government was serious about introducing the six Bills that it had guillotined and jackbooted through the House of Representatives—and it had attempted to do the same in the Senate.

We have never had a full explanation as to why these amendments are considered necessary and why the Government has introduced them. The only conclusion that one can reasonably come to is that the Government panicked when it found that it was unable to prevent the establishment of the Senate select committee. It would appear that it deliberately sought to undermine the work of that committee by trying to accommodate some of the concerns that were expressed and contained in the 150 submissions that the committee had received. I understand that many of those concerns had been expressed to the Tax Office from the date the legislation first became available.

So the Government has engaged in a major back down by introducing these amendments to its so-called fundamentally changed legislation. Quite obviously, the timing of Mr Dawkins's announcement that he was going to make these changes was designed to pre-empt the strong criticisms of his proposals that had been expected to be aired during debate by the select committee.

This follows the usual practice of this Government, and in particular this Treasurer, in that he kept his announcement until as late in the day as possible to attempt to minimise the adverse comment from the media and accounting experts, and from those who had worked very hard to make submissions to the Select Committee only to have the ground cut from under their feet at the very last minute.

Before we get into the debate on the individual clauses and amendments that are before us, I would like an explanation from the Government as to why these amendments have been made, and why the Government has seen fit to so emasculate the legislation that it claimed was fundamental to streamlining and increasing the efficiency of the sales tax regime. Why has it taken this step?Does it accept the view that these amendments emasculate in key areas the Bills that it introduced in May? Those areas are very important areas indeed. They are, to quote the Treasurer himself, the areas of the general anti-avoidance provision, external costs, exempt use, deemed manufacturers, untaxed goods and the small business exemption as well as the important area of leases.

They are not small beer. They are very important areas indeed in the totality of what the Government was purporting to be wanting to do in terms of its changes to the sales tax regime which has been in existence for so many years. The debate on the individual amendments would be helped very considerably if the Government could give the chamber some understanding and explanation of just why these amendments are being proposed now, what the basis for them is, and, very importantly indeed, what they do to the totality of the legislative proposals that were originally introduced in May by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very interesting situation in which we find ourselves and, in a sense, it typifies the nature of the debate that is likely to occur in Australia over the next weeks and months. Here we have the Government being criticised by the Opposition for being flexible. That is exactly what I would expect, because those opposite take pride in their inflexibility. Mr Reith stood up in the House of Representatives and made a virtue of the inflexibility of the Opposition. I have to say that that is the sort of inflexibility that one usually only finds in obscure theoreticians in obscure universities. Now we have the obscure theoreticians in charge of the asylum and they are, therefore, concerned that there might be flexibility.

PARA.TAB: Let me make it absolutely clear: there is no change to the main concepts—the fundamental nature—of the change to the sales tax assessment operation that is set out in diagram one of the readers' guide to the Sales Tax Assessment Bill. That fundamental concept remains unchanged and will remain unchanged from the Government's point of view. We are saying, `We have certain core concepts that are fundamental'. This is what we are trying to achieve. We want to maintain the flexibility which the wholesale sales tax system gives us, as distinct from the Opposition's proposed indirect tax proposals. We want to retain the capacity to exercise discretion to distinguish between necessities and luxuries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want a debate all night tonight?

—I did not ask Senator Short to start this point. I am simply responding. I accept that it was entirely inappropriate. I want to deal with the clauses. We are retaining the core concept. We are showing flexibility in response to a large amount of community concern about detail. We made fairly clear in the committee stage why we are responding and to which we are responding.
—Be brief.
—I am responding to Senator Short's rather lengthy speech. It is interesting that people are concerned that I have responded for three minutes to a 10-minute criticism.
—You are just encouraging us to have to long debate tonight.

—I did not start it. There was a 10-minute speech by Senator Short criticising the Government and making a very partisan speech. He is entitled to do it; it is a partisan chamber. Let us not react when I say that we do not like the Opposition's core concept. He attacked the fundamental nature of the wholesale sales tax. I am defending it and I am saying that at diagram one the main concepts of the Bill are set out. Those core concepts are retained and the Treasurer adopted them in response to a number of community concerns. He did not respond to all the criticisms because we did not agree with all the criticisms. People came to us for a change. We said, `No, no, no', but in six instances we said, `Yes', and we think we will have better legislation. I would be delighted to encourage speedy passage. If my speaking briefly will encourage that, I will be pleasantly surprised.
—I would like to press Senator McMullan a little.
—Senator Watson is concerned about us going on with your comments and you are going again.
—I want to press Senator McMullan a little further. Senator McMullan gave a complete non-answer to the fundamentally important questions that I have raised. Let me summarise them.

PARA.TAB: Question one is: why did the Government move these amendments which so emasculate the legislation that it rammed through the House of Representatives, and that it said was required in order to have a proper simplification—to use its word—of the sales tax regime? I put it to Senator McMullan that it is simply not credible to say that the changes that the Government has made in the six areas that are, essentially, involved in these amendments do not very considerably affect the legislation that he is talking about.

For example, the Government placed great weight on changing the law in relation to deemed manufacturers. Now the Government has essentially given that away. The Government placed great weight on the need for change in terms of external costs. Essentially, it has given that away. It has done exactly the same in terms of exempt use. It has made major changes to its proposals in terms of untaxed goods and small business.

Without arguing the rights or wrongs of the particular amendments that the Government is proposing, what I am putting is that they very fundamentally affect the original legislation. This Senate requires a explanation of that and the implications it has for the Government's whole approach to indirect taxation, because this is what these Bills are about. These are the Government's attempted answers to the proposals of the coalition for the introduction of a goods and services tax. We have always said—and this is the reason why we will be introducing a goods and services tax on coming to government—that the wholesale sales tax is so fundamentally and inherently flawed that it cannot be an efficient, fair and equitable tax.

The Government claims through the simplification exercise that it undertook over nearly a two-year period that it was really going to knock this sales tax regime into shape. Then, at 24 or 48 hours notice, the Government took a political decision that it was going to move fundamental amendments to its own legislation. I repeat, these amendments would not have been made had the Government had its way in the first instance and got this legislation through the House in June. The Government opposed the establishment of the Select Committee. It was only the establishment of the Select Committee that forced the Government in the end to make these amendments.

For Senator McMullan to come in here and not give this Committee an explanation of the reasons for that quite extraordinary action is, with respect, reprehensible. If Senator McMullan expects this Parliament to be able to give the Government's proposed amendments proper, logical and reasoned consideration, he owes it to the Parliament to give an explanation as to the reasons for his actions. I ask Senator McMullan again whether he could provide that explanation to form the basis for a sensible debate and consideration of the amendments that the Government has now circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether to agree with Senator Short, who wants to have a big debate about the politics of it, or with Senator Watson, who does not. I hope that over dinner both senators talk to each other and come to an agreement.
—Senator Watson wants you to answer my question.

—The amendments do not do anything to reflect the sort of drivel that Senator Short rabbited on about, because they do not affect the core concepts that are at diagram one and that constitute why this is a major simplification. None of that is affected. The reasons for the individual amendments were set out clearly in the press release of 11 August from the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and there is nothing to add.

—I think a point of explanation is required. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) is attempting to promote division among a number of senators on this side of the chamber. That is quite inappropriate and quite incorrect. My interjection was directed at Senator McMullan so that he could answer directly the questions asked by Senator Short. I believe a direct and quick response is the appropriate way to gain a speedy passage of the Bills and to ensure that we do not go through until 4.30 tomorrow morning in the same manner that we did last Monday. There are a number of important issues to direct our attention to. I submit that we should look at clauses 1 to 15 inclusive and clauses 26 and 50.

—I will address Senator Watson's last point and make a one sentence response to his other point. I do not accept that people are entitled to come in here, make political speeches at me and then get upset when I make a political speech in response. I will not accept that. I do accept his sensible suggestion as to how after we pass these clauses we might proceed.

—Is Senator McMullan saying to the Committee that he is not going to extend to the chamber the courtesy of an explanation as to the reasons for the amendments that he has proposed and the impact that they would have on major areas of his simplification package. I find that a quite extraordinary and arrogant attitude, if I may say so, that adds to the disregard that this Government seems continually to show to the rights, responsibilities and duties of this Parliament.
—We actually had a Committee that talked about these amendments for hours.
—The amendments were not available to that Committee.

—Senator Short is not talking about the words. He is saying, `Why did we proceed in this direction?' and he knows the answer to that. We had this discussion for hours. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) put out a press release that makes this matter clear. I have incorporated in Hansard statements that outline the details behind both propositions. I do not think that the achievement of Senator Watson's desirable objective of not being here until 4.30 a.m. will be aided by my reading into Hansard the Treasurer's press release, but I will do that if honourable senators opposite wish.

—I think I should have my 20c worth. We have had hours and hours and hours of discussions in the GST versus WST debate. We are in Committee. Senator Short, I do not believe the purpose of your questioning is to attempt to improve the legislation, because the Opposition does not have any amendments.
—Wait and see.

—Senator Watson, if the Opposition has amendments they have not been circulated; I do not have a copy of them. So I think I am entitled to jump to that conclusion. We have already had the debate. We had a very extensive second reading debate which we all remember well. If, in my view, Senator Short's questions are not designed to elicit the sort of explanation that would assist amendment, for example, or improvement, I think we should get on with our consideration. We have had the debate. We are going to an election with two competing taxation systems and the people of Australia will have the opportunity to decide. I hope that we can get on with the discussion of the clauses so that we are not here, in what must be the most unproductive use of the time of this chamber, until 4.30 in the morning.

—I and the coalition do not wish to be here until 4.30 in the morning either. The process of consideration of these Bills would be assisted very considerably indeed if Senator McMullan, who is handling this matter on behalf of the Government, were to give this Committee an explanation. I am not asking him to read pages and pages into Hansard. I am asking him to give the chamber the courtesy it is due.

PARA.TAB: I would like him to explain, at the start of this Committee debate, the reasons for these amendments and the background to them. Why were they introduced so late in the piece? Why were they introduced seemingly to undermine the work of the Select Committee? Why were they introduced not much more than a month or so after the Bill, seemingly to the Government's satisfaction, went through the House of Representatives as drafted and was attempted to be pushed through the Senate as well?

These amendments would not now be being debated here—they would not have been produced—if the Government's own timetable for the passage of this legislation through both chambers had been adhered to. If the Bills that were introduced into the Parliament in such great haste and with such a fanfare by the Government as being the greatest thing in 60 years resulting from the greatest review, how on earth can that argument sit logically against the subsequent actions by the Government of introducing a major range of amendments to those Bills, which have a very significant impact. Those Bills remove from the sales tax regime many of the areas that the Government told us were important including the deemed manufacture provision and the others to which I have already referred. Why is it that so soon after the original Bills were pushed through the House of Representatives and attempted to be pushed through the Senate that such a need for change was found to the extent that these amendments were necessary.

Surely if the Government had done its work and the Taxation Office had been satisfied with the work that it had done in the exhaustive, I presume, and extensive review over two years—although we were told in the Select Committee that there was very little consultation in the course of that review with the clients of the Taxation Office—why was that not sufficient? I do not know whether that is true or not but that is what we were told.

How come we are now, as a Parliament, being asked to consider amendments which were not deemed necessary at the time the Select Committee was established. That was a time when the Taxation Office knew the objections that had been raised and the concerns that had been expressed. It was not that it had to wait until the 150 submissions came up before the Committee. Most of the objections that had been raised had been raised earlier than that and yet no action was taken. Why is it that this action was then deemed to be so necessary given that, in several key areas, the changes brought into this place in the first instance were fundamentally different?

Senator McMullan can shake his head, nod and do whatever he wants to. I know that it has been a long, hard week, and it might be a harder night at the rate he is going. But this chamber does deserve and, I put to you, require courteous treatment by the Government. That courtesy involves fundamentally an adequate explanation of why we are doing what we are now doing. I ask Senator McMullan again, as a matter of courtesy, to explain to us the reasons why those changes were necessary and, if they are necessary, why they were not taken into account in the course of the review that took nearly two years to produce the legislation. Why were they not incorporated in the Bills that Senator McMullan said were so urgent that he wanted to bulldoze them through both Houses? The Government managed to do that in the House of Representatives; it did not manage to do it in this chamber. Once again, I ask for an explanation of that. Such an explanation will considerably help the subsequent consideration of the individual amendments that Senator McMullan is proposing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the comments made by my colleague Senator Short. I can understand the reluctance of the Government to respond because it is indeed embarrassed by what has happened. Let us go through the sequence that has lead to that embarrassment.

PARA.TAB: The Government sought to reduce 29 Acts of complex legislation involving sales tax to approximately six. It was a process that involved something like two years of extensive inquiry by the Australian Taxation Office. Unfortunately, in order to counteract the legitimate issues of Fightback, the Government sought to expedite that simplification process, and there were some problems. In those problems we had a new set of six Bills. The Opposition referred those Bills to a Senate select committee. Prior to the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation sitting, the Government came down with a whole range of changes which completely altered whole sections of that legislation.

Senator Short sought unsuccessfully to refer the amendments arising from the Select Committee deliberations and other issues to a new Senate select committee. With the support of the Democrats and the Government, that process was refused. Had we embarked on that quite orderly process, what is now appearing to be a very long Committee stage evaluation would have been avoided. Therefore, I submit that my colleague Senator Short has raised a number of questions that could otherwise have been legitimately raised in a Senate select committee process of which he, Senator Vanstone and Senator Kernot were a part in the earlier select committee. That forum having been denied, he legitimately raises those issues now. I put it that we could have a succinct, although perhaps embarrassed, reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that I have never heard such silly remarks from such sensible people in my life. I have respect for both Senator Short and Senator Watson. We are usually able to work together very cooperatively. I do not know what has happened to them; I hope that they have a pleasant dinner.

PARA.TAB: The Government said in 1990 that it would have a review of sales tax legislation, and it did. In May of this year, we introduced the simplification of the wholesale sales tax legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some simplification.

—Which it is, very substantially. We then said that we would seek to have that legislation passed during that session of Parliament, which we did. We were unsuccessful—on we went through another process. But we said at that time, `The provision of the legislation will not commence until 1 October 1992. The deferred commencement date will allow members of the simplification review team to be available to meet with key professional and industry bodies and taxpayer representatives to discuss the simplification package. There will be an opportunity for the results of the consultation process to be analysed before the new law commences to apply'. It was always absolutely clear that the Bills were to be subject to consultation.

PARA.TAB: The nature of the consultation process was changed by the Senate. The consultation process we had in mind did not take place because the Senate set up a committee. Therefore, the consultation process went to that Committee. That is fine. As a result, some 150—

TALK.START.PARA: —A little bit late, with respect.

—No, we would have been consulting in a different manner about the Bills but we did not have that opportunity. That was fine and we therefore changed the way we operated and adapted to the majority wish of the Senate. We did not have any choice but we happily did so, as Opposition senators know.

PARA.TAB: The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) made it clear in his statement of 11 August that the consultation process had been facilitated by the establishment of the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation. It was not the only way to do it but it was workable. I do not think that it is actually in the press release, but he made it clear in public on a number of occasions—and I reiterate—that we would not accept amendments that changed the fundamental nature of the wholesale sales tax legislation. We rejected people who wanted to make amendments that made the legislation similar to the GST, as some did. Some wanted to come and say, `Well, we will amend this wholesale sales tax', and at the end of the day we had a set of policies that had all the features that we do not like about the Opposition's policies. Therefore, we rejected those.

They were contrary to the core concepts of the wholesale sales tax. For example, those suggestions started to do away with the capacity of our legislation to distinguish between socially, environmentally and economically desirable activity and undesirable activity that the wholesale sales tax retains. That is a core concept and we had no intention of doing away with that; thus we rejected all those suggestions. There are some suggestions which are still being pursued in this chamber by the Democrats, with which we disagree. In this instance they do not go to the core concept, but we do not like the form in which they are being proposed; so we will not support them.

From over 150 submissions that were received and the responses that were then available to the legislation, the Treasurer indicated that there were six areas of change that we were prepared to accept. He set out those on 11 August in detail. They are on the public record. He set down the nature of the representations which were made on each occasion and why we were responding to them in the way we were. Sometimes we accepted people's proposals entirely; at other times we did not accept their proposal but said we would respond in part. In some cases, in order to allow further examination we said that we would not be proceeding with certain things at this time. So the responses are qualitatively different from different aspects of the proposal.

In addition to that, I have circulated to honourable senators the speeches that would otherwise have been made in moving the various Government amendments. Those are available; they set out the reasons for each amendment. Therefore, there seemed to me to be two causes of concern in so far as I can discern any essential core concepts in Senator Short's concerns. That is, as best I can distil them, there are two problems. One seems to be that we should not have amended the Bill at all because we must have thought it was wonderful because we put it through. I will go back to make it clear. We still support the core simplification concepts set out in diagram 1 and we would have not accepted changes that went to undermine the nature of that reform.

We always made it clear that there would be a consultative process. This is not the process we would have chosen, but it has led to this result. We are happy with some of the amendments as a long term proposition and some, as we have made clear, may only be made to facilitate further review. That is the nature of the parliamentary and democratic process; we are not concerned. This passion about our being embarrassed is wrong. We are very proud of this package. It will be very effective in achieving its economic purposes. It will make the administration of the wholesale sales tax more efficient and the compliance costs lower. It will retain those features of the wholesale sales tax that we wish to retain and improve in some other areas its operation. That is what we set out to do. We did not set out to change its fundamental nature, but to simplify it and to reduce the administrative and compliance costs associated with it. Other changes have been made to wholesale sales tax with regard to things such as business inputs, which are not related to this legislation, but all of which are part of the program of reform.
To the best I can distil that there is some concern, that, I think, is the answer to it. If it is not, I do not have an answer to it; let us get on with the business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not help but rise when Senator McMullan said that he was very proud of the sales tax legislation. It is quite interesting. I have some figures that appear in a Confederation of Australian Industry paper that has only come out in the last few days. Its survey of investor confidence showed that we are still in the midst of a recession. We all know that. We are going to be there for a long while under this Government because it is not taking action to address the fundamental problems with the economy.

PARA.TAB: The results of the survey show that taxes and government charges were the biggest constraint on investment at this time with a degree of intensity of 72 per cent. For the record, I have risen only because Senator McMullan said that he was very proud of legislation which is going to rip money off the community; wholesale sales taxes do that to a great degree.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it isn't going to increase the revenue at all.

—Just a minute. Taxes and government charges constrain investment to a degree intensity of 72 per cent. That is the highest degree of intensity of concern of anyone in the investment sector. To say that the Government is trying to simplify it and do something with a system that is not working properly anyway but which has just trebled the tax take is something that I had to rise on. I had to make those few comments about those wholesale sales taxes which are raising so much money out of the community at the moment. The tax take from them has trebled under this Government.

—I pick up on a comment by Senator McMullan in his previous remarks. If I heard him correctly, Senator McMullan said that overwhelmingly the changes that are contained in these amendments are changes that are designed to reduce the administrative and compliance costs and to increase the efficiency of the new regime. Is that what Senator McMullan said? If it is, do I take it that he is saying that, overwhelmingly, the changes being proposed in these amendments are designed simply to improve the efficiency of the system in relation to reducing administrative and compliance costs and do not go in any substantial way to the substance of the operation of the sales tax regime and the content of the sales tax regime? Is Senator McMullan saying that all the changes being made, for example, in the area of the deemed manufactures, exempt use, external cost and leases are being made, essentially, to reduce administrative and compliance cost?
—No.
—If Senator McMullan did not, I misunderstood what he said.
—Yes, you did.
—What did Senator McMullan say? I was clearly of the impression that that is what he said.

—I said that was the fundamental objective of the simplification process and I outlined the reasons for these amendments four or five times. I suggest that over the dinner suspension Senator Short read any one of the four or five Government statements, whether they are the speeches that have been incorporated in Hansard or the press releases put out by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), each of which outlines in detail the case for each of the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time that is available this evening I will say a few words on this sales tax simplification Bill, as it has been expressed. I would express the view, as others already have, that it is anything but a simplification Bill—as the Government has found out since it rammed it through the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: A bit earlier this evening I heard Senator McMullan say that he could not see why we do not hurry it through this place much sooner and he made mention of the time that we have wasted. After the House of Representatives spent 37 minutes on this Bill—last June, I presume—it passed, without the scrutiny it should have had, and came to this place and the Government expected us to pass it under guillotine in the same period. Since then there has been a short inquiry into it—and how many amendments have there been from the Democrats, the coalition and even the Government since that time? Bearing that in mind, I cannot see any reason for rushing this legislation through right at the present moment.

As taxation officers themselves said quite some time ago, they were battling to understand it themselves. One is on record as saying—and I mentioned this in my speech in the second reading debate—that it took him three days to read the damn thing and even after that he did not necessarily understand it. I therefore believe that this legislation is anything but simplification. As a result of that short inquiry held into this legislation last June-July or whenever it was, a lot of the measures that the Government was going to bring in have been dropped—such as sales tax being paid on farm machinery while it is sitting on the block, and stock while it is sitting on the shelves waiting to be sold. A lot of those measures have been taken out of the legislation. That is indicative of what this Government does at times—it makes an announcement and, when it finds out what the reality is, it backs off.

A good example of this is the announcement of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) this morning. Following the Opposition pointing out the secret taxes that existed in the Budget, he has made some changes. For instance, he said he was going to have a withholding tax on the interest earned at the banks, and now he has backed off from that. His reason for backing off from that, I believe, is that he did not do his homework in the first place. I will get back to the Bill in a minute—

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be encouraging, if you did. I think you are on the wrong Bill, anyway.

—This all relates to the sales tax Bill; it is along the same line. Unfortunately, the Treasurer should take more advice from his advisers before he makes these announcements. I believe the reason he backed off on that one was—and this is something that I pointed out at the time too, if I may say so—that the interest earned at banks on savings accounts, if it was more than $1,000, was covered by provisional tax anyhow. So it would have been collected anyhow—ahead of time and at a much higher rate than the 20 per cent that the Government proposed.
—Senator Panizza, I remind you that the question before the Chair is that clauses 1 to 4 of the Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992 be agreed to.

—I fully understand that, but I was using this as an example of the Government making announcements and then changing its mind as it goes after seeing the obvious. I was simply using that as an example. There were many other things that changed, as I said, like the sales tax on farm machinery while it sits on a block. I am glad Senator Kernot is back in the chamber now. In that situation the sales tax was to be paid and then, when it went to an exempt purchaser, it was to be refunded. Now I see that has been dropped from the Bill.

PARA.TAB: This is where Senator Kernot tried to make fame for herself. She wrote to farm machinery dealers, after they had pounded her with facts on top of facts on the matter. The Government then realised that it could stand as part of that legislation and it backed off on it. But in Senator Kernot's written reply to all the farm machinery dealers of Australia—and she knows what I am talking about; the letter is there and I will show it to her in a moment—she first of all took the credit for the disappearance of that measure from the sales tax Bill and then went on to say, `Of course, under the GST package you will to have pay that anyhow and leave it there until the end of the reporting period'. She did not even say, `until the end of the reporting period'; she said, `while it is on the vacant block'. That is the point. Of course, she knows as well as I do—or should know as well as I do—that under the GST provision one can have GST refunded before the end of the reporting period.

That is what is wrong with this Bill. The Government is in so much of a hurry to try to catch up with Hewson's Fightback and GST package that it has rushed into this. Sales tax has been around, I believe, since either 1931 or 1936 when it was introduced—

TALK.START.PARA: —Early 1930s it was introduced.

—I thank Senator Watson who is very knowledgeable at all times on this subject of taxation. Sales tax has been around since that time. The only ones who will ever come up with a total package to revamp that sales tax will get rid of it and bring something else in. The Government knew there was an election coming on and that it had to find something to counteract the Opposition's proposal, so it picked on the sales tax. That is what happened. That is why we are being so rushed with the Bill here. We are to do all of the committee stage between now and midnight or thereabouts, and so we will not do it justice. I believe it should pulled out completely.

—Senator Kernot has been caught wanting before, so she should not interrupt me now. That is where this Government has gone. I would like to know the rationale for some of the decisions it has taken, like taking away the sales tax exemption for four-wheel drive trucks where the four driving wheels happen to be at the back end of the vehicle rather than at the front. About 18 months ago a tax ruling was issued by one of the Tax Offices in Australia allowing that sort of vehicle an exemption. It was a valid exemption then, under a tax ruling—it was not a court decision or anything like that; it was a tax ruling by the Commissioner. That was allowable where such a vehicle was used in primary production. That applied to a four-wheel drive vehicle—a truck, whatever size it was—where there was tandem drive; in other words, it was four-wheel drive but the four driving wheels were at the back. The Tax Commissioner gave his ruling that that qualified for exemption. Now this Bill specifically removes that exemption. I have not heard any rationale for this. Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is at the table, will give us a reason a bit later on as to why the exemption for such a vehicle should be removed—because it is a four-wheel drive vehicle, the four-wheel drive being on the rear end rather than being used to steer as well.

PARA.TAB: I would like an explanation for that. Why should one four-wheel drive vehicle be different from another one the same size doing the same job, carrying the same weight and transporting the same material just because, of the four driving wheels, two are up the front and two are down the back while the other has four down the back? I have not had a logical explanation, and I would like to have one.

There are vast numbers of problems with this Bill because it tries to be all things to all industries. I believe that it should at least have been referred to a fully fledged committee rather being considered in the short inquiry that was undertaken, although a reasonable amount of good work was done on it in that time.

It is my belief that the whole package of Bills should be removed from the timetable altogether. After all, the Government is still collecting about $10 billion a year in sales tax. It will not necessarily be revenue neutral. I know that it will collect more by this new system than it did before, so it is not a matter of simplification. It is a matter of catching more sales tax in the net.

Seeing that the next election is so close at hand, I believe that this legislation should be put on the backburner. The Government could put this package up as its policy for the next election. If this Bill is it, so be it. It can send it out to the voters of Australia to judge it for themselves, just as they will judge our GST package over the next six months, nine months, four weeks or six weeks, depending on the date of the next election. That is the best advice that I can give the Government on this matter.

It is a pity that the others who claim to know their sales tax laws and claim to know how the GST works do not do that rather than make rash statements as did Senator Kernot when she upset a number of the machinery dealers around Australia. She led them to believe that that was how it was going to work. It was a total untruth. Even I started having a few doubts that I was right—I am generally right on these things—so I went through the GST package again and got the right advice from the people who wrote it. What Senator Kernot said is incorrect. The most decent thing that she could do is to write to all those machinery dealers to whom she has given the wrong message in the last few weeks and give them the right message—that is, that under the GST system sales tax that is paid by the retailer to the wholesaler on purchases to put on his block will be fully refunded without waiting for the end of the reporting period.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 5, page 6, after definition of "passed on", insert the following definition:

"permanent media" means goods designed to have computer programs embodied in them on a permanent basis being goods which do not allow the erasement and replacement of the computer program originally embodied in them;".
Clause 5, page 8, after definition of "taxpayer", insert the following definition:

"temporary media" means goods designed to have computer programs embodied in them on a temporary basis being goods which allow computer programs to be embodied, erased and replaced from time to time;".

This is an unusual subject to talk about—the differentiation of a sales tax system in relation to microchips. The Government intended to tax computer programming to the extent that it is hard-wired inter-componentry in the way that a microchip is. It correctly treats such programming as intrinsically physical and unalterable and therefore a taxable good. But it also treats software, such as alterable software, which is embodied on a floppy disc, as not physical in nature and therefore certainly not a good. Because of that, the software is not taxable under the wholesale sales tax. I do not have a problem with that sort of differentiation but I think the structure of the legislation did not anticipate nor make provision for the sort of emerging technology that we now see in this field.

PARA.TAB: The current legislation exempts from tax all computer programs other than those `embodied on a microchip'. The word `microchip' was chosen because it was thought that software embodied in a microchip was embodied in such a way as to become permanent. It assumes that all microchips are what they call hard-wired. Whilst this was once the case, technology has overtaken legislation in this area. There is a type of microchip which we call an EPROM—erasable programmable read only memory. That type of microchip is now disadvantaged by the outdated definitions in this Bill. The EPROMs have software embodied in them. However, the microchip can be erased and/or reprogrammed. Quite literally, the EPROM is more like a floppy disc than a microchip, but the legislation imposes a tax disadvantage on this EPROM.

Let us think about the recent debate on telecommunications and pay television. In both of these situations there was a conscious and I think a correct decision to be technologically neutral. We know we are going to have innovation. We want that technological innovation to have an opportunity to flourish. It is our argument that that principle should be extended to sales tax law. Senator Watson warned the Senate of the possibility of this kind of result years ago. I hope the Government and Opposition members are not doing one of those nasty little deals over there; I thought only Democrats were allowed to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are trying to help you.
—I was speaking highly of Senator Watson and reminding the Committee that he talked in the Senate about this possibility. He was right, and here we are addressing the sort of anomaly he pointed to.

PARA.TAB: I think the Tax Office has conceded in an unofficial way that there is merit in this argument, but the Government has not sought to remedy the anomaly. Then we have the argument that this is moving outside the simplification process and that this is not the time to do it. I might just anticipate what the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) might say. If he attempts to say that, I remind him that in this very Bill the Government is using the simplification process to change the classification of unprocessed bottled mineral water from being taxable at 20 per cent to being exempt. One would hope for some consistency. If we are to be consistent we cannot say it is okay for bottled mineral water but it is not okay for EPROMs.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Kernot said, this is a technical matter and we should not all stand here pretending to have a level of expertise that we do not have about the technology. That is not really necessary to deal with the tax effects that we are trying to come to grips with here. The wording is complicated with EPROMs, as Senator Kernot has said. I think the principles are fundamentally unaffected by whether it is a high-tech product we are talking about or some other sort of differentiated product. There is no crisis about differentiating where the circumstances are different. In each instance one has to look at the consequences of the distinction people are trying to make.

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendment seeks to have the value of software that is embodied non-permanently on a microchip, such as EPROM, treated as tax-preferred software over `permanent microchips'. This would mean that, in the case of a mobile phone with the tax-preferred microchip, the taxable value would exclude the value of the software, which is around 40 per cent of that phone. The argument that is put in favour of this proposed exemption is that these EPROMs, as with software contained on other temporary media such as a disk, can easily be upgraded or modified.

In addition, I accept that it is argued that EPROMs are more accessible to domestic manufacturers because they are more suited to shorter production runs, but it is hard to see why there is a competitive disadvantage to people from the proposed uniform treatment. Our concern is really to the contrary: providing an exemption for EPROMs would disadvantage competing goods that have software embodied permanently on microchips. For example, I am advised that at least one sort of mobile phone uses permanent microchips and therefore would be at a disadvantage when compared with some of its competitors that use EPROMs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you just support the efficient ones?

—I thank Senator Boswell for his assistance. Therefore, this would provide a competitive disadvantage to some people for no apparent socially beneficial purpose. I do not see the benefit. One is being advantaged over another and it is possible that this could lead to a significant erosion of the tax base as an incentive would be given to people to use those sorts of microchips. There could be a significant proliferation of its use and further distortions could be created between goods which utilise EPROMs and goods using permanent microchips. Therefore, we do not support the exemption for reprogramable memory microchips.

PARA.TAB: I think on balance, notwithstanding that the technology is changing, which is true, it is not apparent to me why that changes the core concepts which underlie it. For that reason the Government will not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment has a number of attractions to the Opposition in that the sales tax legislation in this country frequently lags behind current technical developments. Australia has a good reputation for technical innovation. We have a company here, Voxson, which is essentially the manufacturer and which is going to be principally involved in this operation. As such, it could be disadvantaged in relation to certain imported products that do not have the same degree of sophistication admittedly, but in terms of price and performance would be deemed to be competitive businesses.

PARA.TAB: The other matter that concerns me is that because there is such a big market in Asia and the competition largely comes from there, this corporation has the potential, if it is priced out of its Australian market, to move north. I believe that an unintended consequence of this sales tax legislation could be the loss of a potential industry, the very industry that Australia should be encouraging, and this would be detrimental. While I believe that this Senate should not be used to introduce or to provide changes which will impact heavily on the revenue of this country, I do think that from time to time there are circumstances where the law has failed to keep abreast of the technical know-how and that Australian ingenuity could be prejudiced as a result.

Because of that, I am reluctantly persuaded to support the amendment in this case. During my discussions with the Parliamentary Secretary, he accepted the reasons. I must point out that this is consistent with the stand we took in 1989 and 1990 when the sales tax legislation failed to acknowledge another technical development affecting a product of Australia in terms of the plugging effect of these particular microchips.

In 1986, sales tax legislation was amended in an attempt to make this computer software subject to sales tax. As a result of those amendments, all software embodied in a medium was effectively made subject to tax. Naturally, these amendments caused very great problems in the software industry and eventually in 1990 the sales tax legislation was once again amended to remove sales tax on computer software other than that which is embodied permanently in a medium. The problem words were `permanently embodied in a medium' and this caused problems in relation to those items that were plugged in and, today, it involves that new technology where certain programs can be erased. This is a significant development and I submit to the Parliamentary Secretary that the choice of the word `microchip' in the legislation was unfortunate because it does apply in a highly technical sense to microchips, which are goods into which programs are embodied on a permanent basis.
This new technology has been developed extensively in Queensland, the State of Senator Boswell, who I know is supporting this particular measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Senator Kernot!

—And the mover of this amendment. Therefore I believe that the loss of this industry and that technology to Australia would be unfortunate. I believe there is room for one of those unusual circumstances where it is essential to remind the Government that, from time to time, its legislation must keep pace with technology, particularly the technology that we want to stay here in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this time it might be opportune if I raise some queries because my questions are directed to leases, which are covered under clauses 15, 26 and 50. The relevant additional amendments slot into page 12 after clause 15, clause 26 on page 16, clause 50 on page 25 and schedule 1, table 3, on page 67. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary: will the amendments allow sales tax exemption for taxable components of buildings which are built on speculation by private persons and then sold or leased to exempt persons or sold to a private person for lease to exempt persons?
—My advice is that these deal only with leases of goods, and buildings are not goods for this purpose.

—I therefore have a problem because I expected that to be answered in the affirmative, to be in line with the Treasurer's press release of 11 August 1992 with regard to leasing to exempt bodies. It does not appear that this will be the case. I seek some clarification on this matter.
—If Senator Watson's concern is with goods incorporated into such buildings rather than the buildings themselves—
—That's my next question.

—It is the buildings themselves. In that case I have nothing to add. I am a bit puzzled—knowing Senator Watson's experience in this area—in trying to understand the point he is making. As I understood it, and as I have checked and had confirmed, the sales tax does not apply to leases of buildings and therefore the question of whether they are exempt does not arise.

—Under certain circumstances it can arise, with respect. It depends who they are built for; for example, if they are disposed of to an exempt person. So the whole issue arises only in the very limited circumstances where the ownership or use is going to extend to an exempt person.

—Therefore, we understand from that answer that the exemption will be denied under the proposed amendments unless at the time the taxable goods are incorporated in the building and the building is owned or to be owned or is actually leased to the exempt body. —I do not understand how Senator Watson can talk about the exemption applying in a circumstance in which the tax does not apply. I cannot see how the exemption can apply.
—I thought they would have applied with respect to exempt bodies.

—The question of the exemption of goods incorporated into buildings in these circumstances actually comes up under the E and C legislation. I am told there is a specific exemption there, but it does not relate to the building. It relates to the goods, which is what the wholesale sales tax applies to—the goods incorporated in the building. It comes up at another stage.

—It is also relevant here, so I will go on to my next question concerning the goods related to the building. One of the problems we are going to face during the evening is that the issues do go across so many pieces of legislation. I again return to Senator Short's issue; this is one of the difficulties that the taxpayers who are subject to sales tax have to face in this country. —In public infrastructure projects?
