TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 30, page 18, paragraph 30(1)(a), line 27, after "traveller", insert "or eligible Australian traveller".
Clause 30, page 18, paragraph 30 (2)(a), line 36, after "traveller", insert "or eligible Australian traveller".

This again is a difficult issue. The Government is proposing to alter the current X3 system of sales tax free sales, which allows the sale of stock tax free to Australian and foreign nationals who are travelling overseas. There is currently a procedure which people have to go through. The Sales Tax Assessment Bill proposes to abolish this procedure for Australian nationals yet retain it for foreign visitors. That means that Australian nationals will be able to purchase goods for export sales tax free.

PARA.TAB: The legislation proposes to completely revolutionise the administrative procedures which used to apply and which will be so different now. The Government wants to introduce a system known as a sealed bag docket plucking system. This is the type of arrangement which applies in duty free sales. It involves 100 per cent verification of the fact that the goods are actually exported.

The Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation heard two very differing views on this issue. On the one hand, the duty free operators said that they would be happy with such an arrangement, so happy that they will even volunteer to administer it for the retailers—the jewellers and the photographic dealers—who will be affected by these changes in the administrative procedure. But those affected, the jewellers and the photographic dealers, said that they were unhappy about the cost—that is one consideration—but more than that, they were very wary of their competitors potentially being able to obtain their confidential sales information and for the duty free operators to be in control of the whole verification process.

It was really hard to make a decision on whose arguments and whose objections were the more convincing. Despite the allegations that massive rorting is going on at the moment under the X3 system, nobody has been able to provide me with evidence of this. I have requested it on several occasions.

Mr Darryl Somerville, who appeared before the Select Committee for the jewellers and the photographic dealers, made what I think is a very salient observation. He rejected the assertion that the X3 system was really open to massive rorting. He pointed out that it is much simpler to provide a false registration number—in other words, it is much simpler to fraudulently quote and get the goods tax free—than it is to provide passport details and a copy of travel documents, which the X3 system demands.

It is for these reasons and the possibility that the new system would impact adversely on some local businesses, which will lose what have been increasing sales to Australians travelling overseas, that I am opposing the introduction of a full verification system for the tax free sales of exported goods at this time.I am not opposed to change. I just do not believe at this time that the system that is being suggested is the best option. If the Government wants to bring it back, let it bring it back, but I cannot vote for its system at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the coalition indicates its position in relation to this amendment, I would like to direct about eight questions to the Parliamentary Secretary. For the purpose of those listening to this radio broadcast, the Senate is in committee debating clause 30, which involves a system applicable to eligible foreign travellers. It, essentially, affects jewellery and photo equipment throughout Australia.My first question directed to the Parliamentary Secretary is: why cannot the rules for the present X3 system that applies to these categories of goods simply be tightened rather than abandoned altogether and replaced with a complex administrative system involving costs which will mean that many retailers will be forced out of the system?

—The problem with the X3 system is that there has been substantial evidence of abuse. Senator Kernot said that we have not been able to give that evidence; I will try to give some now. That of itself does not address Senator Watson's question, but I will use it to get to that. I will answer Senator Kernot later and use a preamble to answer Senator Watson's question. When audit activity is undertaken pursuant to the X3 system—and the publicity around it—it sometimes leads to improved levels of compliance for a short while, but then it falls away again. We have evidence that there continues to be a steady flow of residents who have failed to export purchases made under the X3 system and that the intensified auditing has not had a lasting effect in preventing this from taking place. It may be helpful if I give some background information and deal with Senator Kernot's issue simultaneously. Then Senator Watson can go on with his other questions.
—I was going to ask you for the evidence in my next question.

—Let me answer question No. 2. There are several ways of doing so, but let me give these examples. Tax Office audit activity has thrown up the following examples. In Melbourne, prosecution action has been taken against 17 Australian travellers. In Brisbane, 20 per cent of travellers in one random audit had either not exported the goods or had not declared the goods for Customs purposes on returning to Australia. In Perth, up to 50 per cent of travellers purchasing targeted classes of goods in one audit campaign had not exported the goods. Compliance levels did increase once the audit activity became widely known—
—What sort of totals? Fifty per cent of what?

—I do not have that information before me. But if non-compliance of 50 per cent of a random sample is thrown up, that tends to indicate a substantial problem. It would not have been two people of whom one was found not to have complied. In Adelaide, travellers interviewed on returning to Australia admitted to not having exported goods purchased under the X3 system and, in fact, having been advised by vendors that export was not necessary. So the anecdotal evidence is right, but none of us is going to change the law on the basis of anecdotal evidence. But it does cause one concern that it is so widespread and that people are always talking about the system being rorted. From time to time articles appear purporting to confirm that.

PARA.TAB: As I say, none of us is going to change the law on the basis of mere anecdotal evidence or concern, but there is currently no mechanism, other than random checks of travellers at airports, to ensure that these goods are actually exported. Random checks are a very expensive way of doing it. It relies on successful prosecutions and the publicity associated with it. It causes difficulty at airports because there are two separate systems operating. The prosecution is sometimes a bit heavy-handed. Random checks often effectively turn up first offenders who have committed some minor offence and who would not normally be subject to the rigours of the courts for such a minor offence, although they would, of course, have to pay the tax. So if we do not apply that sort of punitive action, then we do not have the deterrent effect. So it is a system that is being abused. I have some other examples here, but I do not want to take the whole night. The audit activity tends to confirm the fears of those of us who have been hearing the anecdotal evidence about abuse.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that the Government has acted so speedily following this random sales tax audit. In other areas the Australian Taxation Office has used the medium of prosecution to provide a sufficient deterrent to avoidance and evasion, the sorts of problems that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) referred to. This sort of knee-jerk reaction so soon after an audit gives me some concern. This sort of arrangement, the X3 arrangement, is not dissimilar to what is used by primary producers in this country. Undoubtedly, an audit of certain primary producers could show that a number of them probably falsely claim. I would hope that, as a result of a random audit in that case, we do not lose that valuable exemption that can apply in a primary production area.

PARA.TAB: Given that the figures are so high, this is a matter of some concern. But I would have hoped that we could have had further time to see the results of the successful prosecution policy that was organised and to see whether there had been a substantial reduction. However, if, according to the evidence, 50 per cent of that sample—if it were a genuine sample—were found not to have complied, obviously that is a matter of some concern.

I come to my second question. But before that, I would have thought that perhaps some processes could have been put in place which would have actually tightened the existing process to overcome the difficulty that the random audit threw up. Knee-jerk reaction from the Tax Office is always a problem because it adds substantially to the volume of tax law. Unfortunately, the losers in this game are essentially the honest people who have to comply and lose this X3 benefit, which is very valuable. I submit that over 50 per cent of the sales of many retailers around the capital cities are involved in the X3 arrangement. In this time of recession it will be a substantial reduction of income—new income—to this country, because it is essentially for people going abroad.

In the interests of expediency and time, I move to my third question. What guarantee is there that the particular company that collects the money, Duty Free Securities Co. Ltd, will continue to offer the docket plucking system on an ongoing basis? If we remove that facility, the whole thing will collapse so far as the duty free stores are concerned. I believe it is relevant for the Senate to ask the Parliamentary Secretary: will the Government give an assurance that this company, in the light of the withdrawal of the X3, will continue to provide that service? I believe that it is necessary to ask that question and to continue that service if we are going to provide this sort of facility to people who have been travelling overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some very powerful arguments to suggest that it is actually in the interests of the Duty Free Securities Co. Ltd to continue to operate, and on as wide and successful a system as possible. Our advice at the moment is that there will actually be representative retailers on the board of this company. That should be ample protection.

PARA.TAB: But at the end of the day, if the assurances that we have been given are not fulfilled by this company, this company at the end of the day is dependent upon the cooperation of the FAC to continue to discharge its operation which is fundamental to the successful activities of the duty free operators in their primary function. I do not think they would wish to fall foul of the Federal Government in that way because their primary function would be being undercut.

So on the face of it there appear to be effective incentives for them to do it. It seems that it is something that they would sensibly wish to do, but if they acted in a way that was exploiting the position that we had been persuaded to take, then we would have to speak to those other government authorities with whom they relate to try to persuade them to do otherwise. I think we could be very persuasive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope the Parliamentary Secretary is very persuasive, because there is a problem for the retailers who lose the X3 arrangement—that there will now be reliance on this particular company. While the honourable senator says they may have people on the board, I ask my fourth question: if this Duty Free Securities Co. Ltd does continue to offer the service—and the Parliamentary Secretary has given an assurance that it is in its interests that it would certainly try to do that—can we have an assurance that this service will be provided at a reasonable price to the previous X3 type operators? When I say a reasonable price, I mean a price of $500 to $600, for example, which has presently been quoted. Does the Government feel that it has a role to ensure that that price is maintained? They might start off at $500 and explode to $1500 or $2000 and make it unviable for a lot of small shops.

—In fact it is that second point that has been raised with me previously; not that they might stop providing the service at all but that they might hike the price. My previous comments are principally directed towards that point rather than the continuing provision of the service. I do not regard that as a serious problem. They have to continue to provide essentially that service to keep their own operations viable. I accept that the problem is the price. My previous comments about our monitoring and capacity to be persuasive were particularly directed towards that question of the price.

—I do not see how the Parliamentary Secretary can guarantee anything in this commercial enterprise. It really concerns me that he asks us to accept assurances that there are going to be people on the board and that we would hope the price would not go up. I think it is just too open. It really worries me that we settle on this one company as a way out when we have so—
—It is a vested interest to get the others out.
—It is a bit of a vested interest.
—Move the others out.

—Yes, move the others out of it. There is another long term agenda: what is the future of duty free operators if we do not move to this new system and the retailers continue to increase their level of competition and the number of sales that they make to Australians? I just find it all too open ended, on the one hand, and a little bit too biased in favour of a vested interest on the other.
—The Government and the Tax Office do not have any particular brief for the Duty Free Securities company. It is a question of somebody providing that service.
—You are providing a monopoly.

—There is nothing in this legislation, nor is it an intention of the Government, to guarantee the company a monopoly and give it a free right to abuse it. There may well be; and there is some indication there are others who would be prepared to move in very quickly if the company were to in any way misuse its position, so we have been advised. And why not? There do not seem to be any evident barriers to entry in the normal economic sense, or any inhibitions on others undercutting the company if they were to come in and rip off the system. Market forces have their shortcomings, but they do apply in some circumstances, as we all know.

—I ask, therefore: is the Government aware that the photographic and jewellery industries represent something like 3,200 retail stores around Australia and, almost to a person, those jewellers and photographic suppliers believe that the real cost of the proposed system will be in the vicinity of $10,000 a year, ultimately, rather than the $500 to $600 that has been quoted here tonight. Would the Parliamentary Secretary like to comment?

—I am aware roughly of those figures with regard to the number of stores, or at least what has been put to me by those two industries. I have no reason to disbelieve them. They seem to be reputable people who ought to know their affairs. It is certainly of that order. It is certainly big. There are a lot of people involved. Of course, the extent to which those 3,200 stores are significantly affected by this varies. Some are affected a lot, some a little. But, yes, it is a large industry and, yes, they generally consider that it is adverse. Some of them, at least, have suggested that it could cost $10,000 to join the system. I have to say that I have not been able to establish the evidence that would justify that $10,000 figure, and on the evidence available it seems highly unlikely.

PARA.TAB: The problem we have is once again the consequences of failing to act. The consequence of failing to act is the Senate saying, `We know that the system is being abused and we are going to decide to do nothing about it'. That is not an option that can be accepted.Somebody could have come and said, `Here is plan B. Here is another way of dealing with this problem'. They have had plenty of time. Just to go back to Senator Watson's previous point about a knee-jerk reaction, the Tax Office has been putting out press releases and public statements of concern about this for nearly two years, since December 1990. This has not been sprung on anybody. It was not a case of an audit in May, an amendment in June and trying to crash it through. This is almost two years of public expressions of concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —By whom?

—By the Tax Office. There have been press releases, publicity and activity. The first press release that I have seen—it is not necessarily the first—was not later than December 1990 and there has been a regular succession of activity.

PARA.TAB: I understand the concern. The industry people came to see me. As I say, they are reputable people. I have no reason to doubt their honesty and bone fides as business people trying to do the right thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which industries?

—The photographic and the jewellery people came to see me together, for which I was duly appreciative. Getting away with one delegation instead of having two is always greatly appreciated by all of us, I am sure.
—They could have put it on video; it would save us a lot of time in this place!

—We have enough diversions without Senator Sherry helping. I have no reason to doubt that those people are reputable people who are concerned about the future of their industries and they came to see us in that proper representative role.

PARA.TAB: On balance the Government finds itself without any alternative, because we cannot say we stood idly by while there was an abuse of the tax system, which we have told everybody we knew about. We have been talking about it for two years. The public would not accept that it was too hard to fix. This is the option and we simply have to make it work.

TALK.START.PARA: —The consequence of the comment that it is too difficult to fix, particularly at a time of high unemployment and recession around Australia, is a little worrying to the Opposition. I repeat, for the purpose of this committee evaluation, the Government's preoccupation with tax avoidance is to the detriment of employment and sales in Australia.

PARA.TAB: In support of that, I submit my next question: is the Government aware that under the proposed system there will be an increased administration cost for the jewellers and retail stores involved in selling photographic items and that sales of such goods from these retail outlets can be as high as 50 per cent for some of the leading stores? Is the Government aware that a loss of 50 per cent of one's business will undoubtedly result in a loss of employment for Australian people? I submit that what will happen is that this business must inevitably be driven offshore.

We made quite a firm stand in relation to an issue relating to the previous amendment. Before this debate concludes, I ask the Government seriously to consider the implications of this on jobs at a time of recession. These jobs will be lost not only in Melbourne and Sydney—the principal areas where the foreign tourists congregate—but also in the isolated towns which have a tourist focus. Some of these stores are very dependent on overseas trade, particularly with the Japanese and others. I therefore ask the Parliamentary Secretary to consider the consequence of what is happening in terms of the loss not only of business but also of jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) is asserting that the system is being abused. Tonight is the first time that we have had any figures. On face value it does sound a little alarming. He is urging us to do something about it because the impact of not acting would be terrible. I understand that it is the job of the Australian Taxation Office to protect our revenue base, but equally I think it is our responsibility to put in place a good system. I understand that another sales tax related Bill will be introduced later in the year. It would seem to me that it might be better if somehow we can all get together and arrive at something which is more acceptable to the main players. I cannot see why we should massively disadvantage Australian retailers in this case at this time.

—There is not a lot new to add. I accept the validity of the points made by Senator Kernot and Senator Watson, and they accept the validity of mine. We all have to make our own value judgments. Let me make a few points. The Government is aware that there will be some increased administrative costs for jewellers and retailers. It is impossible to assess how much that increase will be. Some retailers have indicated that these would be such as to lead to their ceasing in this area of activity. I cannot judge whether that is the case or not.

PARA.TAB: The three of us involved in this triangular debate have had so many debates about changes to the tax system. There have been quite a few Chicken Littles who have said, `The sky will fall in if you do this', but it is still there. The fact that the last few people who said something was going to be a problem turned out not necessarily to have been lying but just to have overestimated the problem does not necessarily mean that these people are wrong. While the last few times that people have come to us and said, `If you make this change it will be a crisis' they have been wrong, it does not necessarily extrapolate that the next person who comes to us with the same argument is wrong. We have to make a judgment. But I have to confess that that does influence my judgment a little.

We are all concerned about jobs. Just to put this in perspective—and Senator Watson nods at what was probably a slip of the tongue, but I would not want it to stay on the record—this does not affect foreign tourists, of course. Senator Watson did say so and I know that he knows that that would not be the case. So we are all concerned about jobs. But Australian travellers can still buy goods tax free with this exemption, which is no less generous than that of any other country of which I am aware. Some of the Senate's most notorious travellers are not here at present; so I cannot check with their expertise in these matters—

TALK.START.PARA: —They're travelling!

—As they probably are all out of the country I have had to settle for a paper assessment. My understanding is that the operation of the sealed bag system has a long history in Australia, although it has not been operating for so long that it has been changed here, and that it is the predominant system overseas for domestic travellers. So this is not some unique thing that we are imposing on Australians. We really are saying that we have tried to be more liberal, if the Opposition will pardon the use of the term, but it may be that it has not been successful.

PARA.TAB: Looking at my notes I see just a couple of other indications of the nature of the problem. These do not go so much to magnitude because they do not have numbers, but they are examples. I just mention them to reinforce the reason for our concern. There have been a number of successful prosecutions against travellers who have admitted being advised by retailers that tax-free purchases may be made without any requirement to export the goods. There have been two separate Australian Federal Police raids, from which possible prosecutions are pending, where shop assistants have signed the X3 certificate on behalf of customers who have had no knowledge at all of the requirement to export the goods. We have had a successful prosecution in Western Australia and some evidence of more sustained activity where shop assistants and/or proprietors have added goods to the bottom of invoices after purchasers have left the store; shop assistants have then purchased goods at tax-free prices.

In these debates we all must be careful that we do not smear a lot of honest people. The overwhelming majority of people working in these industries and managing these businesses are honest people. When giving examples we must ensure that people do not run off and say, `The industry is full of crooks'. No-one is contending that and certainly, in the very few instances where I have been making such purchases, it has been done in accordance with the law. So certainly the majority are clearly honest citizens. I just want to make that qualification because, when we start laying out a series of concerns, it can easily lead to misapprehension about the industry as a whole.

We even had a successful prosecution against an individual who was habitually purchasing goods by obtaining an overseas air ticket, purchasing goods tax free and then getting a refund on the ticket. This particular person was not only doing that on a regular basis but also then advertising the goods through the Trading Post and selling them. This was a tax avoidance-driven business.

So it is a source of serious concern. The alternative arguments are not without merit. But the sorts of experiences that I have exampled have led the Government, after a couple of years of examination, to conclude that we had to act on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Parliamentary Secretary for his explanation. Perhaps it would have been reassuring if those who were in default had been explained to us in terms of a percentage of the total audit—and I noticed that the Parliamentary Secretary used earlier the figure of 50 per cent, which was quite persuasive. Nevertheless, it is useful and helpful information.

PARA.TAB: I now move away from the employment consequences and the fact that a lot of these jobs will be driven offshore and go to the monopoly position of the Duty Free Securities Co. Ltd, which was essentially set up by the duty free stores arrangement. What guarantee is there that Duty Free Securities Co. Ltd will not use the information available from the docket plucking to their own advantage?

We are not dealing with a government instrumentality; we are not dealing with the FAC. We are dealing with a commercial organisation which surely has a vested interest—as I think it was financed by the member duty free stores—in not gathering that information which could prove to be of advantage to its principal owners.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Kernot said it first and Senator Watson said it then: this is not a government agency. So it changes the nature of the guarantees that one can give. We can guarantee what we will do and we can give a pretty strong indication of what a group of which we are members will do. But when the body about which we are speaking is further removed, it is beyond my capacity to give someone a guarantee. I can give a very strong indication of my understanding of the declared intention of the people involved. I only reiterate the not insignificant, but less than perfect, capacity of the Government to influence the way these people act.

PARA.TAB: Commercial confidentiality is an issue which this company would have to be concerned about at the moment because the duty free store owners do not want to give an advantage to each other. There is a fair bit of competition in that industry too, so they would want to make sure that there is a system in place which will protect their respective confidentiality from their competitors. It would seem, on the face of it, that the advice that there is such a system in operation at the moment is logical and probable.

All I can say in addition to that is I am advised that the Tax Office intends to seek to develop administrative arrangements of the new system in consultation with representatives of the affected industry groups which would then be prescribed by regulations before the law started. In the consultative process we would want to consider issues which might raise the possibility of plucked dockets being mailed from the airport directly to the retailers, who would undertake their own matching process. We would seek, through the Tax Office, to be influential; but I cannot give a guarantee because it is not something the Government itself will be doing.

I should have said right at the start that of course the issue has been raised with me at the Committee hearings and in submissions, so we are all aware of it. I cannot give a guarantee, but I can give a very strong indication of our expectation and our intention to act to seek to have that expectation implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —That explanation was really quite persuasive. I hope that during the audit there will be a check to ensure that there is direct remittance of that sort of information in order to overcome one group taking advantage of information supplied by another under this monopolistic arrangement.

PARA.TAB: My final question really comes back to the core issue which is the reason for the particular amendment. Why should retailers be made to pay tax on goods not exported when they have accepted certificates in good faith from purchasers who then deliberately defraud the system by not taking the goods out of the country? Why should the legislation not be amended so that the liability to pay the tax avoided is on the person who avoided the tax—that is, the traveller—rather than the honest trader?

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice—it is logical, and I was not aware of it before—is that a similar system operates in the customs law. There, the obligation to pay the government remains with the store owners but they enter into contractual arrangements with the customers. It is their practice that, to make the purchase, the customers have to enter into a contract with the store owners, so that if they act in such a way that duty becomes payable, the obligation is with the customers, not the stores. It is not the law that prescribes that. The law has a relationship, as one would normally expect, between the store owners and customs, but there has developed a framework of contracts which would be capable of straightforward extension and operation in this circumstance.

—The Senate has before it the amendments moved by the Democrats in relation to eligible travellers which affect jewellery and photographic equipment. This committee stage has been quite valuable. While the Opposition is disappointed that the Government has not applied more strenuous efforts to simply tightening the system, known as X3, rather than abandoning it and throwing additional administrative costs on, essentially, the jewellers and photographic equipment retailers, nevertheless, we had been persuaded that, given the role of a Senate rather than a House of Representatives, as a responsible Senate—and I ask the Government to remember this because next year we hope it will be acting with the same degree of responsibility—it is not our role to disturb a Budget and all Australians on all sides of politics have a responsibility of ensuring the integrity of the revenue measures that are taken.

PARA.TAB: We are not in a position to independently evaluate the extent of the avoidance. Naturally, we have to accept in good faith the 50 per cent evasion figures that have been quoted. Therefore, in the circumstances, we will not be in a position to accept the amendments, valid as they appear, prima facie, from the Democrats. I regret that decision.
Amendments negatived.
Clause agreed to.

Clauses 31 to 50—by leave—taken together. Senator WATSON (Tasmania) (9.58 p.m.)—My particular interest involves clause 31, page 19. It involves containers for use by removalists. I understand that these will now come under the heading of `application for own use' and containers will become Australian used goods for which no tax exemption is available, regardless of the exempt status of the end user.

Under the old sales tax provisions, exemption was granted by the first schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act—items 74, 78, 81 and 110—for the various uses to which these containers were put. Therefore, I have a series of four questions that I would like to submit to the Parliamentary Secretary. Firstly, will not this impact severely on the exempt status of end users, including Commonwealth departments such as the Department of Administrative Services, charities and local governments?

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about the use of these containers for activities exclusively within Australia or for export?

—My question is directly related to containers used within Australia and not for export. I understand the export position. That is perfectly clear. The problem arises in relation to the use of containers by removalists in Australia. I believe this could have a severe impact on exempt status end users, which include Government departments such as the Department of Administrative Services, certain charities and certain local governments. Is that true?

—This is a complex question and not one that has been raised with me before. If a removalist uses a container to move goods, for example, for a benevolent institution within Australia, it is my understanding that there would be no exemption under the existing law, nor under the proposed law. There would be no new detriment, although there would also be no new benefit. As I understand it, the circumstances are unchanged.

—Perhaps the removalists were working under false information. I refer the Parliamentary Secretary to the first schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, items 74, 78, 81 and 110. That is past history and I have been encouraged to speed up the process. Naturally, I must express disappointment. I believe DAS and other people will be the losers.

PARA.TAB: My second question is: is there a further problem in that should government departments such as DAS and other exempt bodies undertake their own removals, private enterprise will be placed at a severe disadvantage? This has the potential to impact substantially on industries which are heavy users of containers and packaging. To some extent, that question could have been circumvented by the Parliamentary Secretary's response. I think there is a problem for those people and I think that we as an Opposition have a responsibility to draw it to the Parliamentary Secretary's attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the basis of my advice, I do not think there is a problem, but I have just made it clear to the representatives of the Tax Office that I want this to be very tightly monitored so that if it does not operate as I have been advised and as I have advised the Senate, and therefore there is some detriment, we will be able to act quickly to rectify it. I am not aware of the problem. It has not been drawn to my attention before. It does not seem to be the case, on the face of it, but I give the honourable senator an undertaking that we will have a very hard look at it to make sure; and if a problem arises, we will act quickly.

—My question is also a related question that has a reference to the exemptions and classifications. Again I think it has a relevance to clause 31. Did the Government intend to remove this sales tax exemption from cardboard boxes, bubble wrap, dividers and other packaging material used by companies to package and protect the furniture and personal effects of its clients? I understand that many of the clients of the Department of Administrative Services will be affected. Is that correct?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is, of course, a very similar issue. I cannot give Senator Watson a clear indication of what every contractor to DAS does at the moment as to whether they regard their goods as exempt or not. The situation with regard to DAS itself will not be changed by this. I think it is really the same answer as before, but I will have to keep an eye on that and let Senator Watson know.
—Thank you.

PARA.TAB: Clauses 31 to 50 agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause 50A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 50, page 25, insert the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Agreements relating to eligible short-term leases

PARA.TAB: (a)the dealing is the granting of an eligible short-term lease of the goods; and
(b)the exempt percentage specified in the agreement under subsection 15A(2) is less than 100%;

SPEECH.PARA: then the exempt part is the taxable value multiplied by the exempt percentage.

PARA.TAB: (a)the goods that are the subject of the taxable dealing are covered by an agreement under subsection 15A(3) or (4), and are for use exclusively as mentioned in that subsection; and
(b)the exempt percentage specified in the agreement is less than 100%;

SPEECH.PARA: then the exempt part is the taxable value multiplied by the exempt percentage.".

TALK.START.PARA: —Could Senator McMullan explain Government amendment No. 8 to the Senate?

—It is the proposed new clause 50A concerning agreements relating to eligible short term leases. Proposed new clause 50A would be inserted at page 25 after clause 50. It is the third of the three we were talking about before concerning leases.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I may suggest that we now take the remainder of the Bill as a whole. There are only Government amendments remaining and if we take the remainder of the Bill as a whole honourable senators can speak to any part of it.

—To assist the Chair, the only concerns the Opposition have relate to a series of questions about the general anti-avoidance provisions. There have been substantive improvements to the original general anti-avoidance provisions. We welcome them, but we still have one or two outstanding questions. That is the only issue in relation to the rest of the Bill that I wish to raise.
—Have we actually dealt yet with Government amendment No. 5?
—Yes. We have dealt with all Government amendments up to No. 8.
—I seek leave to make just a couple of comments about Government amendment No. 5.
—If we take the remainder of the Bill as a whole, you can still do it.

PARA.TAB: Remainder of Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Before Senator Short speaks, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 82, page 38, paragraph (1)(g), line 12, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraphs:

PARA.TAB: "(g)granting an eligible long-term lease, an eligible short-term lease or a lease that will be exempted by section 32;
(h)using the goods exclusively as mentioned in subsection 15A(3) or (4), while the goods are covered by an agreement under that subsection.".

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 83, page 39, paragraph (1)(c), line 10, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraphs:

PARA.TAB: "(c)granting an eligible long-term lease, an eligible short-term lease or a lease that will be exempted by section 32;
(ca)using the goods exclusively as mentioned in subsection 15A(3) or (4), while the goods are covered by an agreement under that subsection.".

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 92 and 93, pages 41 and 42, line 20 (page 41) to line 41 (page 42), omit the clauses, substitute the following clauses:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Division allows cancellation of tax benefits under avoidance schemes

PARA.TAB: "92.(1) This Division allows the Commissioner to cancel tax benefits obtained under schemes to which the Division applies.
"(2) Section 93 explains what it means to obtain a tax benefit under a scheme to which this Division applies.
"(3) Section 93A sets out the way in which the Commissioner may cancel a tax benefit.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Obtaining a tax benefit under a scheme to which this Division applies

PARA.TAB: "93.(1) A taxpayer obtains a tax benefit under a scheme to which this Division applies that has been entered into or carried out by a person or persons (whether or not the taxpayer) if:
(a)the taxpayer has obtained a tax benefit that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the taxpayer would not have obtained if the scheme had not been entered into or carried out; or

(ii)the taxpayer could reasonably be expected not to have obtained if the scheme had not been entered into or carried out (taking into account, among other relevant matters, any things that did not actually happen but could reasonably be expected to have happened if the scheme had not been entered into or carried out); and

PARA.TAB: (b)having regard to the matters set out in subsection (2), it would be concluded that the scheme was entered into, or carried out, by all or any of the parties for the purpose or dominant purpose of obtaining a tax benefit for any person (whether or not that person is the taxpayer and whether or not that person is one of the parties).
"(2) For the purposes of paragraph (1)(b), the matters to have regard to are:
(a)the manner in which the scheme was entered into or carried out;
(b)the form and substance of the scheme;
(c)the time at which the scheme was entered into and the length of the period during which the scheme was carried out;
(d)the result in relation to the operation of the sales tax law that, but for this Division, would be achieved by the scheme;
(e)any change in the financial position of the taxpayer that has resulted, or may reasonably be expected to result, from the scheme;

(f)any change in the financial position of any person who has, or has had, any connection (whether of a business, family or other nature) with the taxpayer, being a change that has resulted, will result or may reasonably be expected to result, from the scheme;
(g)any other consequence for the taxpayer, or for any person referred to in paragraph (f), of the scheme having been entered into or carried out;
(h)the nature of any connection (whether of a business, family or other nature) between the taxpayer and any person referred to in paragraph (f);

SPEECH.PARA: but the matters do not include the actual purpose for which any person entered into or carried out the scheme.

PARA.TAB: "(3) This Division applies to:
(a)a scheme that was entered into after 26 May 1992; or
(b)a scheme that began to be carried out after 26 May 1992 (not including a scheme that was entered into on or before 26 May 1992).
"(4) In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: `carrying out' includes carrying out together with one or more other persons;
`dominant purpose', in relation to several purposes, means a purpose that is dominant when compared to all the remaining purposes taken together;
`scheme' includes:
(a)an arrangement that is not legally enforceable;

PARA.TAB: (b)a course of conduct;
(c)a unilateral scheme or course of conduct;

SPEECH.PARA: `tax benefit' means:

PARA.TAB: (a)any reduction in liability to tax; or
(b)any increase in an entitlement to a credit.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Commissioner may cancel tax benefits obtained under schemes to which Division applies

PARA.TAB: "93A.(1) If a taxpayer obtains a tax benefit under a scheme to which this Division applies, the Commissioner may make an assessment that cancels the tax benefit.
"(2) The Commissioner may, in the assessment, do all or any of the following:
(a)determine, for the purpose of cancelling the tax benefit, that particular things are to be treated as not having happened;
(b)determine, for the purpose of cancelling the tax benefit, that particular things are to be treated as having been done by a different person or to have happened at a different time;
(c)determine, for the purpose of cancelling the tax benefit, that particular things that did not actually happen are to be treated as having happened and, where appropriate:

TAB.TAB: (i)to have been done by a particular person; or
(ii)to have happened at a particular time.

PARA.TAB: "(3) An amount that is payable by a taxpayer because of the cancellation of an entitlement to a credit is to be treated as if it were an amount of tax payable by the taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: [The main effect of treating the amount as if it were tax is to apply the collection and recovery rules in Part 5.]

PARA.TAB: "(4) Notice of the assessment may be included in any other notice of assessment under this Act that relates to the same person.

"(5) An amount payable under an assessment that is made under this section becomes due for payment on the day specified in the notice of assessment. The day must be at least 14 days after the date of issue of the assessment.".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee for allowing me to make a couple of comments on amendment No. 5, which relates to clause 19, and in particular that aspect which deals with the concerns expressed by several submissions to the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation—and I think separate representations were made to the Tax Office as well—about the extent to which design was to be caught up in clause 19(3) of the original Bill in relation to external costs.

PARA.TAB: The Bill as originally drafted included various elements of design in relation to the manufacture and development of goods. That was a matter of serious concern to the Design Institute of Australia and others who were involved in the design side of the production chain, particularly for manufactured goods. The way in which the Bill was originally drafted brought in design, which in many ways can legitimately be regarded as a service. It extended the wholesale sales tax at least to that service and, therefore, moved away from the underlying principle of the wholesale sales tax—that it is a sales tax on goods.

As I understand it, the amendment that the Government has now introduced overcomes that problem. I would seek some comment from Senator McMullan in relation to this matter. My query arises from the press statement of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) dated 11 August which foreshadowed these amendments. As far as external costs were concerned, the press statement said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills seek to bring into the sales tax base product design and development costs incurred by persons who are past the traditional wholesale taxing point (e.g. where design costs are incurred by a retailer who contracts out the manufacture of the goods). While there is general public recognition of the need to tax these costs, a number of practical difficulties in applying the new provisions have been identified. In the light of these concerns, the Government has decided that the full external costs provision should not be proceeded with at this time in order to allow a further examination of the issues identified. However, the proposed external costs arrangements will continue to apply to royalty payments, except that liability will be limited to the value of the royalty payment.
I am not seeking to comment on that latter part in relation to royalties.

PARA.TAB: There was a continuing uncertainty in relation to the proposed treatment of design and development costs, but particularly design, in the wording of the Treasurer's statement of 11 August. This matter was considered in some detail by the Select Committee, which noted in paragraph 29 of its report:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the comments by Senator McMullan that there is not at this time any intention to introduce further legislation to change that situation.
This is now incorporated in the amendments. The report went on:
The Committee believes that so far as possible the uncertainty about future reviews should be removed.

I hope Senator McMullan will be able to give the Committee of the Whole and those who were concerned about this issue some greater assurance than I think has been forthcoming to date as to the Government's future intention in relation to the application of wholesale sales tax to product design and development costs.

PARA.TAB: This matter was left uncertain in the Treasurer's statement. The possibility of further changes was foreshadowed because the statement said that the reason the Government was not going to proceed at this stage was simply `to allow a further examination of the issues identified'. That is an unsatisfactory way in which to leave it. I hope Senator McMullan might be able to give those who are legitimately concerned about this some assurance as to the future intent of the Government. I hope that the future intent will be that the Government will not proceed along the lines that it had included in its original Bill, and that the decision not to proceed will be a permanent decision. I hope we are not just in a holding situation pending, to use the Treasurer's words, further examination.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Short said, we had a significant discussion of this matter on 13 August in the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation. I cannot go beyond what I said on that occasion. The Government and the Treasurer have said that there is general public recognition of the need to tax these goods. Given that that is our view, it would be wrong for us to say, `But we are never going to do anything about it'. What I can say is that this decision not to proceed is not a temporary matter. It is not just for the next few days or weeks or months. There is no legislation in process, there is no active review under way that should lead to an imminent change and there is no current intention so to act.

PARA.TAB: If we did not think there was a problem we would not have proposed the first amendment in the first place. We accept that that amendment may have caused more problems than it solved so we are not proceeding down that track. It would be ideal to be able to say that this will never be reviewed or changed again, but it would be an unrealistic assurance and a false comfort to people because it may well be that at some stage in the future we will need to come back to it. To those in the industry who seek to examine the Hansard for an assurance, I can mainly draw their attention to those things which I said in the Committee on 13 August at page 166 of that Hansard. I confirm that is our view.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan for that answer. Just to clarify the matter a little further, the words that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) used in his statement were that the proposals should not be proceeded with at this time in order to allow a further examination of the issues identified. I want to get clear, if I can, whether there is any further examination being undertaken now or in prospect in the foreseeable future.
—No.

—I have a series of questions relating to the general anti-avoidance provisions. I remind Senator McMullan of some words which I thought he might have felt comforting at the time when he addressed the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation in relation to the general anti-avoidance provisions. Having read those very carefully, I note there is nothing in that speech on the amendment nor in the supplementary explanatory memorandum saying that the general anti-avoidance provision is not intended to apply to ordinary commercial dealings.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, I ask, does the Government concede the need for such a provision, and is there any proposal to establish one, particularly in the light of the assurance of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) that the general anti-avoidance provisions are designed to operate against avoidance schemes of a blatant, artificial or contrived kind? I also ask—because these are related questions—have the concerns with regard to ordinary commercial arrangements been drawn to the attention of the Treasurer as well as to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), and will there be a statement in the House or the Senate to confirm or clarify the operations of the general anti-avoidance provisions in relation to normal commercial dealings?

Will not the first example of a scheme identified by the Tax Office, which is a blatant, artificial and contrived arrangement, be defeated on ordinary principles and, thus, not require the general anti-avoidance provisions to deal with that? Perhaps that series of questions could be answered en bloc.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to give a general response, and if I have not covered all the points that Senator Watson has raised, he might then want to come back to some specifically.

PARA.TAB: I said this in summing up the second reading but, given that it was 4.15 a.m., there were not thousands of people paying the most rapt attention. It was a great speech, but not everybody was listening. I say again what I said then about the general anti-avoidance provision. This goes to some of Senator Watson's concerns. It may not cover them all, and I will see what else there may be that he needs to have answered.

We have been asked, as Senator Watson says, to clarify whether the general anti-avoidance provision will apply to ordinary commercial arrangements. The answer is that it will not. However, as these words are inexact in legal terms, and their scope is uncertain, the new provision, like its counterpart in the income tax law, is designed to apply where, on an objective view of the particular arrangement and its surrounding circumstances, it would be concluded that the arrangement was entered into for the sole or dominant purpose of obtaining a tax benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I may add a second tier of complication. I thank Senator McMullan. That was a helpful and reassuring response which the sales tax community will appreciate. Is it not the case that the second example of a scheme is, in fact, a normal commercial dealing? For example, I refer to the practice of a business choosing to pay an advance lump sum for industrial property rights. Such lump sums are commonly paid for both the cinema and video rights to a film. How can this be a scheme when the exhibition of a film in a cinema is not subject to sales tax and the arrangement applied also to video rights before videos became taxable? I think it is desirable that these normal commercial dealings be brought within the ambit of the general anti-avoidance provisions.

—If the advance payment related to a royalty or something that was not defined as goods and, therefore, to which the wholesale sales tax did not apply, of course there would be no avoidance by definition. If it was an advance payment that led to sales tax not having to be paid in circumstances where, otherwise, it would have been, and there were no other circumstances to indicate that the arrangement had been entered into for other purposes, then one would have thought that on the face of it there was some implication.

PARA.TAB: It is for the courts to decide, not us. We pass the law—and I made these comments at the end of the second reading—and give some guidance to the courts as to what the Government intends the clauses to mean, and I think it is what the Parliament would intend the goods to mean. We do not want to get too far into detail about plan A or scheme B, but those are some of the principles that would be involved without pursuing the example in too much detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the question because I think it demonstrates some fundamental problems in relation to the sales tax as opposed to the GST, which relates to goods and services. In this situation, it relates to rights to screen a film in a cinema or to playing a video. Given the lateness of the hour, I will not pursue that issue but instead move to a more general question.

PARA.TAB: Why do the amended general anti-avoidance provisions list exclusively matters which the Commissioner has to take into account before exercising his powers to counsel a tax benefit, when they do not expressly include normal commercial dealings as being beyond the scope of the general anti-avoidance provisions? I thank the Parliamentary Secretary for his assurance, but point out to the Senate that it probably would have been more helpful to have had that within the provisions of that exhaustive list. I believe that the tax paying community, the lawyers and the courts will take into account the explanation of the Parliamentary Secretary. I thank him for it.

This is the conclusion of the first of several Bills that we are debating tonight. Undoubtedly to the listening audience this has been a very boring debate, but it is an example of the thoroughness with which the Senate is required to examine Bills because of their potential application on particular people around Australia. I apologise for the perhaps boring technical nature of the debate. It is an essential measure of the process of evaluation approval and the system of checks and balances which we believe is healthy in a democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of comments in support of Senator Watson's remarks in relation to the general anti-avoidance provisions. Senator Watson very rightly raised the question of why the exclusion of normal commercial transactions is not specifically included in the legislation. Perhaps Senator McMullan can inform us about that before we conclude this debate.

PARA.TAB: Some of the points of real concern that were expressed about the original Bills and the general anti-avoidance provisions have been picked up in the amendments. In particular, the amendments will clarify the circumstances in which the general anti-avoidance provisions will apply; that is very important. I also believe that there has been a considerable improvement made by virtue of changing the definition of `dominant purpose' to refer to a purpose which is dominant against all the other purposes combined. The original Bills had the definition of `dominant purpose' as just the most important or the largest single purpose, even though that purpose may have been only 5 per cent or less of the total purposes. That is a highly desirable change. It is a matter of concern that it was not defined that way right from the outset.

The other point I wish to raise with Senator McMullan is the fact that great concern was expressed at the hearings of the Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation by both members of the Committee and a large number of those who made submissions to the Committee about the wording of what was in the original Bill's clause 92(2) but which in the amendments has become clause 93A(2). I remind the Senate that that definition relates to the things that the Commissioner can do in the course of making an assessment which cancels a tax benefit that may have been obtained.
Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to an order made earlier this day, I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was referring to new clause 93A(2), which replaces the old clause 92(2), in which is contained the things that the Commissioner can do in the course of making an assessment that cancels the tax benefit that has been obtained under schemes to which this particular division applies. I remind the Committee, because the words have not changed—only the ordering has changed within the Bills—that the Commissioner may, according to this drafting, do all or any of the following:

PARA.TAB: (a) determine, for the purpose of cancelling the tax benefit, that particular things are to be treated as not having happened;
(b) determine, for the purpose of cancelling the tax benefit, that particular things are to be treated as having been done by a different person or to have happened at a different time;
(c) determine, for the purpose of cancelling the tax benefit, that particular things that did not actually happen are to be treated as having happened and, where appropriate:

TAB.TAB: (i) to have been done by a particular person; or
(ii) to have happened at a particular time.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure Senator McMullan is well aware, as we are on this side of the chamber, that that drafting has caused a great deal of concern. It is positively Orwellian in its tones. It gives the Commissioner an enormous exercise of power of interpretation to be able to determine that particular things are to be treated as not having happened, or that particular things are to be treated as having been done by a different person or to have happened at a different time, and that particular things that did not actually happen are to be treated as having happened. They are extraordinarily wide terms to have in the legislation.

PARA.TAB: To the extent that the legislation has been amended to include the range of criteria that the Commissioner has to take into account, it is argued that that does provide some offset to the Orwellian nature of that drafting, but the fact is that that drafting, which was violently opposed by a very wide range of witnesses and which attracted a great deal of attention from a wide range of organisations, particularly in the business world when it was first published and became known, is still there. I believe that that is a matter of considerable concern.

I ask Senator McMullan why that wording is still there. Is he not aware of the continuing concern that there will be about that matter? Does he not agree that the wording does indeed give a single person—in this instance the Taxation Commissioner—enormous powers of interpretation which take the role and the ability of this Parliament to monitor and determine tax law very much out of its hands? We all realise that Taxation Commissioners have to have areas of discretion—there is no question about that—but this is a huge area of discretion. It is a matter of considerable concern. I would appreciate Senator McMullan explaining to the Committee why that is so; why that drafting has not changed; and also the earlier point that I made following Senator Watson's comment about why the exclusion of normal commercial transactions is not included in the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do accept one part of what both Senator Short and Senator Watson said, although not all the others. I do accept that there is a lot of industry concern. I have perhaps not had as many people speak to me as have spoken to Senator Short, but a lot of people have spoken to me. I have been to seminars about the legislation and I have had discussions with distinguished members of the professions who are concerned.

PARA.TAB: My expectation is that it will prove to be much more worrying in the expectation than in the implementation. Certainly the interpretative guide that has been given through the second reading debate and this consideration will be of assistance to the courts and a reassurance to the profession. With that guidance and with the wording as it actually is, people will see that its application will not be the bogey that there is concern about at the moment. That concern falls into that category which is always very hard to deal with, that is, where we have to prove what is not going to happen. They say, `Here is a fear. Prove it will not happen'. That is an impossible brief.

Firstly, I refer to why the term `ordinary commercial arrangements' is not included. I reinforce the point that it is also not included in part 4A of the Income Tax Act. Although I repeat that the provision will not apply to ordinary commercial arrangements, those are not precise legal terms and we have designed a provision to give effect to that intention, rather than merely stating it in a way that would otherwise be very inexact.

The reconstruction power in the general anti-avoidance provision is nothing more than a clear restatement of the reconstruction power that was always intended to be present in part 4A. It merely sets out clearly the type of reconstruction that might be necessary in the implementation of a part 4A equivalent within the Sales Tax Act. Really, it is trying to make clear what reconstruction may have to take place.

There has been some misunderstanding. The amendment does not go as far as Senator Short might prefer, or as some in the industry might prefer. I accept that his view reflects the view of others also. But the amendment, plus the indication of government intent in the second reading and reiterated tonight, will go some way towards easing the concerns. I believe that the practical implementation will provide the remaining reassurance.
Amendments agreed to.
Remainder of Bill, as amended to, agreed to.

Clause 3.
Amendments (by Senator McMullan)—by leave—proposed:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 2, subclause (2), after definition of "agriculture", insert the following definition:
"`always-exempt person' means a person whose use of goods of whatever kind is always covered by an exemption Item, regardless of the way in which the goods are used by the person;".
Clause 3, page 4, subclause (2), definition of "qualifying goods", after paragraph (a), insert the following paragraphs:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 4, subclause (2), at the end of the subclause, add the following definition:

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of brief comments in relation to that. Again this was a matter on which a lot of evidence was taken by the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation. The Government foreshadowed these amendments the night before the Select Committee met and, therefore, there was a problem as far as there being a clear understanding that the amendments that the Government had foreshadowed were going to cover many of the concerns that were raised in the submissions that the Select Committee had received.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, the amendments that have been made essentially cover the problems that were raised with the original clauses. But, in effect, having gone back to where we were with this matter of deemed manufacturer, it does leave what is regarded by many as an inequity as far as it applies to certain of the major oil companies. A submission was made to the Committee—and I know it has been considered by the Government—by Caltex whereby, as a result of the operational structure of the Caltex company and, I think, another oil company—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will accept the Democrat amendments.

—That will truncate my comments, but let me just get them briefly on the record. The coalition has been concerned that there was an inequity as far as Caltex was concerned. The Senate Select Committee recognised that as well. It made the very important point that the taxation laws should be such that businesses are able to operate in an efficient manner and still be entitled to the advantages of the broader business inputs exemptions, without having to structure themselves as companies in order to take those benefits when that structuring may well cut across the most efficient operations and structuring of the companies. The fact that that will be picked up is to be welcomed. I wanted to raise that point because I think we are all concerned about it—certainly, the coalition was concerned about it. It is not just this point, but the important point of principle, that needs to be recognised.

—In early discussions with the Government I understood that it was independently going to take up this amendment. It is regrettable that that has not taken place. Therefore, the Opposition will be supporting the amendment raised by the Australian Democrats.
—I haven't moved it yet!

—We have a complication because we have jumped a subsection in coming on to the deemed manufacturer provisions. I welcome this initiative because I think it is essential to ensure in the national interest, if I can use that term, that we do have a level playing field. It was unfortunate under the old legislation that the oil companies that had an Australian shareholding had a greater exposure to sales tax than the other oil companies operating in competition, which were basically those which were wholly owned overseas.

PARA.TAB: I must, of course, venture to declare to the Senate that I have a vested interest in this outcome, I suppose. I have a small shareholding in Caltex and Pioneer, which is the parent company for Ampol, both of which will be beneficiaries under this legislation. For that reason, it is always difficult to move amendments—not that it would be of such a minor nature not to be a material one. I think in the interests of disclosure I had to make that statement. Certainly, not in my own interest but in the national interest, I deem that we should be encouraging Australian ownership in these vital ventures and, essentially, we should not tilt the sales tax law so as to adversely affect Australian ventures which have a high content of local ownership. I support the initiative. I am pleased that the Government will be accepting it, and it has the endorsement of the Opposition.
Amendments agreed to.

Senator Watson summed up what I was going to say. I think the important thing about these amendments is that they address the competitive problems of local Australian industry and they do it without the need for costly restructuring. I think it is a better way to go and I thank the Opposition for its support.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, I indicate that the Government will be accepting these amendments. I have had discussions with representatives of Ampol and Caltex. I suppose I should give a little of the history—although everybody here knows about it, so I will be brief. The distinction that is in the legislation as proposed is merely the extension of the existing discrimination. We sought to eliminate it in a manner which put everybody back to their positions, but that caused even more agitation. So we pulled back to half-way and I think we have now been persuaded as to the fundamental point.

PARA.TAB: We do not want this clause to operate contrary to our fundamental policy: namely, we do not want companies to restructure their operations for tax purposes; we want them to structure their operations for business purposes. This amendment seems, on the face of it, to achieve that objective. Therefore, we will support it, as does the Opposition, and may we can get on with it quickly.
Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 3 contained a number of proposals and, essentially, the committee leapfrogged over one issue that I wished to draw attention to. PARA.TAB: It seems that further amendments may be necessary, despite the undertaking by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on 11 August with regard to sales tax on new goods donated to charities. TALK.START.PARA: —I have a problem in relation to item 23 of schedule 1, page 26—activities relating to printing. We have typesetting equipment used by commercial printers. I have a series of questions. How did the inequalities in this area tally with the Government's stated policy of promoting local book production? Secondly, will the legislation be workable? For example, consider an Australian publisher which has a different section printed by different legal entities, not necessarily the publisher.
—Is this an Australian newspaper?

—Commercial publishers. Will not the way in which the legislation is drafted in this respect create a great deal of uncertainty and chaos in the industry? If I may, I will submit a number of scenarios which I believe could be a problem. Publishers will need to be experts in sales tax law and copyright law and to conduct a detailed analysis of each article which is produced for inclusion in a newspaper or magazine. The fewer the divisions of labour, the greater the problem. The more efficient the use of equipment by shift work, the fewer the available exemptions and the greater the problems. For example, a senior editor or journalist who creates and finalises the process himself is denied an exemption, while equipment used to check and subedit the work of less efficient persons is exempt. That makes a mockery of this clever country. We are trying to introduce new technologies of which the newspaper industry is at the forefront, and here we have a sales tax impediment. I seek a response from the Parliamentary Secretary to those three questions.
—My response is that in the short term, in the terms of this Bill, this is not something we are changing, as Senator Watson would know.
—It is simplification, to bring us up to date as the clever country.

—I am not sure that we would regard it as a simplification. As Senator Watson knows, this is not mainly an exemptions and classifications exercise. We have done some where it fitted in with the simplification structure. There has been some lobbying by newspapers seeking this exemption, as there was when the change was made. It is not our intention to agree to it. When the amendment was originally made and we made the changes about computerised equipment, we gave consideration to this matter and did not extend it to journalists and authors. At this stage, we do not see any reason to change our view on it. The only new piece of information Senator Watson gave me is that this will be a difficulty for publishers. I always thought publishers of newspapers knew everything about everything. They always seem to act as if they do.

—Everything about everything except sales tax law. Even the publishers do not know much about that. I fall into the same category. I raise this issue as a serious one. Although the Parliamentary Secretary will not address the issue tonight, I would hope that, in the interests of making this a clever country and ensuring that newspapers and book publishers can take advantage of the latest technology, this sensible suggestion will be implemented.

PARA.TAB: In line with the previous questions in relation to the newspaper industry, some of us are avid book readers and have the national interest at heart, and we would like to see these books produced in Australia. I draw attention to one of my distinguished sisters-in-law, who has produced quite an expert volume of which, I understand, Prime Minister Keating has bought a number of copies. Much of that, unfortunately, had to be printed outside the country, although it related exclusively to Australian fauna and flora.

That is the background to my next question. What is the rationale of the book bounty program, which seeks to promote local production, and of the legislation, which seeks to deny exemption for equipment used to carry out that local production? I think it is appalling to have these laws. While the Government does not intend to change it now, this recession is the appropriate time to draw attention to the problems of the book bounty program.

There is a contradiction in that the higher the quality of the publication—the sort of publication I was referring to; a publication that sells for $60 or $70—the fewer the sales tax exemptions that are available. I am sure Mrs Anna Meike Mein would endorse the comments that have been made.

Has the Tax Office made any recommendations in connection with typesetting equipment? The current legislation provides exemption for typesetting equipment used by commercial printers, and this new legislation denies this exemption. I seek the Parliamentary Secretary's response.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the name of the book?

—It is very unfair of Senator Watson to keep us all in such suspense. I suppose not knowing the title of the book will save those of us who cannot afford $60 books from wanton extravagance. I do not think I want to create a precedent by advising of the recommendations the Tax Office might have made to the Government about anything, but I can say that the Government has at this stage no intention of introducing any changes in this area. I am aware of the issues; the Treasurer is aware of the issues, and as far as I know there is no intention to change. The matter may come up for review some time in the future, but I do not want to hold out any hope or expectation to those who are pursuing it. At this stage it is not our intention to pursue any amendments on this matter.

—That is somewhat disappointing. Essentially, the previous Prime Minister wanted Australia to be at the forefront of technology, wanted Australia to be the clever country, and I would have hoped that the new Prime Minister (Mr Keating) would adopt that same philosophy in ensuring that our tax laws do not inhibit modern, efficient, up-to-date manufacturers in using the latest technology. With regard to typesetting equipment used by publishers, why is it that manufacturers are entitled to exemption for equipment used in creating designs and formula for production as well as virtually all equipment used in planning and development while publishers are still denied exemption to certain typesetting equipment? There is no rationale for these sorts of distinctions in this day and age because the technology has changed, but the sales tax law has not been brought up to date to acknowledge that they should have equal treatment as they are essentially using the same processes and equipment.

—We can chase ourselves around in circles on this. I understand the concerns of the industry; they have been referred to the Treasurer. At this stage the Government does not have any intention of making any changes and we are certainly not seeking to do it through this vehicle. We can have a debate about it some other time. We may lose the support and even the attention of some of our colleagues were we to start it now. All I can say is that it is not our intention to amend this Bill at this time in that way.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Subject to Item 108 of Schedule 1, goods made from cardboard or paper for the use in marketing take-away beverages or foodstuffs (whether for consumption on the premises from which they were sold or elsewhere), where all the cardboard or paper used in the goods is recycled paper.
