SPEECH.PARA: I guess people will not be surprised to hear the Australian Democrats moving these amendments. We think that sales tax should be used to reward good business practices and to penalise bad ones. That can be extended to the issue of different media for packaging. These amendments seek to maintain the current 10 per cent rate for containers made from 100 per cent recycled paper but to tax all other containers at a new rate of 20 per cent. We think that would create a fiscal incentive for people who use these containers to move to packaging made from recycled paper.

PARA.TAB: I know the issue is complex. If one wants to take it to its logical conclusion, one should take into account the total energy life cycle of products and one should look at weight and volume of packaging, et cetera. The issue is important and we should be sending the right signals. I regret that the Government and the Opposition will not be supporting these amendments. But I guess the least we could hope for is that the Government will take up this issue in the national waste minimisation and recycling strategy which is now under way.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be supporting these particular amendments moved by the Australian Democrats. However, we wish to take this opportunity to draw the Government's attention to the need under a simplicity program or tax simplification agenda to follow the well-recognised precedent in sales tax law—for which we seem to have some departure here, which is unfortunate. The containers should bear the same rate of sales tax as the goods that those containers carry. So if the goods are exempt, it follows that the containers themselves should be exempt.

PARA.TAB: Otherwise one would run into some unusual situations whereby if one buys a wrapped pie directly from the manufacturer the wrapping is exempt; but, if the wrapping is put on in the shop, it is not exempt. The problem is certainly exacerbated under the legislation that we have before us. I think that the takeaway food area, such as McDonald's and Kentucky Fried Chicken, in particular is disadvantaged by the Government's decision not to adhere to the principle that the packaging should follow the same rate of tax as the goods themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting these amendments either. I am not a renowned purist in these matters but these amendments would introduce a concept whereby goods could qualify for different rates of tax depending on how they were used. Overall, we think that amendments like these are not consistent with the simplification measure. We will not be supporting them.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting this amendment. Equipment used in servicing cars, buses or transport vehicles is not exempt. The maintenance of equipment used is very important in a lot of other industries, but it is not consistent with the whole fundamental framework of the legislation to provide this exemption. Without this exemption the industry has done fairly well up until now. The prospect that it is suddenly going to stop being safety conscious because the law is not changed is somewhat unlikely.

—The nature of this debate tonight indicates the need for an annual corrections Bill. Is the Government considering such a Bill in relation to sales tax law to remove certain anomalies? One of the inherent problems of sales tax law is that there are a number of inconsistencies and anomalies and the appropriate vehicle to bring about a level playing field is an annual corrections Bill. It is imperative for good administration to remove those inconsistencies.

PARA.TAB: I will use a quick example. SALES TAX IMPOSITION (GENERAL) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bills—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.

Sales Tax Imposition (Excise) Bill 1992, Sales Tax Imposition (Customs) Bill 1992 and Sales Tax Imposition (General) Bill 1992 reported without amendments or requests; Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992, Sales Tax Amendment (Transitional) Bill 1992 and Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill 1992 reported with amendments but without requests; report adopted.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the Bills be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this time of the night I shall be very brief. On behalf of the coalition, I want to indicate that we will be voting against all of these Bills. We will only call one division, but we will be opposing each of the Bills.

PARA.TAB: Certainly the Bills, as now amended, are an improvement on the Bills that were first introduced into the Parliament and guillotined through the House of Representatives. A similar attempt was made to guillotine them through here. It should be noted that the Bills are better now than they were because of the action of the Senate in establishing a select committee, which did at least give some scope for their examination. As a result, some of the worst features of the Bills have been changed or removed.

The Bills remain totally objectionable to the Liberal and National parties. The sales tax regime is nothing more than a hidden consumption tax which takes from taxpayers without their knowing some $10 billion a year. That sum has more than trebled in the nine years of Labor government. I find it quite ironic that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), in introducing his new tax legislation today, said that in doing so the Keating Labor Government would not be introducing a broadly based consumption tax. All I can say to the people of Australia is that they should not believe that. The wholesale sales tax is a consumption tax. It is a hidden consumption tax. The actions of this Government in its approach to policy making and, particularly, government spending would necessitate, if it were to remain in government—thank God it will not be—its introduction of a broadly based consumption tax.

The amended legislation remains poisoned with the anomalies and inconsistencies that are inherent in a wholesale sales tax regime of this nature. The Bills remain profoundly hostile to business. Many important matters which were dealt with in the 150 submissions that the Select Committee on the Sales Tax Legislation received have not been considered either by that Committee or by the Senate and I believe that the legislation still contains inherent defects which, as I have said, a tax regime of this nature can never wash out.

This exercise has been much more than a simplification exercise.`Simplification' is a total misnomer for it. There have been some major policy changes. There have been significant extensions of coverage of the sales tax regime. It has not been a simplification procedure because one cannot simplify legislation of this nature unless one tackles the multi-rate structure and the whole question of exemptions and classifications. Neither of those has been attempted to be tackled in the Government's so-called simplification exercise. Indeed, we have had the extraordinary situation both at the Select Committee stage and tonight of the Government admitting its awareness of anomalies and of its having said equally openly that it is not going to take action to remove or correct those anomalies.

As I say, this is a hidden consumption tax. It is being extended by stealth. It is being extended overtly as well in this legislation. There remain inherent problems with the Government's wholesale sales tax regime. There is no way that a tax of this nature can have the inherent difficulties and problems with it corrected. One obvious example—there are many others—is that it is a tax which automatically cascades into the cost structure, thereby increasing the costs of doing business and of manufacturing and producing goods and services in this nation of hours at a time when we need to be more productive and more cost competitive. This works against the interests of those basic objectives.

That is why the next government of this country—a Hewson coalition government—will abolish the wholesale sales tax and replace it with a goods and services tax, bringing the indirect taxation system of this nation into line with the rest of the developed world and with the needs of a nation such as ours that desperately needs growth and development. The taxation needs are for a fair and equitable, simple, efficient and certain indirect tax regime. That is what a goods and services tax can produce for this country. That is something that a wholesale sales tax regime will never be able to achieve, no matter how much we may tinker with it. For that reason the coalition will be opposing these Bills.
Question put:
That the Bills be now read a third time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a third time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received the following message from the House of Representatives:

TAB.TAB: Message No. 610

PARA.TAB: Mr President,
The House of Representatives transmits to the Senate the following resolution which was agreed to by the House of Representatives this day and requests the concurrence of the Senate therein:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the resolution of appointment of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act be amended by omitting paragraphs (1) and (16) and substituting the following paragraphs:

PARA.TAB: (1)That a joint select committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, be appointed to inquire into and report on:

TAB.TAB: (a)the provisions and operation of the Family Law Act 1975 and, where the committee thinks appropriate and necessary, make such recommendations for amendments to the Family Law Act and other action in respect of:
(i)the role, funding, effectiveness and availability of the services of:
(A)the Family Court Counselling Service, and
(B)approved organisations providing marriage counselling and family mediation services;
(ii)the proper resolution of custody, guardianship, welfare and access disputes;

(iii)the proper resolution of family law property disputes, including the question whether it is desirable that the Family Law Act be extended to property disputes arising out of de facto relationships;
(iv)the effective enforcement of rights and duties under the Family Law Act;

(v)the exercise of discretion by the courts, including the question whether it is desirable to better structure the exercise of the discretion of the courts in making orders determining disputes in relation to children or property;

(vi)the adversarial nature of proceedings under the Family Law Act and their associated legal costs, including the question whether amendments to the Act or other action are desirable to require or encourage greater use of arbitration, mediation or other forms of alternative dispute resolution;
(vii)the prohibition in the Family Law Act on the publication of accounts of proceedings which identify parties, witnesses or other persons associated with the proceedings; and
(viii)the retiring age for judges of the Family Court of Australia; and
(b)the administration of the Family Court of Australia to assess:
(i)the base level of funding required to enable the Court to undertake its statutory functions at a level that will meet the reasonable expectations of the Parliament; and
(ii)the effectiveness of present expenditure by the Court towards undertaking those functions and meeting those expectations.
'(16)That the committee report to each House of the Parliament, for term of reference (1)(a) by 17 December 1992, and, for term of reference (1)(b) as soon as possible'.

PARA.TAB: Ronald Edwards, Acting Speaker
Ordered that the message be considered forthwith.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:
That the Senate concurs with the resolution of the House of Representatives as contained in message No. 610.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the deliberations of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act on its report, which is now in a draft stage, the Committee came to the conclusion that the report would be inadequate and incomplete if the report did not address the question of the funding of the Family Court of Australia. Whilst the funding of the Court was not one of the terms of reference given to the Committee when it was established in March last year, many of the submissions received by the Committee did address this matter and there is an acceptance that funding levels may impact upon the ability of the Family Court to undertake its statutory functions. The effectiveness of the present expenditure by the Court is also raised in many submissions.

PARA.TAB: The funding of the Family Court has also been the subject of a number of press articles in recent times, including one such article in a Western Australian newspaper on Wednesday, 9 September which reported on a speech by Chief Justice Nicholson to a family law conference in Perth. The Committee instructed me as Chairman to write to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and inquire about how we might address the dilemma and to explore avenues and actions on how the Committee might fulfil its obligations to the Parliament. I thank the Attorney-General for his cooperation on this matter.

The Committee envisages that the additional reference will be expeditiously dealt with. To this end, the Committee will not be advertising for further public submissions but it will be inviting a number of organisations and individuals to expand upon their original submissions. It is the objective of the Committee to present its report on its earlier references to the Parliament by mid-November of this year and to report on the additional reference by the first sitting day of next year. Question resolved in the affirmative.

In the interests of completeness and in keeping with the principle of making details of the remuneration and allowances of members of the Parliament publicly available, I also table on behalf of the President details of allowances paid to senators who are not chairs of committees.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, earlier this month, a Chinese dissident leader who had gone back to China for the first time since the Tiananmen Square massacre was arrested. That arrest caused some concern around the world. The matter has taken on greater significance following the presentation recently of a report from a joint parliamentary committee which inquired into the status of refugees within Australia.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to read a message on behalf of the Federation for a Democratic China. It has been sent to me; it is addressed to the Australian Parliament. The message reads:

1 September 1992, Chinese government arrested Mr Shen Tong, the first student leader in Tiananmen Square who returned to China. It was in the background that Chinese government just announced, as always, that `we warmly welcome all overseas students and scholars to come back to China. Your future will be guaranteed regardless of your opinions and activities in the past.'
Chinese Minister for Social Security, TAO Si-ju once promised to senators of the US Congress during his visit to America. . . `Shen Tong will be all right if he returns to China,' he said
The arrest of Shen Tong once again shows the Chinese government's natural instincts of continuously violating human rights and defying world opinions.

We earnestly request the Parliament and Australian Government to continuously note the human rights situation in China and put pressure on the Chinese Government to release Mr Shen Tong as well as all other political prisoners and stop persecuting dissidents in any form.
Thanking you!
Yours sincerely,
The Federation for a Democratic China, Australia

Mr Deputy President, it is appropriate that this message be conveyed to the Australian Parliament because the events taking place in China and in particular the human rights situation there are relevant to us as it is highly likely that the Australian Government will decide that Chinese students will be required to return to China unless they can demonstrate genuine refugee criteria to enable them to stay. In that context, the treatment that the Chinese Government has dished out in recent days to dissidents who have chosen to return to China is a relevant factor. I hope that the Australian Government will take this case and similar cases into consideration when making decisions on the status of Chinese refugees who may be required to return to that country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to the Taxation Commissioner's changed view on the derivation of receipt under a swap contract, which was first advised to industry on 27 February 1992, will a final ruling based upon this changed view be applied to any taxpayer on contracts from 27 February 1992.

(2) In following audit trails, is the Australian Taxation Office aware of the considerable cost that could be incurred by that taxpayer in calculating both expense and income for prior years and aligning deductibility and derivation with the proposed changed view.

(3) Is the Commissioner now reconsidering his changed view, and the applicability to this changed view to the spreading of both deductibility and derivation of income in line with accounting principles, such principles be referred to in Arthur Murray (NSW) Pty Limited v FC of T (1965) 114 CLR 314 and the Australian Guarantee Corporation Limited v FC of T 84 ATC 4642, where those cases relate to the derivation of income the accrual of an expense, respectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The meeting on 27 February 1992 referred to by the honourable senator was held to discuss issues raised in various submissions received by the Tax Office in response to its draft ruling on interest rate swaps (EDR45) with a view to reaching some finality on the ruling.

Matters discussed included the point of time at which obligations arose under commonly used swap documentation, the technical merits of the due and payable/due and receivable basis of tax accounting for swaps expressed in EDR 45 (compared with argument that relevant case law would support an accruals basis for some categories of business taxpayers), and the appropriate date of application of final ruling.

(2 and 3) At the meeting of 27 February 1992, industry and professional representatives expressed some misgivings about the view that, under the most common swap contracts, swap receipts are derived and swap payments are incurred for tax purposes at the beginning of each relevant calculation period. Their concern was that such a view was not consistent with tax accounting practices adopted in either the banking and finance industry or the non-finance corporate sector.

Since this question was raised by the honourable senator the final Ruling, IT 2682, has been issued by the Commissioner. The Ruling accepts that payments and receipts under an interest rate swap agreement can be brought to account on a daily accruals basis.

This view was arrived at by the ATO after further detailed analysis of the most common documentation under which interest rate swaps are written, taking into account the various submissions received in response to EDR45 and the application of the relevant case law.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that in the Taxation Laws Amendment Act 1992 there is a possible unintended consequence of Section 14 of the Act which purports: `to ensure that there is not an unintended mismatch of expenditure on stock intended to be used as trading stock and income derived in relation to the disposal of the stock before the stock becomes trading stock on hand', that this apparent unintended consequence occurs in the case of a primary producer whose activities involved breeding cattle or producing crops, and that the outcome of those activities results in `trading stock' because of the definition of that term in section 6 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

(2) Does the Minister agree that it is unintended and unfair that expenditure relevant to these activities will now have to be claimed not in the year of expenditure but in the year in which the livestock or crops come into the primary producers' financial calculations.

(3) Is the Minister aware that one way to rectify the problem could be to insert the words, `other than livestock or crops relevant to a business of primary production' after `trading stock' in paragraph 51(2A)(a).

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that, in his opinion, subsection 51 (2A) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 can apply only to expenditure on the acquisition of stock that is expected to come on hand as trading stock of the taxpayer but has not come on hand by the end of the year of income. Expenditure by a primary producer on the purchase of, for example, fertilizer, fuel, seed for crops or the semen or embryos used in animal breeding is not in that category. The Commissioner does not consider that the words "will become" are used in the subsection to describe the process by which, for example, seed acquired for planting grows into a crop ready for harvesting.

Further, the crop produced or the animal bred, while typically trading stock, would not, in the Commissioner's opinion, have been "acquired" with the expenditure in question. Such resulting trading stock would have been produced, not acquired. The terms "acquired" and "produced" are both used in the definition of "trading stock" in section 6 of the Act and the Commissioner considers that, in the related context of subsection 51(2A), the meaning of the term "acquired" does not include produced or, for that matter, manufactured.
The Commissioner intends making a public ruling on this matter.

While I do not, therefore, agree that the provision requires amendment, I note that the amendment suggested in the honourable senator's question would have the result that forward purchase contracts of the kind at which subsection 51 (2A) is specifically directed (explanatory memorandum, page 105) would be taken outside the provision if the contract was for the purchase of livestock. The Government could not accept that outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was the Laos Sugar Mill project, financed through IDC Credit, financed wholly or in part by Australian Aid funds or grants which included Australian taxpayers' funds; if so, on what date was the advance made to the World Bank.

(2) Does Australia make contributions to a general regional or Laotian fund with no funds being specifically targeted for individual projects; if so, how does Australia achieve its stated aid objective.

(3) If Australian funds were committed to this project: (a) will the loans be repaid to the Australian people on privatisation of the project; (b) did the feasibility study of the project take into account the then current Laotian sugar crop, if any; (c) was land to be appropriated from subsistence farming to grow sugar for export; (d) did the feasibility study take into account the then very depressed price and international over-supply of sugar; (e) what is the corporate structure of Batstone Technology Pty. Ltd,; (f) is Batstone Technology Pty. Ltd., a wholly Australian owned company or is it a wholly owned subsidiary of an international company and what is the name of that international company; and (g) what procedures does the official Australian Aid organisation have to handle the privatisation of aid projects financed through loans agreements such as international banks and the DIFF scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Laos Sugar Mill project was financed by International Development Association (IDA) credits. Australia's contributions to IDA form part of a multilaterally financed pool, in which funds are not differentiated according to their source. It is therefore not possible to say whether particular contributions were used to support particular projects. IDA funds are allocated at the direction of the Board of the World Bank which is vested with the authority to determine the conditions on which any loan is made.

AIDAB has advised that bilateral aid funds were used for two activities associated with the Laos sugar industry after the IDA tender to supply the sugar mill to Laos had been won by Batstone Technology Pty Ltd in June 1988.

After Batstone had won the tender, the Government of Laos requested AIDAB to fund a program of technical training associated with sugar production. This training program, valued at approximately $200,000, and funded by AIDAB on a grant basis, was conducted in Australia between August and November 1988 by the Batstone Company.

In July 1988, the Government of Laos requested further technical assistance and specialist inputs for the sugar industry. AIDAB agreed to fund a feasibility study which examined the production and processing of sugar at the Pak Sap operation, and an assessment of the technical assistance, equipment and other inputs necessary to ensure its viability and sustainability. The cost of the study was approximately $31,000.

(2) Australia supports the Asian Development Fund (ADF) which allows the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to lend highly concessional funds to the poorer developing member countries of the Bank in the Asia Pacific region, including Laos PDR. It also supports the IDA which enables the World Bank to lend on highly concessional terms to poorer countries, including in the Asian region and to Laos PDR. Contributions to both IDA and the ADF are untied and provided on a grant basis. The main functions of IDA and the ADF are to foster economic and social development in developing countries. These are major Australian aid objectives.
(3) As outlined in (1), Australian funds were not directly committed to the financing of the Laos Sugar Mill project.

(a) The Government of Laos is required to repay the IDA credit to the World Bank, whether or not the sugar mill is privatised. Repayments of IDA loans by developing country recipients are normally used by the World Bank in making new loans. They are not repaid to the contributor governments.
(b) The World Bank's Staff Appraisal Report of the Laos PDR Agricultural Production Support Project, which included the sugar mill project took into account the size of the Laotian sugar crop.
(c) Land was not appropriated from subsistence farming to grow sugar for exports; the purpose of the project was to increase sugar production for domestic consumption. Laos is a sugar importer.
(d) The Appraisal Study on which the project was based took into account the world price of sugar and the international sugar supply situation.

(e) Batstone Technology Pty Ltd is a registered Australian exempt proprietary company, limited by shares and incorporated in Victoria. According to the Australian Securities Commission all the shares are held beneficially by one Director.
(f) The information available from the Australian Securities Commission suggests that Batstone Technology Pty Ltd is a wholly Australian owned company.

(g) Loans by international development banks to which Australia subscribes (the World Bank, the ADB and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development) sometimes assist in the privatisation of public organisations as a means of encouraging economic growth. The conditions of those loans, like other loans, are determined by the respective boards of directors. Australia's representatives on the Boards are expected to judge such loans on their merit in accordance with the charters of the banks. The DIFF program is aimed at assisting Australian exporters to compete in the sale of capital equipment and related services in certain developing country markets. Ownership of the organisations purchasing Australian equipment or services financed by DIFF may be public or private.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has despatched a number of letters to taxpayers informing them that according to their records they have received undeclared income from various banks and building societies.

(2) Many of those taxpayers either did not have accounts at such institutions or had not earned the interest income stated, therefore: (a) how many taxpayers have received such letters and have informed the ATO that they have received incorrect notices; and (b) what plan of action is the ATO following in order to minimise this tax file number computer problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. As part of the Income Matching System (IMS), the ATO compares the interest income details provided by financial institutions with the information provided by taxpayers in their returns of income.

In cases where there is a minor discrepancy the taxpayer is advised by letter of such and informed that in future all interest income for a financial year should be included in his or her return. This procedure enables the ATO to avoid costly amendment action in cases involving relatively small amounts and yet protects the revenue by ensuring that taxpayers are aware of their taxation obligations.
Approximately 14,000 of these warning letters have issued since 1 July 1992.

(2)(a) Nearly 500 taxpayers. The majority of disputes resulted from incorrect information supplied by the financial institutions. Approximately 160 of the disputes were as a result of incorrect matching by the ATO. Procedures have been revised to eliminate these mismatching errors.

(2)(b) The matter raised by the honourable senator has nothing to do with the Tax File Number (TFN) system. The matching process referred to above was in relation to interest details provided by financial institutions prior to the implementation of the Tax File Number (TFN) requirements. Future reporting of interest details by financial institutions will be under the TFN system and the problem of mismatching one taxpayer's name with another will not arise.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 July 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the tax deductibility of election expenses incurred by candidates at Federal, State and Local Government elections:

(1) Is the Minister aware that while election expenses incurred by taxpayers on their own behalf are tax deductible, expenses incurred by a person who is not a taxpayer are not tax deductible even though the expenses may have been met by the spouse of the candidate who is a taxpayer.
(2) Does this tax treatment anomaly disadvantage a large sector of the community, especially those single income families where the non-taxpayer is the candidate for election.

(3) Is this different approach to candidates' tax treatment a disincentive for persons who are not in paid employment to seek elected office, especially in those legislatures where party political financial assistance is minimal or non-existent, or for those persons who seek to be elected as independent candidates; if so, does this tax treatment anomaly conform with any or all equality of opportunity provisions enshrined in Australian law or with all international conventions, covenants or treaties to which Australia is a party: if not, does the Government contemplate any measures to correct the anomaly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) The Government does not consider this treatment to be anomalous. A fundamental principle of the Australian taxation system is that deductions are allowable against a taxpayer's assessable income to the extent to which expenditure is incurred in gaining or producing that assessable income. Expenditure incurred by another person cannot be offset against a taxpayer's assessable income.
Deductions of a concessional nature such as that allowed for election expenses incurred follow the same principle.

(3) This principle is not dissimilar to the general deduction principles of tax laws in other countries and has been part of the Australian taxation system since its inception. The Government is not contemplating any changes to this fundamental principle.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Government's sales tax legislation before the Parliament in the Autumn sittings, has the existing sales tax exemption on sun hats been removed; if so, does this mean that hats will now cost more to consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Sun hats are regarded as clothing for human wear and as such they will remain exempt from sales tax under the new sales tax legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Corporate Plan of the Australian Taxation Office for 1992/94, which stated that by 30 June 1992 the responses to monitoring of the quality of oral and written enquiries would be available to the public—Will the Minister release the results of its Taxpayers' Assistance Group's monitoring of the quality of responses to oral and written enquiries.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Corporate Plan for 1991-94 states that the Taxpayer Assistance Group would develop, pilot and implement nationally a process to monitor the quality of responses to oral and written enquiries by 30 June 1992.

This is a benchmarking process on the current level of the quality of oral and written advice. These benchmarks will be used to gauge the improvements made in the quality monitoring processes in the Branch Offices. Results from the national benchmarking process will be released.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 19 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that 1993 has been designated by the United Nations as International Year of Indigenous People, with an official launch scheduled in New York on 10 December 1992.
(2) What activities have been planned to mark this year which focuses on human rights and social justice for all indigenous people.
(3) Has a departmental officer been nominated to work with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in planning and co-ordinating activities for International Year of Indigenous People.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) Australian Archives plans to publish in 1993 the first of its detailed guides to records held in its repositories relating to Aboriginal people, including family and community histories. The first guide will be to records held in the ACT Regional office. There is also an ongoing focus, not limited to 1993, on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people through programs administered by my portfolio:
the Government has committed additional resources in 1992-93 to extend the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Electoral Information Service administered by the Australian Electoral Commission;

Purchasing Australia, in support of recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, is promoting initiatives to maximise opportunities for employment and training of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the context of contracts for Commonwealth goods and services;
Australian Archives, also in support of recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, is addressing the storage of, and access to, the Royal Commission's records;

DAS Projects seeks to employ Aboriginal communities in infrastructure work it manages for local Shire Councils in Aboriginal communities. This practice provides employment and training for Aboriginal people, increases Aboriginal ownership of infrastructure projects and returns Shire Council funds for projects to the local Aboriginal community; and
the Department of Administrative Services has developed a DAS Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Recruitment and Career Development Plan for 1992-93 to 1994-95.
(3) Yes. DAS has a National Account Manager specifically for work with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 18 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the recent Earth Summit in Rio De Janeiro and the need to slow down the rate of greenhouse gas emissions:
(1) What steps does the Government have under consideration to encourage the more efficient use of fuel by Government and private transport.
(2) Would the abolition of fuel tax encourage an increased use of vehicles and a rise in the volume of vehicle emissions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) A number of actions are being addressed by the Government to encourage the more efficient use of fuel in the transport sector as one of the measures for lowering greenhouse gas emissions. Following on from the release of the Ecologically Sustainable Development (ESD) reports in November 1991, the National Greenhouse Steering Committee (a Commonwealth-State officials group) released in June 1992 the Draft National Greenhouse Response Strategy (NGRS) Discussion Paper. The Discussion Paper canvasses a range of measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, including in relation to the transport sector (pp. 36-46). These measures cover both government and private transport. Following a period of public consultation and further development, the Strategy is to be presented to Heads of Government for endorsement at the end of 1992. A copy of the Draft NGRS Discussion Paper has been forwarded to the honourable senator and to the Table Office.

(2) Yes. The connection between fuel price and fuel usage is well documented. For example, the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics Occasional Paper 103 of 1991 `Demand Forecasts and Demand Elasticities for Australian Transport Fuels' showed that fuel consumption would rise with a drop in fuel prices. A 10% drop in fuel prices would give rise to a 6.6% increase in petrol consumption and a 5.5% increase in diesel consumption. Increased fuel consumption resulting from an increase in vehicle usage would lead to additional greenhouse gas emissions as well as air pollutants, traffic noise, and congestion.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Social Security: Media Releases

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) For what period of time has it been the practice of the Department of Social Security to circulate the Minister for Social Security's media releases either by fax or by mail.

(2) How many copies of each of the media releases by the Minister for Social Security titled `Pensioner Fightback Flop', `Hewson's Youth Wage Much too Low' and `Hewson using 1960's Data', all of which are party political and attack the opposition's policies, have been so far circulated by mail by the department and at what cost.
(3) Is the Secretary of the Department aware of the practice of his department using its resources to circulate ALP party political propaganda, and does it have his approval.
(4) Who authorised the department to mail out the media releases by the Minister for Social Security, especially those which are of a highly party political nature.

(5) Given that the department does use taxpayers' funds to circulate propaganda coming out of the office of the Minister for Social Security, material which contains no information content other than to attack the Opposition, will the department also agree to circulate the media releases by the opposition spokesman on Social Security using the same mail lists it is currently using to circulate the Minister's media releases; if not why not.
(6) Given that the department has been mailing out the media releases by the Minister for Social Security, does the department and its Secretary endorse the views contained in those releases.

(7) If the department and its Secretary do not endorse the views contained in the Minister's media releases, how do the department and the Secretary justify circulating those media releases at public expense.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

PARA.TAB: (1) It has been a long standing practice across various administrations for Commonwealth Government Departments to distribute ministerial media releases.

(2) The department has distributed a total of 4766 copies of the media releases titled `Pensioner Fightback Flop', `Hewson's Youth Wage Much too Low' and `Hewson using 1960's Data' at a cost of $2,924.70.
(3) and (4) The content and means of distribution for ministerial media releases are matters for the Minister.

(5) It is a general long standing practice for all ministerial media releases to be distributed from portfolio mailing lists. Parliament requires the listing of ministerial media releases in departmental annual reports presumably in acknowledgment that production and distribution are administrative functions of departments.
(6) and (7) See answer to (3) and (4) above.

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the department or any of its statutory authorities make available or approve any grants to trade unions or community groups in the financial year 1991-92; if so, in each case: (a) what is the name of the trade union or community group which received the funds; (b) what was the amount of the grant; (c) what was the purpose of the grant; (d) under what program was the grant made; and (e) was any contribution made by the trade union or community group towards the project and what amounts were involved.

(2) Have any similar grants been approved for 1992-93; if so, in each case: (a) what is the name of the trade union or community group which received the funds; (b) what was the amount of the grant; (c) what was the purpose of the grant; (d) under what program was the grant made; and (e) was any contribution made by the trade union or community group towards the project and what amounts were involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Department of Finance, the Australian National Audit Office and the Retirement Benefits Office have not made available or approved any grants to trade unions or community groups in the financial years 1991-92 or 1992-93.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Rail Link to Port of Brisbane

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 20 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How much funding has the Federal Government provided to the Queensland Government for construction of a dual gauge rail-link to carry freight to the Port of Brisbane.
(2) Have any conditions been placed on this funding which must be met by the Queensland Government before the money is provided; if so, what are those conditions.

(3) Is the Minister aware of the widespread concerns expressed by Brisbane residents that constructing the rail line along the existing rail corridor will result in increased noise problems, and that the Draft Impact Assessment Study has recommended that a State School may need to be moved because of the impact of the increased noise from rail freight traffic.

(4) Will the Government reconsider introducing compensation payments for Australians suffering injurious affection from such projects, as recommended in the Australian Law Reform Commission Report No.14.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Federal Government will contribute $30 million to the cost of the project. This is part of an $89 million project to improve the rail connection to the Port of Brisbane, including terminal facilities at the Port. I understand that the remaining funds will be provided by National Rail ($10 million), Queensland Rail ($19 million) and the Port of Brisbane Authority ($30 million).

(2) Approval of the expenditure is subject to Queensland providing an assurance that the project conforms to Federal and State environmental requirements relating to the environment, heritage, Aboriginal lands and sacred sites.

(3) I am aware that there has been concern that the proposed rail link will lead to increased noise problems. I understand that the Draft Impact Assessment Study prepared by the Queensland Government has found that opposition from residents has largely been based on concern over existing rail noise together with fears of increased noise because of the proposed standard gauge link. However, the Study has found that the proposed standard gauge traffic will, by itself, cause a relatively small noise impact. Freight traffic on the narrow gauge track is the major cause of complaint against the existing rail line. I under-

ANSWER.PARA: stand this traffic will continue to grow whether or not the standard gauge project proceeds.

PARA.TAB: The Study recommends a number of measures to reduce noise as well as a design study for specific noise barriers. The Queensland Minister for Transport, the Hon D J Hamill MLA, has advised me that he has endorsed these recommendations.

The Study notes that the State School referred to is currently affected by rail noise from existing narrow gauge operations. The main impact is from intrastate freight trains, which produce maximum noise levels of up to 90 dBA. Construction of the new line will allow greater freedom to schedule these narrow gauge freight trains in daytime because existing constraints due to scheduling of passenger services will not apply. The Study indicates that it is this increased number of daytime freight movements, rather than additional standard gauge traffic, which may exacerbate the situation and make relocation of the school an option worthy of consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 8 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Greenslopes Repatriation General Hospital:
(1) What are the Government's intentions with respect to Wards 14 and 15 and is the Government considering the closure of these wards; if so, why.
(2) If it is the Government's intention to close down these wards what arrangements will be made for patients normally admitted to these wards.
(3) What impact will these proposed changes have on negotiations for the transfer of Greenslopes from the Commonwealth to the State health system.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Wards 14 and 15 provide inpatient and urgent outpatient psychiatric services. These services are to be maintained and specific arrangements will be agreed with the Queensland Government when integration occurs. Specific ward arrangements have yet to be considered. No immediate changes are planned.
(2) and (3) See answer to (1).
